subject: The Best Engineering Jobs in 2019
body: Consider taking a remote job? The ASME Career Center can help! Good news, check out The Best Jobs in Engineering With pay that outpaces the averages of most other industries, and positive hiring projections for the foreseeable future, careers in engineering offer some of the most attractive opportunities in the American workforce. But the label â€œengineeringâ€ covers a wide spectrum. Green technology and aerospace sciences are two entirely unique avenues, and both are covered in CareerCast.comâ€™s Jobs Rated Report on the Best Jobs in Engineering in 2019. The top locations for both employment and income for some of the best engineering jobs are Texas, California, Oklahoma, Chicago, Dallas-Fort Worth-Arlington metropolitan areas, and Alaska. The three highest average incomes for the engineering profession are in Chicago, Dallas and Anchorage, Alaska. CareerCast.com tracks the Top 10 Best Jobs in Engineering on an annual basis in itâ€™s Job Rated Report and virtually all engineering careers have a positive projected growth outlook, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics forecasts. Petroleum Engineer is #1 with a 15% projected growth rate, followed by Aerospace Engineer at #2 with a 6% projected growth rate. Mechanical Engineer made it to #6 of the Top 10 with a projected growth rate of 6% and a median salary of $87,370. In terms of sheer numbers of projected Mechanical Engineering jobs added to the economy by 2028, this is one of the leaders with 12,800. Credit the versatility needed to become a Mechanical Engineer, with professionals boasting a repertoire that translates to a variety of different job sectors. Beyond brining you the annual Jobs Rated Report - Best Jobs in Engineering the ASME Career Center offers advice on job hunting, resume writing, networking, interviewing, career guidance and much more. Post your resume today and let hiring companies find you. Post Your Resume! â†’ The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) 012920- 18561 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Nuclear Rockets for Mars Space Travel
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter How to overcome the challenges of connecting smart cars and smart cities 01.30.2020 Podcast: Connecting Cars with Smart Cities The Internet of Things is the key building block in the development of smart cities. Connecting cars and other vehicles to each other and smart traffic monitoring systems is essential for their development. Rob Tiffany, vice president of IoT strategy for Ericsson, talks about the obstacles in developing connectivity. The Future of Nuclear Rockets for Space Travel The Nuclear Thermal Rocket Element Environment Simulator (NTREES) is crucial for future missions to Mars. Bill Emrich, a longtime NASA employee and lead engineer at NTREES, has dedicated his life to developing viable nuclear rockets, which will not only send astronauts into deep space but also bring them back home. Bioengineering Blog: Tools to Accelerate the Development of Energy-Based Medical Devices Using tissue effect simulation, tightens requirements and accelerates progress on a medical device while simplifying the research tool, reducing lengthy and costly requirements for both. This translates to faster time to market, an earlier platform launch, and more revenue. QUIZ: What Do You Know About Autonomous Cars? When was the first self-driving car demonstrated? 1995 1925 1939 2003 FEATURED WHITE PAPERS Design Basics: Continuous-Flex Cables Choosing the right cable can mean the difference between a few thousand and tens of millions of cycles. Get design guidelines that maximize performance and service life. Ford Optimizes Manufacturing with 3D Printed Tooling Learn how Ford has integrated 3D printing into its workflow to create custom manufacturing tooling. subject: 5 Ways Mechanical Engineers Can Boost Their Salary
body: ASME TechWorkforce - ME Magazine Newsletter ASME's Volunteers are a cornerstone of the organization 01.30.2020 ASME Volunteers: The Pulse of Our Society ASME CEO Thomas Costabile speaks with exemplary ASME volunteer Pasquale Dell'Aquila on the work he has done for both the Oregon Section and the Society. After 140 years, volunteers are key to ASME's future as much as the young engineering student members as they embark on new careers. Workforce Blog: A Wonderful Day to Make a Difference ASME is launching a campaign to help improve the quality of life around the world, particularly in underserved communities. Editor-in-Chief of Mechanical Engineering magazine, John G. Falcioni, shares his thoughts on how making a positive difference in people's lives cannot be underscored enough. Infographic: 5 Ways to Boost Your Engineering Salary There are always ways for mechanical engineers to increase their salaries. Most approaches require planning and a significant investment in time, money, and education. Here are five ways to start boosting your engineering salary. QUIZ: Which Schools Offer the Best Undergraduate Engineering Programs? Which school offers the best undergraduate program in mechanical engineering? subject: Smart Planes to Fly Like a Bird
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter A Timeline of the 3D Printing Industry 02.04.2020 How Espresso Machines Work: The Engineering Inside Do you know what it takes to make a perfect espresso shot? Modern espresso machine design is not only about pressure technology and mechanics, but it involves 3D printing, energy-efficient technology, modeling and simulation, IoT, and lots of caffeine for engineers. Building a Plane that Flies by Feel By stretching force sensors across the entire surface of a wing to sense the air moving over it, Stanford University researchers hope to create smart aircraft that feel and think like a bird. Kirigami Tutorial for Engineers How do you turn a flat material into just about anything? Origami is one path. Now, using mathematics, researchers at Harvard have shown that a few cuts can produce just as unlimited results. Inspired by kirigami, they developed an algorithm that is likely to become a useful tool for engineers. Sponsored Ad Join Us at the 2020 AMUG Conference AMUG brings a unique experience to additive manufacturing where attendees are eager to share insights. Designed to facilitate information exchange between AM users, the conference brings together individuals of all experience levels. March 22- 26, 2020. Infographic: The History of 3D Printing The history of 3D printing can be traced back to the 1980s. In the industry's infancy, several companies competed against each other to be the first to file patents and claim ownership over the market. Today, the technology has become open sourced, paving the way for numerous 3D printing companies to flourish. L&D COURSES Spring 2020 ASME Learning & Development Programs Sign-up for our Spring L&D courses to learn more about piping, gas turbines, nulcear energy, welding, and more. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals An eLearning course focusing on the different stages of production and manufacturing. subject: 3D Printing in Combat Areas and Space
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Oil Industries Crucial Partner for Climate Change 02.06.2020 Top 10 Bioengineering Trends Personalized medicine, miniaturization, material innovations, and additive manufacturing are key engineering trends that bioengineers are eager to incorporate into their designs. Here are the ten top trends for bioengineering R&D in 2020. 3D Printing in Hostile Environments The Fabrication in Austere Environments pilot program deployed a ruggerized 3D printer to an undisclosed desert locale to demonstrate that troops without engineering or medical degrees can easily and quickly 3D print all the necessary supplies and tools as they need them. In parallel to the military deployment, a similar experiment has been successfully conducted in another remote locationâ€”aboard the International Space Station. Energy Blog: The Oil Industry is Part of the Solution The quickest way to tackle climate change is to enlist the oil and gas industry as a critical partner. Petroleum companies have some of the deepest pockets and most technically capable workforces around. How are Mechanical Engineers and Canned Pineapples Related? Commercial pineapple production started about 1890. How were pineapples processed in that era? Pineapples were peeled and cut by hand to fit into standard size cans. Blades attached to steam-powered wheels whittled the pineapples to size. Large pineapples were forced into smaller diameter cans, with the outer portions thrown out as waste. The fruit was soaked in a lye solution until its tough outer skin fell off. L&D COURSES Spring 2020 ASME Learning & Development Programs Sign-up for our Spring L&D courses to learn more about piping, gas turbines, nuclear energy, welding, and more. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals An eLearning course focusing on the different stages of production and manufacturing. subject: Top 10 Growing Smart Cities
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter How to Train Your Robotic Dog 02.11.2020 Training Robots to Move Like Dogs Virginia Tech mechanical engineering assistant professor Kaveh Hamed is working to enhance bio-inspired locomotion in robots. Using control algorithms, AI, and sensors, his quadrupedal robots can trot and bound like dogs. They have also replaced cheerleaders to do push-ups to celebrate Hokies scoring points in football games. Top 10 Growing Smart Cities Smart cities around the world are developing quickly, fueled by expanding services of the Internet of Things. Here are 10 examples of cities committed to smart growth by leveraging technology and integrating an online population into new systems that make a city work smarter. Graphene Tool to Measure Light As light heats the tiny graphene drum, it heats up, expands, and the vibrational pitch changes. Tracking those pitch changes allows University of Oregon researchers to mechanically measure the amount of light hitting the device. The graphene nanobolometer is heat-resistant and can potentially be useful in countless applications. subject: Display Your Engineering Pride with a Framed ASME Membership Certificate
body: Display your pride with an ASME Membership Certificate! Let others know you are a Proud Member of ASME Connect with us: An ASME Membership Certificate will acknowledge your professional status and display your pride! By joining ASME, you have demonstrated your commitment to high professional standards. Let others know you are a member of the most respected professional mechanical engineering organization in the world by displaying an attractive, framed ASME Membership Certificate in your office or home. Every certificate is superbly printed on 8.5x11 quality grade paper with an embossed gold ASME seal. Your certificate will bear your name

subject: Smart Sails Provide Wind Power to Ships
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Test Your Knowledge on 5G Technology 02.13.2020 Inner Ear Implant Restores Balance One morning, A'ndrea Elyse Messer awoke to find she had no sense of balance. She couldn't walk without a cane. Then she discovered an experimental implant that restored her balance using a three-axis gyroscope and accelerometer. 7 Biggest Trends for Engineering in the 2020s Artificial intelligence will reshape engineering in the 2020s, from autonomous vehicles and robots to software that works with engineers to design and optimize their products. Today's discrete Industry 4.0 technologies will also grow more interconnected and more affordable for smaller firms, sparking a new wave of increasingly complex manufacturing operations and disruptive products. High-Tech Sails Bring Wind Power to Big Ships Suddenly, wind power is new again. Shipping companies are now experimenting with high-tech sailsâ€”everything from giant kites to rotating columns that work on the same principle as a curve ballâ€”in an effort to reduce fuel cost and emissions. What is the Future of 5G Technology? Which tech company was the first to release a 5G-enabled phone? subject: 5 Young Inventors Changing the World
body: ASME TechWorkforce - ME Magazine Newsletter Where in America do Mechanical Engineers Work? 02.14.2020 Podcast: Skills You Will Need for Aerospace Careers of Future Laura McGill, vice president of engineering at Raytheon Missile Systems, talks about the many job opportunities available for young engineers in the aerospace industry, her own career path, as well as offers management advice for large multi-generational engineering teams. Infographic: Where Do America's Mechanical Engineers Work? Mechanical engineers work in dozens of industries, and the technical divisions of ASME span from aerospace to tribology. According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, most work in different manufacturing sectors and in engineering services. 5 Young Inventors Aim to Change the World Anyone can be an inventor. In February, we honor the inventorsâ€”those who decided to change the world through the power of engineering. Here is a list of five young inventors, who have set out to better the world through the power of imagination and creativity. Flashback Friday: Celebrating Thomas Edison A biography of Thomas Edison could easily fill its pages with lists. Edison holds more patents than any other American, even 80 years after his death. In celebration of the National Inventors' Day, Engineers Week, and Edison's birthday, let's take a look back on his life in this ASME classic. subject: Call for Papers: Special Issue on Non-probabilistic and Hybrid Approaches for Uncertainty Quantification and Reliability Analysis
body: ASME Journal of Mechanical Design: Special Issue Call-for-Papers: 'Data-Driven Design (D3)' ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Eng. Systems Connect with us: ASME's Guide for Journal Authors Submit Your Manuscript â†’ CALL FOR PAPERS ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems, Part B: Mechanical Engineering Special Issue on Non-probabilistic and Hybrid Approaches for Uncertainty Quantification and Reliability Analysis (SI042B) Computational models have played a crucial role in the transition from a traditional experiment-centered engineering practice towards a virtual design context, where the performance of designed components is assessed long before the first prototype is built. Recent advances in numerical approaches enable in this context the application of hyper-resolution, high-fidelity, and first principle-based computer simulations which provide an analyst with a plethora of information on the design at hand. However, in most realistic engineering cases, the designer is faced with a multitude of sources of uncertainty on both the actual model form (i.e., the equations that have to be solved) and on the physical quantities that are used to parametrize these models. Such uncertainty stems either from the apparently pure random nature of some physical quantities (e.g., earthquake or wind loadings on a structure, or the mechanical behavior of complex materials such as soil or parts produced with Additive Manufacturing), incomplete knowledge on the actual value of these quantities (e.g., stemming from incomplete or too scarce data or future design decisions that yet have to be made), or a combination of both. When uncertainty stemming from incomplete knowledge is involved in the design process, non-probabilistic and hybrid/polymorphic approaches are gaining momentum for the assessment of the (bounds on the) reliability of designed structures and components, and the quantification of the underlying model response uncertainty. In this context, powerful techniques based on e.g., the framework of interval or fuzzy calculus, p-box formulations, information theory, Dempster-Shafer belief functions or game theoretical foundations, have been introduced in the last two decades. However, their application towards realistic engineering applications requires further developments both on a theoretical as well as a numerical/algorithmic level. Scope This Special Issue is aimed at gathering contributions that discuss new theoretical developments and advanced applications of non-probabilistic and hybrid approaches towards uncertainty quantification and reliability analysis. More specifically, papers discussing theoretical developments in the framework of non-probabilistic, hybrid, or polymorphic uncertainty and efficient numerical (or semi-) analytical propagation schemes for forward and inverse analysis with such uncertainty models are of particular interest for this Special Issue. In view of assisting the translation of these novel methods towards application, papers that apply these methods to challenging and realistic engineering cases in general are also welcomed, especially if the non-probabilistic or hybrid models for the uncertainty are based on real data. Indicative Topics: â€¢ New theoretical developments in the modeling of, and simulation with non-probabilistic or hybrid representations of uncertainty such as intervals, fuzzy sets, set-valued approaches, interval probabilities, credal sets, Dempster-Shafer belief functions, interval fields, or imprecise random fields. â€¢ Efficient propagation schemes for such non-probabilistic or hybrid representations, including new algorithmic developments, surrogate models, model order reduction, or low-rank representations. Publication Target Dates Paper submission deadline: May 31, 2020 Submission Instructions Papers should be submitted electronically to the Journal at journaltool.asme.org. If you already have an account, log in as author and select Submit Paper at the bottom of the page. If you do not have an account, select Submissions and follow the steps. In either case, at the Paper Submittal page, select the ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems, Part B: Mechanical Engineering and then in the Special Issue dropdown menu choose Non-probabilistic and Hybrid Approaches for Uncertainty Quantification and Reliability Analysis (SI042B). Prior to formal submission, please send a copy of your manuscript to the guest editors to ensure the work falls within the scope of the Special Issue and is otherwise appropriate for peer review. Guest Editors Matthias Faes, KU Leuven, Belgium, matthias.faes@kuleuven.be David Moens, KU Leuven, Belgium, david.moens@kuleuven.be Michael Beer, Leibniz University Hannover, Germany, beer@irz.uni-hannover.de Kok Kwang Phoon, National University of Singapore, Singapore, kkphoon@nus.edu.sg Hao Zhang, The University of Sydney, Australia, hao.zhang@sydney.edu.au The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® (ASMEÂ®) 021420 - 19560 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. ABOUT US | CONTACT US | PRIVACY | UNSUBSCRIBE | MANAGE PREFERENCES Add @asme.org to your e-mail address book or safe senders to ensure delivery of ASME emails to your inbox. subject: Star Trek's Top 7 Tech Innovations
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter CES 2020 Highlights in Robots and AI 02.18.2020 Video: CES 2020 Highlights in Robotics, AI, and Smart Vehicles The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is a showcase for the latest in technology innovation. The event covers almost every technical vertical you can imagine, from smart cars to virtual reality, to robots and digitally connected clothing. At this year's CES, one of the highlights was the increasing collaboration between machine and human operators via artificial intelligence and improved sensing. Sponsored Ad Designing the Most Effective Heat Exchanger High-temperature high-pressure heat exchangers could reduce the amount of fuel needed to power many industrial processes, reducing costs, and improving energy efficiency. To that end, engineers from Carnegie Mellon and UC Davis are working to create the most efficient heat exchanger by using new techniques for 3D printing. Infographic: 7 Most Inventive Technologies of Star Trek The writers for the original Star Trek series were not scientists or engineers, and they invented" futuristic technologies to further plots (or escape from narrative dead-ends). Find out how many of the innovations predicted on Star Trek have been reproduced in real life. Sponsored Ad Join Us at the 2020 AMUG Conference AMUG brings a unique experience to additive manufacturing where attendees are eager to share insights. Designed to facilitate information exchange between AM users

body: ASME 2019 IMECE: Call for Papers The IMECE Call for Abstracts Submission Deadline is March 16, 2020 Connect with us: Presenting at IMECEÂ® 2020 is the Best Way to Improve Your Research Submit an Abstract â†’ Abstract Submission Deadline: March 16, 2020 Do you want to build upon your research with different points of view? The International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition (IMECE) provides a conducive environment for professionals to engage the mechanical engineering field by presenting their latest research. A recent IMECE presenter said that the best part of IMECE was, â€œThe chance to present and receive feedback and [receive] excellent recommendations.â€ By presenting your research to peers from a variety of engineering fields, you will receive ideas and perspectives that could further enhance your research projects. One IMECE presenter states that â€œI think the conference (IMECE) is a great place to learn about the field and present your own work.â€ Donâ€™t miss this opportunity to present your research as there are 17 different IMECE 2020 tracks to choose from. subject: Brain Signals to Command Electronic Devices
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Top 10 Internet of Things Tech for 2020 02.20.2020 10 Best IoT Examples in 2020 The Internet of Things is rapidly transforming how we do business and live our daily lives. Today's IoT applications include home security, activity trackers, digital twins, self-healing mechanical systems, smart eyeglasses, ingestible sensors, smart farming, connected contact lenses, industrial security and safety, fleet management, and motion detection. Sponsored Ad Low-Carbon Concrete Can Fight Global Warming The production of concrete is responsible for as much as 10 percent of global carbon dioxide emissions. Research teams around the world are pursuing technologies to reduce concrete's carbon footprint. Some are being deployed cost-effectively today, while other, potentially even better solutions, are being developed in labs. Harnessing the Brain to Send Electronic Commands EEG headset monitors brain waves and uses machine learning to identify commands that are electronically executed without voice. Using an app, it can also monitor and set a baseline of a user's mental state that can be monitored over time. QUIZ: What Programs Make a City Smart? By 2022, this city plans on installing intelligent lighting on all public roads, and have solar panels installed on the roofs of 6,000 buildings: San Diego Copenhagen Kuala Lumpur Singapore L&D COURSES Spring 2020 ASME Learning & Development Programs Sign-up for our Spring L&D courses to learn more about piping, gas turbines, nuclear energy, welding, and more. Design by Stress Analysis per ASME BPV Code, Section III, Division 1: Class 1, 2 and 3 Components Providing guidance for applying the requirements of the updated Edition of Mandatory Appendix XIII Design by Stress Analysis per ASME BPV Code, Section III, Division 1 Class 1, 2 and 3 vessels, pumps, valves and piping in nuclear power plants. body: ASME News Feb. 21, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 4 / Feb. 21, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 4 / Feb. 21, 2020 Applications Due Soon for ASME Scholarships ASME student members who are interested in applying for one of the Societyâ€™s more than 80 scholarships â€” including 20 ASME IGTI Gas & Turbomachinery Scholarships and the new Petroleum Engineering Scholarship â€” should act now. Applications must be submitted by March 3. Read more Sponsored Ad Prevent Corrosion Under Insulation: A Two-Pronged Approach Preventing CUI is rarely a one-size fits all endeavor. There are a multitude of variables at play from the jacketing, to the insulation, to the weather that can influence your systemâ€™s ability to successfully inhibit CUI. Join experts from Johns Manville in the upcoming Insulation IntelÂ® webinar, Mitigating CUI: A Two-Pronged Approach, on Tuesday, Feb. 25 at 2:00PM ET & earn PDH Credit. If youâ€™re interested in presenting a full paper at the event, the deadline to submit an abstract is March 16. Applications will be accepted starting March 4, but the â€œplan and learnâ€ pre-application phase for the competition is now underway. In addition, nomination deadlines for several established Society awards are quickly approaching. Learn more â†’ ASME Issues â€œNâ€ Certification to NuScale Power ASME recently issued its â€œNâ€ Certificate of Authorization to Oregon-based NuScale Power, confirming the companyâ€™s successful demonstration of its commitment to safety and quality. The granting of the certificate marked a major milestone for the nuclear power industry and brought the industry a step closer to making small modular reactors a reality. Read more VOLT Academy Communication and Networking Training Held in Houston The ASME Petroleum Division and the South Texas Section, in conjunction with the Volunteer Orientation and Leadership Training (VOLT) Academy, recently sponsored a special training event for Society members titled, â€œCommunicating and Networking in ASME.â€ Read more Jayathi Murthy ASME Fellow Jayathi Murthy, Ph.D., dean of the UCLA Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science at the University of California, Los Angeles, was recently elected to the National Academy of Engineering. Membership in the NAE, a private nonprofit organization that honors exceptional engineers from around the world, is considered one of the highest professional honors an engineer can receive. Learn more â†’ Zoubeida Ounaies ASME Fellow Zoubeida Ounaies, Ph.D., professor and associate head of administration in the department of mechanical engineering at Pennsylvania State University, was named the inaugural director of the Penn State Convergence Center for Living Multifunctional Material Systems, a joint partnership with Germanyâ€™s University of Freiburg to design sustainable materials using biological and bioinspired principles. subject: ASME Journal of Medical Devices - Call for Papers: Special Issue on Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces
body: ASME Journal of Mechanical Design CALL FOR PAPERS Connect with us: ASME's Guide for Journal Authors Submit Your Manuscript â†’ CALL FOR PAPERS ASME Journal of Medical Devices Special Issue on Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces Significant advances have been made in the field of medical robotics in recent decades. Spanning series and parallel robotic architectures, rigid and soft materials, and a variety of control approaches, the potential for robotic applications in medicine remains vast. As the technologies underlying robotic solutions continue to mature and develop, new robotic medical applications will continue to emerge. A related area of growing interest is the interaction between human operators and robotic medical devices. Without appropriate and user-friendly interfaces, the uses of these technologies are limited. Haptic devices are an example of the profound effect that interface devices can have on practical functionality and applicability of technology in medical applications. The focus of this Special Issue is the intersection of medical robotics and human interfaces for medical applications. Topic Areas â€¢ Kinematics & dynamics for medical robotics â€¢ Exoskeletons & prostheses â€¢ Humanoid & service robots â€¢ Assistive robots & elderly assistance â€¢ Surgical robots â€¢ Human-robot interfaces â€¢ Haptic devices â€¢ Medical treatments using robotics & automation Publication Target Dates Paper submission deadline: June 15, 2020 Initial reviews completed: July 15, 2020 Special Issue publication date: December 2020 Submission Instructions Papers should be submitted electronically to the journal at journaltool.asme.org. If you already have an account, log in as author and select Submit Paper at the bottom of the page. If you do not have an account, select Submissions and follow the steps. In either case, at the Paper Submittal page, select the ASME Journal of Medical Devices and then select the Special Issue Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces. Papers received after the deadline or papers not selected for inclusion in the Special Issue may be accepted for publication in a regular issue. Special Issue Guest Editors Med Amine Laribi, PhD, Associate Professor, Institut PPRIME, DÃ©partement GÃ©nie MÃ©canique et SystÃ¨mes Complexes, CNRS, University of Poitiers, Poitiers, France med.amine.laribi@univ-poitiers.fr Carl Nelson, PhD, Professor, Mechanical and Materials Engineering, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE, USA cnelson5@unl.edu Nandini Duraiswamy, PhD, Biomedical Engineer, US Food and Drug Administration, Silver Spring, MD, USA Nandini.Duraiswamy@fda.hhs.gov The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® (ASMEÂ®) 022420 - 19609 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: New Space Drone to Explore Titan
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Generative Design Drives Creative Engineering 02.25.2020 Manufacturing Blog: Generative Design and Engineering Jobs CAD software uses generative design to autonomously create the geometry of a design. This sounds like another case of AI threatening engineering jobs, but according to industry consultant Chad Jackson, productivity boosts are not likelyâ€”but more creative engineering is. Sponsored Ad A New Drone Gets Ready to Explore an Unusual Planet Saturn's moon Titan is teeming with organic molecules that could support life. To explore it, engineers are building a drone that will take advantage of Titan's low gravity and super-dense atmosphere to travel long distances and even land on mountains. Infographic: Robots at Your Service The number of service robots being sold is increasing explosively. Some 361,000 professional service robots were expected to be sold in 2019, up from 271,000 in the previous year. This infographic shows the forecast for unit sales of service robots in 2019 and 2022. 6 Questions with Magic Leap's Cathy Hackl Cathy Hackl helps drive enterprise partner marketing initiatives for Magic Leap, a software startup company that developed an augmented reality spatial computing platformâ€”Magic Leap One. Is AR technology on the verge of disrupting the industry and becoming a powerhouse tool for engineers? L&D COURSES Spring 2020 ASME Learning & Development Programs Sign-up for our Spring L&D courses to learn more about piping, gas turbines, nuclear energy, welding, and more. subject: Top 10 Growing Smart Cities
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter 3D Printing and the Biocompatibility Challenge 02.27.2020 3D Printing Overcoming Biocompatibility Challenge U.S. medical devices and implants must all meet FDA standards for biocompatibility and safety. That is not easy for 3D-printed products since their material properties are not finalized until after they are produced. Yet engineers are making headway as 3D medical printing takes hold in the biomedical industry. New Tech to Find Shipwrecks Some of the world's biggest mysteries lie in the ocean's depths. Most of the estimated 3 million shipwrecks containing troves of historical and cultural artefacts, as well as real treasures, are still waiting to be discovered. Now, new innovative technology is helping humans to dive deeper, autonomously map and explore the seafloor, and discover new shipwrecks. Video: 10 Growing Smart Cities Smart cities around the world are developing quickly, fueled by expanding services of the Internet of Things. Smart cars, connected lights, new sustainable architecture, advanced data monitoring systems, and reusable energy systems are just some examples of how cities are becoming smarter. Watch this video to find out about ten examples of cities committed to smart growth. Bioengineering Blog: Visualization of Complex Ideas in Medical Devices Computational modeling and simulation aren't often thought of as communication tools, but when coupled with data visualization, they can become an effective way to communicate the operation of a medical device to a wide range of audiences, independent of their technical background. L&D COURSES Spring 2020 ASME Learning & Development Programs Sign-up for our Spring L&D courses to learn more about piping, gas turbines, nuclear energy, welding, and more. Bolted Joints and Gasket Behavior This course examines how to assess a successful value of bolt load, as well as explains the importance of specifying a tightening procedure. It introduces the subject of PVRC (Pressure Vessel Research Council) and leak tightness calculations. Text: Top 10 Growing Smart Cities ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter 3D Printing and the Biocompatibility Challenge 02.27.2020 3D Printing Overcoming Biocompatibility Challenge U.S. medical devices and implants must all meet FDA standards for biocompatibility and safety. That is not easy for 3D-printed products since their material properties are not finalized until after they are produced. Yet engineers are making headway as 3D medical printing takes hold in the biomedical industry. New Tech to Find Shipwrecks Some of the world's biggest mysteries lie in the ocean's depths. Most of the estimated 3 million shipwrecks containing troves of historical and cultural artefacts, as well as real treasures, are still waiting to be discovered. Now, new innovative technology is helping humans to dive deeper, autonomously map and explore the seafloor, and discover new shipwrecks. Video: 10 Growing Smart Cities Smart cities around the world are developing quickly, fueled by expanding services of the Internet of Things. Smart cars, connected lights, new sustainable architecture, advanced data monitoring systems, and reusable energy systems are just some examples of how cities are becoming smarter. Watch this video to find out about ten examples of cities committed to smart growth. subject: How Well Does an Engineering Major Pay?
body: ASME TechWorkforce - ME Magazine Newsletter Celebrate the Innovations of African American Engineers 02.28.2020 ASME TechCast: Siemens CEO Barbara Humpton In this ASME TechCast episode, Barbara Humpton, CEO of Siemens USA, talks about the role digital technology plays in building a sustainable world and improving lives. She also offers advice to young engineers on how they can get involved in addressing some of the biggest challenges facing humankind. Staying at the Forefront of Technology ASME is an engine for technology leadership, one that is fueled by the passionate dedication of our volunteers, members, and staff. While that passion can be seen throughout ASME, nowhere is it more evident than in the activities of ASME's Technical Events & Content (TEC) sector that plays a key role in making the Society the renowned engine of knowledge, safety, and prosperity that the world has come to know. Infographic: How Well Does an Engineering Major Pay The engineering profession is one of the most stable careers today. Find out how engineering ranks against other STEM majors, what your salary will be when you graduate, and some of the best U.S. cities offering engineering and STEM jobs. Sponsored Ad Quiz: Celebrating African American Engineers and Inventors Henry Blair was a farmer who could not read and signed his name with an x

subject: Top 10 Influential Women in Engineering
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Hacksmith Entertainment Turns Fantasy Into Reality 03.03.2020 How Long Can a Drone Stay in the Sky? Engineers at the University of Michigan are testing with an experimental high-altitude, long-endurance drone, called X-HALE, to develop long and thin aircraft wings that will keep aircraft aloft for months. Sponsored Ad James Hobson Turns Fantasy to Reality James Hobson has made a career turning fiction into reality. He has created movie realistic props based on popular characters such as Captain America and Wolverine. Along the way, his company Hacksmith Entertainment has become an engineering firm focused on the future. 10 Influential Women in Engineering There are many influential womenâ€”educators, innovators, leadersâ€”who are not only breaking the stereotype but are also role models and mentors for the next generation of female engineers. We spotlight 10 women engineers who are transforming the fields of bioengineering, energy, robotics, and manufacturing and paving the way for other women to follow. Smart Pacifier to Monitor Baby's Health It's hard to continuously monitor babies' health or regularly prick them with needles to test for glucose levels. Now, as a first step to develop a wearable medical device appropriate for infants, researchers from Spain's University of AlcalÃ¡ and the University of California, San Diego, are testing a pacifier biosensor that can measure blood sugar with every suck. subject: 3D-Printed Organs Becoming Reality
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Quiz on the History of Self-Driving Cars 03.05.2020 Podcast: Building Energy Resiliency in the Caribbean The Caribbean island of Bonaire is an idyllic vacation spot, but its power generation and grid system was unreliable. When ContourGlobal bought the energy assets it knew the system had to be reworked. The result was a 24-MW system using wind and solar, along with backup diesel generators, coupled with a lithium-ion battery storage system and a digital management system that ties it together. 3D-Printed Organs Nearing Clinical Trials Thanks to 3D bioprinting and electrospinning, Wake Forest Institute for Regenerative Medicine bioengineers are moving artificial skin and blood vessels closer to clinical testing. They are also making progress on such 3D-printed organs as hearts, livers, and kidneys. Energy Blog: Our Energy and Climate Policies are Counterproductive When it comes to energy and transportation, the biggest policy failures have to do with climate pollution. Our current policies have us locked into outcomes that run counter to what most people want. QUIZ: What Do You Know About Autonomous Vehicles? The first driverless car debuted in 1939 at the General Motors exhibit at the New York World's Fair. Created by famed industrial designer Norman Bel Geddes, the car was not fully autonomous. Why not? It was driven by an operator using remote radio control. It had a hidden driver in the trunk. It could only follow magnetic spikes embedded in the track. Its computer was too small for independent decision making. L&D COURSES Spring 2020 ASME Learning & Development Programs Sign-up for our Spring L&D courses to learn more about piping, gas turbines, nuclear energy, welding, and more. Bolted Joint Course Package: Bolted Joint Design and Assembly Principles This course combines the bolting and gasket design, bolted flange joint design, and bolted joint assembly principles. WEBINARS Simulations in Medical Device Design April 16 | 2pm ET Learn how multiphysics simulation can help engineers to overcome challenges in designing medical devices. Submit an Abstract â†’ Abstract Submission Deadline: March 16, 2020 The International Mechanical Engineering Congress and ExpositionÂ® (IMECEÂ®) is the perfect venue for mechanical engineers to present their latest research to their peers in the mechanical engineering field. subject: A Day in the Life of an Engineer at Lockheed Martin
body: Building the Confidence needed to become a successful Engineer Free Webinar for ASME Members only A Day in the Life of an Engineer working at Lockheed Martin ASME is bringing you new â€œA Day in the Lifeâ€ webinars, continuing the successful series. Ever wondered what itâ€™s like to work as a mechanical engineer for the worldâ€™s top Aeronautics Company? Come join us for this exclusive webinar with Jose M. Rodriguez, a Senior Mechanical Engineer at Lockheed Martin. All webinars will be recorded and will be available online. Webinar: A Day in the Life of an ME working at Lockheed Martin Date: Date: Tuesday, March 31st, 2020 Time: 1:00 PM EST Register for the Webinar! â†’ Jose will share his experience and insights being a Mechanical Engineer in the Aeronautics industry. Jose is a Senior Staff Mechanical Engineer for Lockheed Martin Aeronautics Co., supporting the design and development of several air vehicle projects within Skunk WorksÂ® and other company lines of business. His primary field is Air-Breathing Propulsion Engineering to include Engine Performance Analysis, Technology Development, Propulsion System Selection and Integration. His 12-year career as a Propulsion Engineer includes work on various types of manned and unmanned aircraft and propulsion systems within Lockheed Martin Co., Gulfstream Aerospace Corp., General Electric, Naval Air Systems Command, and General Atomics. Prior to his career in engineering, Jose was an aircraft technician and holds an FAA Airframe and Powerplant Certification. Jose also served as an enlisted member of the U.S. Navy for 9 years and holds a B.S. and M.S. degrees in Aeronautical Science and Aerospace Engineering from California State Polytechnic University, Pomona and Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University. Jose is currently pursuing his Ph.D. at The University of Texas at San Antonio with dissertation work planned in the field of Shock-Wave Boundary Layer Interaction in Hypersonic Flow. You will have the unique opportunity to ask Jose questions about his role as a mechanical engineer, the company he works for and learn tips and get advice how to be successful in a mechanical engineering role at Lockheed Martin. Please register today and prepare your questions to learn what a Day in the Life of a Mechanical Engineer working at Lockheed Martin is really like! subject: ASME Participates in Smithsonian STEM Day
body: ASME News March 6, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 5 / March 6, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 5 / March 6, 2020 ASME Participates in Smithsonian STEM Day Engineering students from the University of the District of Columbia led ASMEâ€™s participation at the second annual Smithsonian/National Museum of African American History and Culture (NMAAHC) STEM Day, held recently in Washington, D.C. Read more Sponsored Ad Register for the PE Mechanical Exam TODAY Registration is now open for the new computer-based PE Mechanical exam. The first testing appointments are available starting April 2020. Register for the new PE Mechanical exam by logging in to your MyNCEES account and following the onscreen instructions. Learn more â†’ Reminder: Time is Running Out to Submit an Abstract for IMECE The clock is winding down for authors who would like to give a full paper presentation at the ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition (IMECE) this November. Researchers who would like to present their work at IMECE 2020 only have until March 16 to submit an abstract. Read more Sponsored Ad Journal Seeks Papers for Special Issue on Non-Probabilistic and Hybrid Approaches The ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems, Part B: Mechanical Engineering is now accepting papers for a special June 2021 issue focusing on non-probabilistic and hybrid approaches for uncertainty quantification and reliability analysis. Read more Sponsored Ad Nominations Due Soon for New Early Career Leadership Award The Committee on Honors reminds members that nominations for ASMEâ€™s newest award, the Lakshmi Singh Early Career Leadership Award, are due April 1. Read more Sponsored Ad Turbo Expo Hotel Deadline Approaching The deadline to reserve a hotel room for the upcoming ASME Turbomachinery Technical Conference & Exposition (Turbo Expo 2020) â€” the Societyâ€™s premier turbomachinery technical event â€” is only days away. Read more Sponsored Ad Register for Spring 2020 ASME Learning & Development Courses This spring, ASME Learning & Development will be offering courses in Santa Fe, N.M.; Houston, Texas; Nashville, Tenn.; Portland, Ore.; Baltimore, Md.; Las Vegas, Nev.; and Annapolis, Md. â€” as well as Amsterdam, Netherlands, and Barcelona, Spain. Learn more Douglas Bohl ASME member Douglas Bohl, Ph.D., associate professor of mechanical and aeronautical engineering at Clarkson University, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. Dr. Bohl has contributed to the engineering profession through his research, teaching and service, and his work on the development and application of novel diagnostic techniques to advance the understanding of fluid dynamics, according to his Fellow citation. Learn more â†’ Pingsha Dong ASME member Pingsha Dong, Ph.D., professor of naval architecture and marine engineering at the University of Michigan, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in honor of his work in predicting fatigue life. ASME elected Dr. Dong to this prestigious grade of membership for his invention of a breakthrough fatigue life prediction method for welded structures, according to his Fellow citation. Read more Sponsored Ad Journal Seeks Papers for Special Issue on Non-Probabilistic and Hybrid Approaches The ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems, Part B: Mechanical Engineering is now accepting papers for a special June 2021 issue focusing on non-probabilistic and hybrid approaches for uncertainty quantification and reliability analysis. Read more Sponsored Ad Nominations Due Soon for New Early Career Leadership Award The Committee on Honors reminds members that nominations for ASMEâ€™s newest award, the Lakshmi Singh Early Career Leadership Award, are due April 1. Read more Sponsored Ad Turbo Expo Hotel Deadline Approaching The deadline to reserve a hotel room for the upcoming ASME Turbomachinery Technical Conference & Exposition (Turbo Expo 2020) â€” the Societyâ€™s premier turbomachinery technical event â€” is only days away. Read more Sponsored Ad Register for Spring 2020 ASME Learning & Development Courses This spring, ASME Learning & Development will be offering courses in Santa Fe, N.M.; Houston, Texas; Nashville, Tenn.; Portland, Ore.; Baltimore, Md.; Las Vegas, Nev.; and Annapolis, Md. â€” as well as Amsterdam, Netherlands, and Barcelona, Spain. Learn more Douglas Bohl ASME member Douglas Bohl, Ph.D., associate professor of mechanical and aeronautical engineering at Clarkson University, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. Dr. Bohl has contributed to the engineering profession through his research, teaching and service, and his work on the development and application of novel diagnostic techniques to advance the understanding of fluid dynamics, according to his Fellow citation. Learn more â†’ Pingsha Dong ASME member Pingsha Dong, Ph.D., professor of naval architecture and marine engineering at the University of Michigan, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in honor of his work in predicting fatigue life. ASME elected Dr. Dong to this prestigious grade of membership for his invention of a breakthrough fatigue life prediction method for welded structures, according to his Fellow citation. subject: An Indestructible Soft Robotic Bug
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Understanding the Basics of Quantum Computers 03.10.2020 The Basics of a Quantum Computer Quantum computing is heralded as the future of computing. In theory, quantum computers can solve problems that can't be solved or would take a supercomputer months or years to solve. However, their development is still in the early stages. As these computers evolve, engineers need to understand how the technology works and what is their role in the quantum future. Sponsored Ad The Very Tiny 3D-Printed Michelangelo's David An additive micromanufacturing system from Exaddon proved its viability by producing copper replicas of Michelangelo's David, one at a millimeter high and another 0.1-millimeter tall. This technology uses an electrochemical process to deposit drops of a metal solution to build up structures layer-by-layer in precise detail, and it's primarily targeted for microelectronics. One Indestructible Bug In a Soft Robotic Body Whether real or robotic, bugs are fragile: A well-aimed fly swatter can mean instant death to either. Now, EPFL engineers have developed a soft robot equipped with dielectric elastomer actuators. The DEAnsect can stand up to repeated swatting and will continue moving forward propelled by electric vibrations. QUIZ: What Do You Know About the First Typewriter? Christopher Latham Sholes, the co-inventor of the typewriter, was a Wisconsin newspaper publisher and state legislator. Sholes is credited with passing what legal reform in 1853? Extending women the right to vote Eliminating the death penalty Establishing a 40-hour work week Legalizing beer brewing in Milwaukee L&D COURSES Spring 2020 ASME eLearning Programs Sign-up for our Spring online eLearning programs for new courses on boilers & pressure vessels, fluids & heat transfer, welding, GD&T, nuclear energy, and project management. Boiler Pressure Vessel Code for Design and Fabrication Learn the rules on pressure vessel design and construction primarily for beginners and for those looking to update their knowledgeâ€”based on the Section VIII, Division 1 requirements. WHITE PAPERS Selecting the Right 3D Printing Material Explore the properties of thermoplastic and metal materials available for direct metal laser sintering, selective laser sintering and stereolithography technologies. subject: Veteran Hospitals to Receive 3D-Printing Treatment
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Gallium Nitride to Improve Efficiency in Power Transistors 03.12.2020 Advances in Prosthetics Create Realistic Motion and Touch The latest advances in prosthetic limbs include smart artificial skin and improved neural connections. For instance, researchers have wired electrodes directly to nerves within the arm, allowing the brain to create natural movements and sensations with the hand. Engineers are also developing electronic skins that are up to 1,000 times faster than the human sensory nervous system, enabling improved sensory detection and motion for prosthetic devices. Sponsored Ad VA System Rolls Out 3D Printing The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, the nation's largest integrated health care system, is currently exploring ways in which 3D printing can solve a wide range of problems, from visualizing organs before surgery to personalized medicine and improved prostheses. Dr. Beth Ripley is leading the project and she explains how VA is planning to roll out 3D printing throughout the system. Sponsored Content How Gallium Nitride Enables Smaller, More Efficient Power Supplies One of the most common transistors in switching power supplies is a metalâ€“oxideâ€“semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET). While popular, MOSFETs experience losses in the silicon when operating at high switching frequencies. Power designers have begun to turn to Gallium Nitride, a wide band-gap semiconductor material, which like silicon, can be used to make semiconductor devices such as diodes and transistors. ASME Classic Trial By Ice: Ocean Robot Explores the Arctic Seas In the summer of 2014 Chris Judge, an engineering assistant with the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts, was holding a videogame controller aboard the German icebreaker RV Polarstern in the Arctic Ocean. The joint American-German research team selected him, due videogaming prowess, to pilot a newly built sea robot on a unique mission. Nereid Under Ice was designed specifically for exploring the underside of Arctic sea ice, an area so far off-limits to scientists. L&D COURSES Spring 2020 ASME Learning & Development Programs Sign-up for our Spring L&D courses to learn more about piping, gas turbines, nuclear energy, welding, and more. Boiler Pressure Vessel Code for Design and Fabrication Learn the rules on pressure vessel design and construction. The course is aimed for beginners and for those looking to update their knowledgeâ€”based on the Section VIII, Division 1 requirements. WEBINARS Simulations in Medical Device Design April 16 | 2pm ET Learn how multiphysics simulation can help engineers to overcome challenges in designing medical devices. Intro to Desktop 3D Printing: Compare FDM, DLP, SLS, and SLA Technology April 21 | 2pm ET Gain the foundation you need to start speaking the language of 3D printing. subject: Spread the Word about ASME's Free Freshman/First Year Student Membership
body: ASME Membership Freshman/First Year Students Can Join ASME for Free Connect with us: Spread the Word! ASME Student Membership is Free for Freshman/First Year Students You are already enjoying your FREE ASME Student Membership Isn't it time you let your friends in on the secret? Thank you for joining ASME as a student member and taking advantage of our Freshman/First Year Free option! Now we need your help to be sure every other eligible student knows about this great opportunity! As a student member you are the perfect ambassador to communicate the value of ASME to your Freshman/First Year friends who have yet to join. Simply point them to our quick and easy online form and they can become a student member for absolutely no-cost in just minutes! http://go.asme.org/students or http://go.asme.org/join In addition to telling your peers about this opportunity in person, you can also share ASME's Freshman/First Year Free Student Membership offer on Facebook, LinkedIn, Google+ and Twitter - or by forwarding this email or posting the offer on your university intranet - or however you wish! ASME is committed to helping mechanical engineering students reach their full potential - and with the help of students like you - we can continue to grow our global community of professional engineers and students who are working together to address the world's concerns in meaningful ways. Please help us spread the word about ASME Freshman/First Year Free Student Membership â€” your friends will thank you for it. http://go.asme.org/students or http://go.asme.org/join Unbeatable Benefits! Like regular ASME student membership, Freshman/First Year Free Membership includes unlimited use of AccessEngineering, ASME's world-class online reference tool with over 775 engineering titles including the essential Marks' Standard Handbook for Mechanical Engineers; Perry's Chemical Engineers' Handbook; Standard Handbook for Civil Engineers; Standard Handbook for Electrical Engineers, just to name a few! subject: The Future of Synthetic Lab-Grown Meat
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Cobot Safety and Proper Risk Assessment 03.17.2020 Infographic: Cobots, Safety, and Risk Assessment Collaborative robots are built with safety in mind. Their built-in safety features have opened the door for more collaboration between humans and robots. However, no cobot arm is inherently safe. Universal Robots' Joe Campbell highlights how a proper risk assessment and a cobot's safety features can create a safe work environment. Sponsored Ad Lab-Grown Meat: A Big Step Forward Researchers are using tissue engineering to grow meat in the lab. The synthetic meat, grown on a scaffold made by a process similar to 3D printing, already has the texture of natural meat. Led by Harvard's Kit Parker, the team needs to perfect their ability to grow fat cells before their synthetic steaks are ready for the grill. Manufacturing Blog: Should You Design for Additive Manufacturing? Should engineers embrace design for additive manufacturing (DfAM), a collection of best practices to make better, more cost-effective 3D-printed parts? The answer is not obvious, says industry veteran Todd Grimm. QUIZ: Who Are These Five Influential Women Engineers? The first female CEO and the first woman to lead any major automaker. Who is she? Ginny Rometty Indira Nooyi Ursula Burns Mary Barra L&D COURSES Practical Piping Design ASME's Practical Piping Design provides you with a thorough knowledge of the industry process piping standard, ASME's B31.3 code, and how to apply it. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals An eLearning course focusing on the different stages of production and manufacturing. WHITE PAPERS Selecting the Right 3D Printing Material Explore the properties of thermoplastic and metal materials available for direct metal laser sintering, selective laser sintering and stereolithography technologies. subject: ASME Journal of Medical Devices - Call for Papers: Special Issue on Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces
body: ASME Journal of Mechanical Design CALL FOR PAPERS Connect with us: ASME's Guide for Journal Authors Submit Your Manuscript â†’ CALL FOR PAPERS ASME Journal of Medical Devices Special Issue on Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces Significant advances have been made in the field of medical robotics in recent decades. Spanning series and parallel robotic architectures, rigid and soft materials, and a variety of control approaches, the potential for robotic applications in medicine remains vast. As the technologies underlying robotic solutions continue to mature and develop, new robotic medical applications will continue to emerge. A related area of growing interest is the interaction between human operators and robotic medical devices. Without appropriate and user-friendly interfaces, the uses of these technologies are limited. Haptic devices are an example of the profound effect that interface devices can have on practical functionality and applicability of technology in medical applications. The focus of this Special Issue is the intersection of medical robotics and human interfaces for medical applications. Topic Areas â€¢ Kinematics & dynamics for medical robotics â€¢ Exoskeletons & prostheses â€¢ Humanoid & service robots â€¢ Assistive robots & elderly assistance â€¢ Surgical robots â€¢ Human-robot interfaces â€¢ Haptic devices â€¢ Medical treatments using robotics & automation Publication Target Dates Paper submission deadline: June 15, 2020 Initial reviews completed: July 15, 2020 Special Issue publication date: December 2020 Submission Instructions Papers should be submitted electronically to the journal at journaltool.asme.org. If you already have an account, log in as author and select Submit Paper at the bottom of the page. If you do not have an account, select Submissions and follow the steps. In either case, at the Paper Submittal page, select the ASME Journal of Medical Devices and then select the Special Issue Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces. Papers received after the deadline or papers not selected for inclusion in the Special Issue may be accepted for publication in a regular issue. Text: ASME Journal of Medical Devices - Call for Papers: Special Issue on Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces ASME Journal of Mechanical Design CALL FOR PAPERS Connect with us: ASME's Guide for Journal Authors Submit Your Manuscript â†’ CALL FOR PAPERS ASME Journal of Medical Devices Special Issue on Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces Significant advances have been made in the field of medical robotics in recent decades. Spanning series and parallel robotic architectures, rigid and soft materials, and a variety of control approaches, the potential for robotic applications in medicine remains vast. As the technologies underlying robotic solutions continue to mature and develop, new robotic medical applications will continue to emerge. A related area of growing interest is the interaction between human operators and robotic medical devices. Without appropriate and user-friendly interfaces, the uses of these technologies are limited. Haptic devices are an example of the profound effect that interface devices can have on practical functionality and applicability of technology in medical applications. The focus of this Special Issue is the intersection of medical robotics and human interfaces for medical applications. Topic Areas â€¢ Kinematics & dynamics for medical robotics â€¢ Exoskeletons & prostheses â€¢ Humanoid & service robots â€¢ Assistive robots & elderly assistance â€¢ Surgical robots â€¢ Human-robot interfaces â€¢ Haptic devices â€¢ Medical treatments using robotics & automation Publication Target Dates Paper submission deadline: June 15, 2020 Initial reviews completed: July 15, 2020 Special Issue publication date: December 2020 Submission Instructions Papers should be submitted electronically to the journal at journaltool.asme.org. If you already have an account, log in as author and select Submit Paper at the bottom of the page. If you do not have an account, select Submissions and follow the steps. In either case, at the Paper Submittal page, select the ASME Journal of Medical Devices and then select the Special Issue Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces. Papers received after the deadline or papers not selected for inclusion in the Special Issue may be accepted for publication in a regular issue. Special Issue Guest Editors Med Amine Laribi, PhD, Associate Professor, Institut PPRIME, DÃ©partement GÃ©nie MÃ©canique et SystÃ¨mes Complexes, CNRS, University of Poitiers, Poitiers, France med.amine.laribi@univ-poitiers.fr Carl Nelson, PhD, Professor, Mechanical and Materials Engineering, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE, USA cnelson5@unl.edu Nandini Duraiswamy, PhD, Biomedical Engineer, US Food and Drug Administration, Silver Spring, MD, USA Nandini.Duraiswamy@fda.hhs.gov The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® (ASMEÂ®) 031920 - 19928 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Coronavirus and Its Impact on Supply Chains
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter SURVEY: Tell Us How Coronavirus is Impacting You 03.24.2020 Bioengineering Blog: Supply Chains and the Coronavirus Health Crisis Medical device companies have felt the consequences of supply chain disruptions as the demand for products has unsurprisingly risen with the pandemic gaining steam. Meanwhile, health officials continue to grapple with confining the virus and researching a vaccine. Both intertwined issues are everyone's problem. Sponsored Ad Sponsored Content The Latest Automation Innovations from ATX West ATX West is one of the largest trade shows in the United States. Mechanical Engineering speaks with experts from Universal Robots, Bosch Rexroth, Productive Robotics, and OnRobot about their new tech devices and the trends engineers can expect in 2020. 5 Questions with IBM's Lisa Seacat DeLuca Lisa Seacat DeLuca is a Distinguished Engineer and director of the Watson Internet of Things division since 2017. In 2016, Lisa was named one of the Most Influential Women in IoT, and in 2015, she was named one of MIT's 35 Innovators Under 35 and one of Fast Company's 100 Most Creative People in Business. ASME sat down with DeLuca to discuss her patent process, her inspirations, and her thoughts on STEM and diversity. SURVEY: How the Coronavirus is Impacting Engineers?â€”Let Us Know COVID-19 is having a devastating impact on the economy. A majority of the workforce has been working from homeâ€”many individuals for the first time in their lives. We want to know how you are being impacted by the coronavirus. Has the transition been difficult? What tools are you using to adjust working at home? Take our quick survey and let us know. First, what is your main job focus? Design Engineer Assembly Engineer Maintenance Engineer Management Engineer Supervisor Engineer Academic professor or professional Student Self-Employed L&D COURSES Practical Piping Design ASME's Practical Piping Design provides you with a thorough knowledge of the industry process piping standard, ASME's B31.3 code, and how to apply it. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals An eLearning course focusing on the different stages of production and manufacturing. WHITE PAPERS Selecting the Right 3D Printing Material Explore the properties of thermoplastic and metal materials available for direct metal laser sintering, selective laser sintering and stereolithography technologies. subject: The IMECE 2020 Abstract Deadline Extended to March 30th
body: ASME 2019 IMECE: Call for Papers Submit your IMECE 2020 paper abstract by March 30, 2020 Connect with us: You still have time to submit an IMECE 2020Â® abstract! Submit an Abstract â†’ The IMECE 2020 Abstract Submission Deadline: March 30, 2020 Are you working on mechanical engineering-related research and want to share the results with your peers? Then consider presenting your work at the International Mechanical Engineering Congress & ExpositionÂ® (IMECEÂ®) from November 15 â€“ 19, in Portland, OR. A previous IMECE presenter said that their favorite part of IMECE was â€œthe chance to present and receive feedback and excellent recommendations.â€ The IMECE 2020 abstract submission deadline has changed to March 30th. IMECE 2020 offers 17 different track topics ranging from Acoustics, Vibration, and Phonics, Biomedical and Biotechnology to Mechanics of Solids, Structures and Fluids. subject: Coronavirus Vaccine Begins Human Trials
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Medical Markets Embrace Metal 3D Printing 03.26.2020 Hands-Off Medical Imaging The ultrasound is an incredible tool for peering beneath the skin's surface. But not if you're a burn victimâ€”the contact is too painful. Now there's a laser ultrasound that captures its images from afar, offering a pressureâ€“free look inside the body. Sponsored Ad Video: US Begins First Human Trial of Coronavirus Vaccine Bioengineers are racing to evaluate a candidate vaccine against the new coronavirus, starting a phase one trial to monitor its safety and effectiveness. It may take up to 18 months before the vaccine is ready for public use. Infographic: Medical Markets Embrace Metals Additive Manufacturing Systems There are 19 metals additive manufacturing systems commercially available or in development. The global metal AM market is valued at EUR 1.51 billion, and the medical & dental segment commands a strong place within it. Metal 3D Printing for Orthopedics Advances in 3D printing technology, software, and materials are making it possible to mass-produce orthopedic devices, implants, and instruments from metals and metal alloys, such as titanium, cobalt-chrome, and stainless steel. Depending on the product design and metals selected, 3D printing of orthopedic products promises a faster and less expensive process than traditional subtractive machining methods. L&D COURSES Practical Piping Design By completing the Practical Piping Design eLearning path, you will learn how to read and interpret the B31.3 code, safely design piping, and think critically through problems to make complex piping design decisions without the use of the software. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals This eLearning course focuses on all stages of production and manufacturing, including design, post-processing, and business considerations. WEBINARS Simulations in Medical Device Design April 16 | 2pm ET Learn how multiphysics simulation can help engineers to overcome challenges in designing medical devices. Intro to Desktop 3D Printing: Compare FDM, DLP, SLS, and SLA Technology April 21 | 2pm ET Gain the foundation you need to start speaking the language of 3D printing. subject: Introducing E-Fest Digital 2020
body: ASME E-Fests A virtual E-Fest event for engineering students worldwide Innovate. Create. Compete. Celebrate. ASME E-FESTSÂ® NEWS Whatâ€™s Trending in the Engineering Student Community Announcing E-Fest Digital 2020 Register Now â†’ As the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) remains a global issue, ASME has made the decision to cancel E-Fest North on April 3-5, 2020 and E-Fest South on April 24-26, 2020, to ensure the safety of our attendees and staff. While we are deeply disappointed that we will not be holding these events in-person, we understand the hard work and time spent in preparation, so we have decided to pivot to an online version: E-Fest Digital 2020! What is E-Fest Digital? Itâ€™s a half-day global engineering experience for students to showcase their technical innovations in areas such as design, additive manufacturing and robotics, interact with industry engineers and mentors, and develop their leadership and professional skills. When and where is E-Fest Digital taking place? It will be held April 25, 2020 and will be entirely virtual, on our ASME E-FestsÂ® YouTube channel. In the meantime, subscribe to our YouTube channel and check out our content! How much does it cost to attend? Itâ€™s free! We want to ensure you continue to learn which means, engineering students from anywhere in the world can register for free and have access to all the presentations, sessions, competitions, Q&As and more! Who should attend? Engineering students of all disciplines from all over the world! We especially encourage students that were planning to attend E-Fest North or E-Fest South to register! Will there be competitions? Yes! Most, if not all of the traditional ASME E-FestsÂ® competitions will be part of the main event and challenge students to highlight their engineering skills via video submission. And there will be prizes! Follow us on social for the latest updates. Follow us @efestsasme on Instagram, Twitter and Facebook for the most up-to-date info! Register Now â†’ Sponsored Ad 500+ Papers and Presentations Explore how your peers are making advances in new product development and research through multiphysics simulation in this open-access resource with over 500 papers, posters, and presentations from COMSOL Conference 2019. Download Now â†’ Have questions? We're here to help! Contact Us You have received this email because you previously registered for an E-Fest event that was cancelled due to COVID-19. This is a one-time notification of change in format. If youâ€™d like to continue to receive E-Fests updates, please make sure your communication preferences are up to date by visiting the ASME Preference Center and checking Conference & Events under the Products & Services category. The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ASMEÂ® 032620 - 17343 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Battling the Coronavirus with Artificial Intelligence
body: ASME TechWorkforce - ME Magazine Newsletter ASME Today & Tomorrow: Paving the Way Forward 03.27.2020 OSHA Guidelines for Working During the Coronavirus Pandemic During the coronavirus pandemic, while most people are being asked to work from home, some factory workers and engineers continue to head into work to keep manufacturing plants open. To help these companies maintain safe working conditions, the Occupational Health & Safety Administration released guidelines defining levels of exposure to Covid-19 and how to prepare workplaces to keep employees safe. Sponsored Ad ASME Today & Tomorrow: Paving the Way Forward ASME CEO Tom Costabile sits down with five distinguished women who have served in the organization's highest office as ASME President. They share their perspectives on the Society's past, present, and its future. Bioengineering Blog: AI and Deep Learning Save Research Time During a Pandemic Within the news cycles of the developing coronavirus pandemic, there has been a focus on time it takes to develop new vaccines and critical medical equipment. AI, deep learning, and other technologies are now being harnessed to find solutions to the challenges presented by the pandemic. Sponsored Ad Sponsored Content How Gallium Nitride Enables Smaller, More Efficient Power Supplies One of the most common transistors in switching power supplies is a metalâ€“oxideâ€“semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET). While popular, MOSFETs experience losses in the silicon when operating at high switching frequencies. Power designers have begun to turn to Gallium Nitride, a wide band-gap semiconductor material, which, like silicon, can be used to make semiconductor devices such as diodes and transistors. L&D COURSES Practical Piping Design By completing the Practical Piping Design eLearning path, you will learn how to read and interpret the B31.3 code, safely design piping, and think critically through problems to make complex piping design decisions without the use of the software. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals This eLearning course focuses on all stages of production and manufacturing, including design, post-processing, and business considerations. WEBINARS Simulations in Medical Device Design April 16 | 2pm ET Learn how multiphysics simulation can help engineers to overcome challenges in designing medical devices. Intro to Desktop 3D Printing: Compare FDM, DLP, SLS, and SLA Technology April 21 | 2pm ET Gain the foundation you need to start speaking the language of 3D printing. subject: NEW JOURNAL: CALL FOR PAPERS - ASME Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems
body: ASME Journal of Mechanical Design: Special Issue Call-for-Papers: 'Data-Driven Design (D3)' Editor - Vladimir Vantsevich Connect with us: ASME's Guide for Journal Authors Submit Your Manuscript â†’ ASME Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems CALL FOR PAPERS NEW JOURNAL IN 2021! (First articles online in 2020) The purpose of Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems is to provide an international platform for the communication and discussion of technical knowledge and solutions in the transformative areas of the research and engineering design of autonomous vehicles and systems that operate in all media and inter-medium environments: ground, air, space, and water. The focus of this journal is on an autonomous vehicle system-of-systems approach to modeling, simulation, design, and physical and virtual testing. The vehicle applications include, but are not limited to, personal and cargo transportation, construction and forestry, farming, scientific research, investigation of the underground, air and water, exploration of other planets, infrastructure monitoring, surveillance, military, and beyond. Topic areas include, but are not limited to: autonomous vehicle and multi-domain system dynamics in interaction with multi-physics environment in different media; transdisciplinary-inspired design concepts for safe and secure performance, energy efficiency, and survivability of autonomous vehicles and systems; intelligent morphing and dynamics of autonomous vehicles and systems; intelligent exteroceptive and proprioceptive sensing, actuation, decision-making and controls for agile dynamics and mission/task fulfillment; localization problems, landscape, air and aquatic environment sampling; fault-tolerance in severe, uncertain, and adversarial environments; human-in-the-loop and autonomous intelligent decision making related to dynamics and mission/task learning and fulfillment; integration of autonomous vehicles into the manned and unmanned traffic of their respective media; artificial intelligence and social behavior factors and challenges for communication, decision making, and dynamic interaction between (i) autonomous vehicle systems, (ii) autonomous vehicles, and (iii) autonomous vehicles and infrastructure in a particular medium and inter-medium environments; integration of modeling and simulation with gaming technologies for autonomous vehicle design and training purposes; and transformative conceptual and engineering design for life cycle management of autonomous vehicles and autonomous systems. Scope â€¢ Artificial intelligence â€¢ Intelligent decision making, controls, and observation â€¢ System models â€¢ Modeling, simulation, and designing autonomous vehicle systems for their autonomy â€¢ Payload models â€¢ Proprioceptive sensors in autonomous vehicle systems and exteroceptive sensors for autonomous vehicle and environment interactions â€¢ Outdoor and cyber-physical indoor proving grounds and research facilities â€¢ Inputs/outputs and environmental models in autonomous vehicle simulation and design â€¢ Gaming environments Submission Guidelines All submissions should be prepared in accordance with the ASME Author Guidelines and be submitted through the ASME Journals Connect webpage (journaltool.asme.org). Select Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems. The Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems will debut its Inaugural Issue at the 2020 International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition (IMECE 2020). To be reviewed for inclusion in this Inaugural Issue, papers should be submitted by June 1, 2020. Editor Vladimir Vantsevich, ScD, PhD, ASME Fellow Professor and Director, Vehicle and Robotics Engineering Laboratory School of Engineering / Mechanical Engineering The University of Alabama at Birmingham Mailing Address: 1720 2nd Avenue South / BEC 356D Birmingham, AL 35294-4461, USA Tel: +1 205.975.5855 Email: vantsevi@uab.edu The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® (ASMEÂ®) 032720 - 19992 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com.
