subject: Drive solutions for zero hunger & clean water during COVID-19
body: Apply for the E4C & Siemens Virtual Design Challenge by engineers, for everyone | www.engineeringforchange.org Engineer a Better World Apply for the Innovate for Impact: Siemens Virtual Design Challenge Driving solutions for zero hunger & clean water Application Deadline Extended: May 4, 2020 Apply Now â†’ As the Coronavirus (COVID-19) remains a global issue, it is forcing all of us to change the way we work, interact socially, and think about our sphere of influence. At E4C we are deeply committed to confronting the new challenges we face with the tools and resources to inspire action locally and globally. Take this opportunity to make an impact on the world by applying for the Innovate for Impact Siemens Virtual Design Challenge to help achieve two of the United Nationâ€™s Sustainable Development Goals by 2030: Zero Hunger (SDG 2) and Clean Water (SDG 6). Because many of you are still adapting to new schedules and staying at home, weâ€™ve extended the application deadline to May 4 in order to give you additional time to apply. Apply human-centered design to engineer innovative hardware solutions that help achieve the United Nationâ€™s Sustainable Development Goals by 2030: Zero Hunger (SDG 2) Design a postharvest off-grid preservation technology to reduce the farm-to-table food loss in lower resource settings that lack electricity. Clean Water (SDG 6) Design a low-cost, energy-efficient, scalable technology for desalinating brackish water. LEARN MORE Why Apply? This challenge unites the entrepreneurial spirit of engineering communities focused on changing the world, and the resources of a top-10 global software company with a 170-year history of service. Through this design challenge, Siemens USA and Engineering for Change are providing engineers with platforms to expand whatâ€™s humanly possible, creating new spaces to dream, innovate and develop technology to drive the Sustainable Development Goals. $10,000 Awarded to Winner of Each Track One winner or winning team will be selected from each challenge track. Each winner will receive (USD) $10,000, for a total of $20,000 in prizes. Winners will also meet with Barbara Humpton, CEO of Siemens USA. Winning designs will be promoted through Siemens USA's and Engineering for Change's platforms, and they will receive exclusive invitations to industry events. Application Deadline Extended: May 4, 2020 APPLY NOW Interested in promoting an opportunity or becoming a sponsor? Learn more here or contact us at partners@engineeringforchange.org. Stay Connected Engineering for Change | 2 Park Ave. | New York | NY | 10016 ENGINEERING FOR CHANGE is a knowledge organization dedicated to preparing the global workforce to deliver solutions that improve the quality of life of underserved communities. Our community believes that engineering can change the world. Join us! subject: How Ford is Making Respirators for Covid-19
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Engineers To The Rescue Against Coronavirus 03.31.2020 Coronavirus Update: Engineers to the Rescue Over the past weeks, engineers have been racing to prevent the coronavirus outbreak from growing even more deadly. They are revamping factories to make ventilator parts, designing and 3D printing critical medical supplies, setting up virtual hackathons and open-source groups to develop ventilators and face shields, and boosting production of N95 respirators. 10 Humanoid Robots of 2020 Humanoid robots are staffing a hospital in Wuhan, China, helping medics to disinfect, measure temperatures, deliver food and medicine, and entertain medical staff and COVID-19 patients. Here's a list of ten other humanoids that collaborate with humans in factories, warehouses, theaters, schools, space, and at home. Video: How Ford is Making Respirators for Covid-19 To address the shortages of surgical respirators in the fight against coronavirus, Ford is working with 3M to produce a new kind of Powered Air-Purifying Respirator, while also helping to increase production of 3M's current respirator device. Quiz: How Much Do You Know about The Falkirk Wheel? Scotland's Falkirk Wheel is an engineering marvel, the world's first and only rotating boat lift. It reconnects two canalsâ€”the Edinburgh & Glasgow Union Canal and the Forth & Clyde Canal. Two giant rotating arms are fitted with water-filled caissons to lift the boats from one canal to the other. See what you know about this landmark project in this quiz. What is the difference in height between the two canals? 15 meters 35 meters 40 meters 52 meters L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April, so be sure to check out our discounted course list. Learn Piping Design On Your Own Time Reliance on software without a fundamental understanding of the underlying principles of engineering has become a common industry issue. Learn how to avoid costly mistakes with this new learning path consisting of four eLearning courses. WHITE PAPERS Selecting the Right 3D Printing Material Explore the properties of thermoplastic and metal materials available for direct metal laser sintering, selective laser sintering and stereolithography technologies. subject: Submit Your IMECE 2020 Presentation Only Abstract Today
body: ASME 2019 IMECE: Call for Papers The IMECE 2020 Presentation Only Abstract Submission Deadline is July 13, 2020 Connect with us: Share your research and present at IMECE 2020Â® Submit an Abstract â†’ Presentation Only Abstract Submission Deadline: July 13, 2020 Did you miss out on submitting a paper abstract for this year's International Mechanical Engineering Congress & ExpositionÂ® (IMECEÂ®)? Don't worry, as you still have an opportunity to showcase your research at IMECE 2020 by submitting a presentation only abstract. IMECE is ASME's largest research and development conference focused primarily on mechanical engineering but encompasses perspectives from many engineering disciplines. View all IMECE 2020 Tracks Presenting at IMECE 2020 is a fantastic way to introduce your research and ideas to the mechanical engineering community. IMECE is also an excellent opportunity to network with your peers. A recent IMECE attendee says that IMECE has great networking opportunities as the number of people who attended was huge." Don't hesitate and submit an IMECE 2020 presentation only abstract today as the deadline is July 13

subject: The Invisible Heroes of the Coronavirus Crisis
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter The Future of 4D Printing 04.02.2020 Please Note: Due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, you may experience a delay with receiving Mechanical Engineering magazine depending on your location. Don't fret! You can always read the digital edition at your convenience. ASME Special TechCast: Ventilation System to Prevent Virus Spread In this special edition of ASME TechCast, Professor Qingyan Chen of Purdue University, who has researched the spread of viruses through ventilation systems in passenger vehicles, discusses the ventilation system his lab is developing that would prevent the airborne transmission of pathogens like coronavirus by allowing each person to breathe in only his or her own air. Sponsored Ad Invisible Heroes of Coronavirus Crisis In modern society, some of the most important people are the hardest to see. In places where the coronavirus pandemic has hit worst, only essential personnel are on duty: Medical professionals, first respondersâ€”and utility workers. Utility workers are invisible because they are doing their jobs well. ASME TechCast: Moving Toward 4D Printing Belgian life sciences firm Antleron builds factory of the future to implement new strategies to produce 4D-printed biomaterials. CEO Jan Schrooten talks with ASME.org about building a process to produce 4D materials for medical applications that differs completely from existing strategies and layouts. Sponsored Content The Latest Automation Innovations from ATX West ATX West is one of the largest trade shows across the United States. Mechanical Engineering speaks with experts from Universal Robots, Bosch Rexroth, Productive Robotics, and OnRobot on their new tech devices and what trends can engineers expect for 2020. L&D COURSES Learn Piping Design On Your Own Time Reliance on software without a fundamental understanding of the underlying principles of engineering has become a common industry issue. Learn how to avoid costly mistakes with this new learning path consisting of four eLearning courses. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Every day, metal additive technologies continue to change the manufacturing landscape. The gap between technology and integration keeps getting wider. That means employers and managers are looking for a well-trained and skilled workforce to integrate this technology into their workplace. With the help of ASME, that will be you. Save over 50% on this new eLearning course. WEBINARS Simulations in Medical Device Design April 16 | 2pm ET Learn how multiphysics simulation can help engineers to overcome challenges in designing medical devices. Intro to Desktop 3D Printing: Compare FDM, DLP, SLS, and SLA Technology April 21 | 2pm ET Gain the foundation you need to start speaking the language of 3D printing. subject: ASME E-Fests Announce Inaugural E-Fest Digital Event on April 25
body: ASME News April 3, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 7 / April 3, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 7 / April 3, 2020 E-Fest Digital 2020 Set for April 25 ASME has organized an exciting new online festival for engineering students, E-Fest Digital, as a substitute for the cancellations of this monthâ€™s E-Fest North and E-Fest South events in Michigan and Georgia because of the continuing COVID-19 crisis. Read more Sponsored Ad Choice Platform Helps You Put the RIGHT Plan in Place The ASME Professional Liability Insurance Program has been enhanced! ASME members now have access to a Choice Platform, which provides members with a choice of coverage options from leading insurers: Lloydâ€™s of London and/or Beazley Insurance Company. Learn more â†’ ASME Statement on COVID-19 Response In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, governments around the world are now instituting or calling for restrictions on travel, gatherings, and in-person meetings in an effort to limit and slow the spread of the virus. ASME supports these efforts and has been responding actively in a variety of ways that are developing in real time. Read more Sponsored Ad Save the Date: ASME Robotics Industry Event Set for Texas This Fall ASME will hold its Robotics for Inspection & Maintenance event again this fall in College Station, Texas. The event, which will have the theme â€œBridging the Gap Between the Expert and Asset,â€ is scheduled to take place Sept. 30-Oct. 1, 2020. Read more Sponsored Ad E-Fest Asia Pacific Draws Record Attendance ASME Engineering Festivalsâ„¢ kicked off 2020 with E-Fest Asia Pacific in Rajkot, India. Approximately 1,600 students, educators and other guests attended the event, which was held Feb. 28-March 1 at Marwadi University. Read more Sponsored Ad Special Journal Issue to Focus on Digital Twin The ASME Journal of Computing and Information Science in Engineering is now accepting manuscripts for a special issue focusing on digital twin driven design and manufacturing. The deadline to submit a paper for the special issue is Aug. 31, 2020. Read more Sponsored Ad Application Deadline Extended for New Siemens/E4C Design Challenge The Innovate for Impact: Siemens Design Challenge, in partnership with Engineering for Change (E4C), is a new competition intended to drive solutions for zero hunger and clean water in support of the United Nationâ€™s Sustainable Development Goals. If you are interested in entering the competition, there is still time to sign up. The application deadline has been extended to May 4. Learn more Learn from Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April, so be sure to check out our discounted course list. Learn more Matthew Campbell ASME member Matthew Campbell, Ph.D., professor of mechanical engineering at Oregon State University, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. According to his citation, Dr. Campbell was recognized for â€œhis pioneering work in the area of computational design synthesis, including the impactful contribution of agent-based design synthesis and theory and implementation of graph grammars,â€ as well as for â€œfundamental contributions to computational manufacturing planning.â€ Learn more â†’ Kenneth Hall ASME Fellow Kenneth C. Hall, D.Sc., the Julian Francis Abele Distinguished Professor in the mechanical engineering and materials science department at Duke University, has been named a member of the National Academy of Engineering (NAE). Dr. Hall was cited for the â€œdevelopment of unsteady aerodynamic and aeromechanics theories and analysis for internal and external aerodynamic flows.â€ Hall is the tenth Duke Engineering faculty member to be elected to the NAE. Learn more â†’ Your Email Preferences Events Calendar ASME Membership ASME Foundation Sections & Divisions Engineering for Change (E4C) Capitol Update Obituaries The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. The deadline to submit a paper for the special issue is Aug. 31, 2020. Read more Sponsored Ad Application Deadline Extended for New Siemens/E4C Design Challenge The Innovate for Impact: Siemens Design Challenge, in partnership with Engineering for Change (E4C), is a new competition intended to drive solutions for zero hunger and clean water in support of the United Nationâ€™s Sustainable Development Goals. If you are interested in entering the competition, there is still time to sign up. The application deadline has been extended to May 4. Learn more Learn from Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April, so be sure to check out our discounted course list. Learn more Matthew Campbell ASME member Matthew Campbell, Ph.D., professor of mechanical engineering at Oregon State University, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. According to his citation, Dr. Campbell was recognized for â€œhis pioneering work in the area of computational design synthesis, including the impactful contribution of agent-based design synthesis and theory and implementation of graph grammars,â€ as well as for â€œfundamental contributions to computational manufacturing planning.â€ Learn more â†’ Kenneth Hall ASME Fellow Kenneth C. Hall, D.Sc., the Julian Francis Abele Distinguished Professor in the mechanical engineering and materials science department at Duke University, has been named a member of the National Academy of Engineering (NAE). Dr. Hall was cited for the â€œdevelopment of unsteady aerodynamic and aeromechanics theories and analysis for internal and external aerodynamic flows.â€ Hall is the tenth Duke Engineering faculty member to be elected to the NAE. subject: Protolabs Shifts Manufacturing to Battle the Coronavirus
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Dyson to Manufacture Ventilators 04.07.2020 Please Note: Due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, you may experience a delay with receiving Mechanical Engineering magazine depending on your location. Don't fret! You can always read the digital edition at your convenience. Video: Dyson to Manufacture Ventilators to Fight COVID-19 Hospitals are strained and low on medical supplies as the surge of patients suffering from coronavirus continues. The U.K.-based vacuum company, Dyson, has designed a bed-mounted ventilator for COVID-19 patients. Biotechnology Anticipates 4D Printing As engineers in the biotechnology industry shift toward 3D printers for commercial bioprinting, many wonder 'what is the next step?' 4D printing, a term that is a bit of a misnomer because it still relies on 3D printers, uses time as the fourth dimension, creating printed materials that change their shape over time. Protolabs Dedicates Manufacturing to Battle the Coronavirus To help fight the coronavirus pandemic, rapid prototype manufacturing company Protolabs has dedicated its production servicesâ€”which include injection molding, 3D printing, CNC machining, and sheet metal fabricationâ€”to produce medical components needed for ventilators, face masks, and COVID-19 test kits. QUIZ: Which are the Best Engineering Animals of the World? The Vogelkop Bowerbird is known for building impressive homes. The bower" is the hut-like structure they build can span many feet in width and height. The front of the entrance is typically adorned with leaves

subject: The Coronavirus Impact on Supply Chains
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Are Floating Structures the Future of Cities? 04.09.2020 Please Note: Due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, you may experience a delay with receiving Mechanical Engineering magazine depending on your location. Don't fret! You can always read the digital edition at your convenience. Supercomputer Designs Drone to Fight Siberian Fires A new machine-learning approach to drone development from scientists at Tomsk State University could help engineers more quickly find an aerodynamic profile and an optimal design than using traditional methods. The supercomputer-designed UAV prototype is geared to search for wildfires in Siberia. Sponsored Ad Modeling the Affect of COVID-19 on Supply Chains Georgia Tech's Pinar Keskinocak is a systems engineering professor who has studied the interconnections of pandemics and systems such as supply chains. She is developing an agent-based model for COVID-19, one of the many roles engineers are playing in the current pandemic. Can Engineers Build Floating Cities to Save Island Nations? As sea level rise threatens cities across the globe, engineers are looking at relocating giant pieces of infrastructure to buoyant buildings, or very large floating structures. What had once seemed like an exercise in extreme engineering now has taken on an edge of desperate necessity. Can the challenges be overcome in time? Sponsored Ad ASME Classic: Why We Have Eyelashes When his daughter was born, fluid dynamicist David Hu was astonished at the length of her eyelashes. The fact that the newborn was otherwise hairless prompted him to question why we have these hairs at the edge of our eyelids to begin with. Hu and his colleagues at Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta found that shorter lashes failed at properly blocking the air and longer ones actually directed more airflow to the eye. L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April. Be sure to check out our discounted course list. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Every day, metal additive technologies continue to change the manufacturing landscape. The gap between technology and integration keeps getting wider. That means employers and managers are looking for a well-trained and skilled workforce to integrate this technology into their workplace. With the help of ASME, that will be you. Save over 50% on this new eLearning course. WEBINARS Simulations in Medical Device Design April 16 | 2pm ET Learn how multiphysics simulation can help engineers to overcome challenges in designing medical devices. Intro to Desktop 3D Printing: Compare FDM, DLP, SLS, and SLA Technology April 21 | 2pm ET Gain the foundation you need to start speaking the language of 3D printing. subject: How Are Engineers Working Through the Coronavirus Pandemic?
body: ASME TechWorkforce - ME Magazine Newsletter Why Are Ventilators So Hard To Engineer? 04.10.2020 Please Note: Due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, you may experience a delay with receiving Mechanical Engineering magazine depending on your location. Don't fret! You can always read the digital edition at your convenience. Making the Most of a Virtual Job Fair During the coronavirus pandemic, job search seems like a near impossible task. But practicing social distancing and looking for a jobâ€”without leaving your homeâ€”is possible, thanks to virtual career fairs. Here are eight steps to make the most of them. Sponsored Ad How Engineers are Working Through the Coronavirus Pandemic Engineers across the country are asked to stay at home and continue to work. It's their efforts that have brought us the technologies we're using in our hospitals today. Their efforts will also be vital in keeping our economy going by maintaining work hours during this crisis. So, how are they fairing, and what are their biggest challenges? Infographic: What Makes Ventilators Hard to Engineer Hospitals around the world are facing shortages of ventilators to treat COVID-19 patients. As manufacturers rise to the challenge, and shift their production lines to manufacture ventilators, here are some of the key challenges engineers face when designing these vital machines. Sponsored Content MTC Develops Simulation App to Revolutionize Design for AM Parts The Manufacturing Technology Centre (MTC) in Coventry, UK, researches additive manufacturing techniques and supplies designs and prototypes to part producers in the industry. To verify the quality and performance of their additively manufactured parts, the MTC employs multiphysics simulation software for virtual design testing, validation, and performance prediction. L&D COURSES Learn piping design on your own time Reliance on software without a fundamental understanding of the underlying principles of engineering has become a common industry issue. Learn how to avoid costly mistakes time with this new learning path consisting of 4 eLearning courses. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Every day, metal additive technologies continue to change the manufacturing landscape. The gap between technology and integration keeps getting wider. That means employers and managers are looking for a well-trained and skilled workforce to integrate this technology into their workplace. With the help of ASME, that will be you. Save over 50% on this new eLearning course. subject: NEW JOURNAL: CALL FOR PAPERS - ASME Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems
body: ASME Journal of Mechanical Design: Special Issue Call-for-Papers: 'Data-Driven Design (D3)' Editor - Vladimir Vantsevich Connect with us: ASME's Guide for Journal Authors Submit Your Manuscript â†’ ASME Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems CALL FOR PAPERS NEW JOURNAL IN 2021! (First articles online in 2020) The purpose of Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems is to provide an international platform for the communication and discussion of technical knowledge and solutions in the transformative areas of the research and engineering design of autonomous vehicles and systems that operate in all media and inter-medium environments: ground, air, space, and water. The focus of this journal is on an autonomous vehicle system-of-systems approach to modeling, simulation, design, and physical and virtual testing. The vehicle applications include, but are not limited to, personal and cargo transportation, construction and forestry, farming, scientific research, investigation of the underground, air and water, exploration of other planets, infrastructure monitoring, surveillance, military, and beyond. Topic areas include, but are not limited to: autonomous vehicle and multi-domain system dynamics in interaction with multi-physics environment in different media; transdisciplinary-inspired design concepts for safe and secure performance, energy efficiency, and survivability of autonomous vehicles and systems; intelligent morphing and dynamics of autonomous vehicles and systems; intelligent exteroceptive and proprioceptive sensing, actuation, decision-making and controls for agile dynamics and mission/task fulfillment; localization problems, landscape, air and aquatic environment sampling; fault-tolerance in severe, uncertain, and adversarial environments; human-in-the-loop and autonomous intelligent decision making related to dynamics and mission/task learning and fulfillment; integration of autonomous vehicles into the manned and unmanned traffic of their respective media; artificial intelligence and social behavior factors and challenges for communication, decision making, and dynamic interaction between (i) autonomous vehicle systems, (ii) autonomous vehicles, and (iii) autonomous vehicles and infrastructure in a particular medium and inter-medium environments; integration of modeling and simulation with gaming technologies for autonomous vehicle design and training purposes; and transformative conceptual and engineering design for life cycle management of autonomous vehicles and autonomous systems. Scope â€¢ Artificial intelligence â€¢ Intelligent decision making, controls, and observation â€¢ System models â€¢ Modeling, simulation, and designing autonomous vehicle systems for their autonomy â€¢ Payload models â€¢ Proprioceptive sensors in autonomous vehicle systems and exteroceptive sensors for autonomous vehicle and environment interactions â€¢ Outdoor and cyber-physical indoor proving grounds and research facilities â€¢ Inputs/outputs and environmental models in autonomous vehicle simulation and design â€¢ Gaming environments Submission Guidelines All submissions should be prepared in accordance with the ASME Author Guidelines and be submitted through the ASME Journals Connect webpage (journaltool.asme.org). Select Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems. The Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems will debut its Inaugural Issue at the 2020 International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition (IMECE 2020). To be reviewed for inclusion in this Inaugural Issue, papers should be submitted by June 1, 2020. Editor Vladimir Vantsevich, ScD, PhD, ASME Fellow Professor and Director, Vehicle and Robotics Engineering Laboratory School of Engineering / Mechanical Engineering The University of Alabama at Birmingham Mailing Address: 1720 2nd Avenue South / BEC 356D Birmingham, AL 35294-4461, USA Tel: +1 205.975.5855 Email: vantsevi@uab.edu The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® (ASMEÂ®) 041020 - 20205 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. ABOUT US | CONTACT US | PRIVACY | UNSUBSCRIBE | MANAGE PREFERENCES Add @asme.org to your e-mail address book or safe senders to ensure delivery of ASME emails to your inbox. subject: Will Ventilator Hacks Really Work?
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Share Your Coronavirus Stories With Us 04.14.2020 Please Note: Due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, you may experience a delay with receiving Mechanical Engineering magazine depending on your location. Don't fret! You can always read the digital edition at your convenience. Workforce Blog: Tell Me Your Coronavirus Stories The coronavirus pandemic has created havoc in the lives of people around the world. Editor-in-chief of Mechanical Engineering magazine, John Falcioni, invites you to share your stories on how you are coping during the COVID-19 pandemic. Sharing Ventilators: Will Hacks Really Work? Hospitals dealing with COVID-19 face an acute shortage of ventilators, a matter of life and death for patients with critical respiratory problems. To get around the problem, some physicians and engineers are hacking ventilators so they can support more than one patient at a time. Could this be dangerous? Sponsored Ad Your Productivity is Our Priority We know the importance of having the right equipment for working remotely. subject: Digital Version of Mechanical Engineering Magazine is Available
body: ASME Membership Don't let COVID-19 prevent you from reading the ME Magazine Dear Chandu Binu, The novel coronavirus COVID-19 pandemic is a global health crisis that presents a unique challenge that affects every member of the ASME community. We would like to express our concern and support for all the members of this vital community who are affected by this crisis across the world. We understand that this has impacted the postal delivery of the Mechanical Engineering magazine in many countries around the globe. I would like to take this opportunity to remind you that Mechanical Engineering magazine has been and continues to publish a digital version for our members which can be accessed online at https://www.memagazinedigital.org You can continue to stay up to date on new and emerging technologies and trends through this digital version of ASME's award winning, members-only magazine. We hope to resume delivery of the magazine in the near future. Please stay well and stay safe. subject: How 3D Printing is Helping Fight the Coronavirus
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Digital Manufacturing Toolkit for Part Customization 04.16.2020 Please Note: Due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, you may experience a delay with receiving Mechanical Engineering magazine depending on your location. Don't fret! You can always read the digital edition at your convenience. Sponsored Content A Toolkit for Customizing Your Parts with Digital Manufacturing For designers trying to decide between ordering custom parts or off-the-shelf components, digital manufacturers can help. Protolabs highlights the benefits that come with using 3D printing, injection molding, and CNC machining for mass customization and on-demand production. COVID-19 Transforms Life on Engineering College Campuses Colleges across the country are repurposing resources and capitalizing on their expertise in innovation and problem-solving to join the fight against COVID-19. Many labs that normally would have dozens or more varied projects going on simultaneously have now focused solely on ways to flatten the curve of the current pandemic. 8 Ways 3D Printing is Helping to Fight Coronavirus As the COVID-19 pandemic depletes critical medical supplies around the world, 3D printer manufacturers, as well as manufacturers with 3D printers, are converting their processes to produce these vital supplies and equipment. The 3D-printed equipment includes safety goggles, oxygen valves, nasal swabs, masks and shields, ventilator parts, respirators, door openers, and quarantine booths. Sponsored Ad Your Productivity is Our Priority We know the importance of having the right equipment for working remotely. At Dell, you can rely on our expertise in empowering your productivity wherever you are. Visit www.Dell.com/ASME or call 800-757-8442 to speak with a Small Business Tech adviser & reference your Member ID #530005122736. Video: Highlights from 3D Experience World 2020 This video recaps the highlights in 3D printing from the Dassault Systemes' 3D Experience World 2020, held in Nashville, TN, in February 2020. The event brought together a community of designers, engineers, and entrepreneurs who shared their experiences with innovative technology. L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April. Be sure to check out our discounted course list. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Every day, metal additive technologies continue to change the manufacturing landscape. The gap between technology and integration keeps getting wider. That means employers and managers are looking for a well-trained and skilled workforce to integrate this technology into their workplace. With the help of ASME, that will be you. Save over 50% on this new eLearning course. WHITE PAPERS Why Advanced Work Packaging Is Right for Your Organization Owner organizations and contractors alike are both seeing the benefits of adopting an Advanced Work Packaging (AWP) methodology in their capital projects. An AWP framework helps drive increased predictability, improve productivity, and yield significant cost savings. subject: Learn how PTC 19.1 Test Uncertainty can help you evaluate risk at our webinar
body: Register today for ASME's webinar on PTC 19.1 Test Uncertainty Connect with us: Measuring uncertainty can help you to evaluate risk Within any test, thereâ€™s a certain level of risk that something could go wrong. This can lead to inaccurate results, which can influence decisions, putting resources, budgets and even lives in danger. PTC 19.1 helps you to identify the reliability and quality of measurements across different test variables and methodologies. This enables you to make more informed decisions, so you can optimize your test variables and design, which can provide more accurate test results. And, in turn this can lead to better decisions, down-the-line, from the people who are using your test data to help guide their decisions on resources, budgets and factors that could mean the difference between life and death. Register today for our upcoming webinar, where you'll learn about: â€¢ Classification systems used to quantify errors and uncertainties â€¢ The Taylor Series Method and Monte Carlo Method â€“ two internationally accepted uncertainty propagation methods â€¢ Value of performing a pretest and post-test uncertainty analysis, along with the importance of effectively communicating test results â€¢ How performing an uncertainty analysis can help you to evaluate risk and make more informed decisions when designing your tests To register for the webinar or purchase the latest version of the standard, click on the buttons below. ASME PTC 19.1 Standard on Test Uncertainty â€“ Introduction and Applications Date: Thursday, April 30, 2020 Time: 12:00 PM-1:00 PM EST Register Today Buy Now Share our upcoming webinar with colleagues and friends: You will be emailed instructions after registration. Dr. Glenn Steele, a Giles Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Mississippi State University and Ronald Dieck, who served as chairman of the ASME PTC 19.1 on Test Uncertainty committee for over 20 years, will be conducting the webinar. Immediately following the presentation, you'll have 30 minutes for questions. If you have any comments or questions, please contact Michelle Pagano (PaganoM@asme.org) ABOUT THE PRESENTERS Glenn Steele Ph.D., PE Professor Emeritus Mississippi State University Dr. Steele is a Giles Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Mississippi State University (MSU). He received his B.S. in mechanical engineering from MSU and his doctorate from NC State University. Following graduate school, he worked at the Westinghouse/Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory where he did research and development work on nuclear power plant components for the U.S. Navy. After joining the MSU faculty in 1979, Dr. Steele focused on education, research, and service in the energy area with special emphasis on the applications of uncertainty analysis. He served as head of the MSU ME Department and also in other administrative roles including Interim Dean of Engineering, Interim Vice President for Research and Economic Development, Interim Provost and Academic Vice President, and as director of two university research centers. Uncertainty analysis is the primary focus of Dr. Steeleâ€™s involvement with national and international committees on the development of new standards for experimental error analysis. He also has co-authored a book on the subject which is in its fourth edition. Ronald H. Dieck President Ron Dieck Associates, Inc. Ronald H. Dieck served as chairman of ASME PTC19.1 on Test Uncertainty for over 20 years before assuming his current role as vice chairman of the committee. In 2000, he started Ron Dieck Associates, Inc., to provide consulting and training in instrumentation, measurement systems, metrology and measurement uncertainty. Prior to that he served as President of the Instrumentation Systems and Automation Society, ISA, (1998-1999) and also served as the President of the Asian Pacific Federation of Instrumentation and Control Societies, APFICS, (2002). He is the author of the text: Measurement Uncertainty: Methods and Applications, 5th Edition, 2017 and a Fellow of ISA in measurement uncertainty. Ronald H. Dieck holds a bachelor of science degree in physics and chemistry from Houghton College in Houghton, New York, and a master's degree in physics from Trinity College, Hartford, Connecticut. subject: A Quick Ventilator Design for Hospitals Everywhere
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter A Transformer Robot, Voice Controlled and Fully Automated 04.21.2020 Powerful Breakthrough Batteries Researchers at Monash University in Australia have developed a lithium-sulfur battery that can last more than four times longer than standard lithium-ion batteries. It uses commonly available materials, is easy to manufacture, and is a good candidate for commercialization. A Ventilator for Everyone With ventilators in short supply, researchers at the Bakken Medical Devices Center have created a simplified version that can be produced quickly and on the cheap. In a single week, they created a prototype that could easily be reproduced in any hospital. The FDA recently approved the production and use of this ventilator. A Robotic Transformation Fans of Optimus Prime, pay attention. Upon voice command, a new programmable robot automatically converts from a robot man to a vehicle in a smooth and seamless transformer-like movement. L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April. Be sure to check out our discounted course list. Learn Piping Design On Your Own Time Reliance on software without a fundamental understanding of the underlying principles of engineering has become a common industry issue. Learn how to avoid costly mistakes time with this new learning path consisting of 4 eLearning courses. WHITE PAPERS Why Advanced Work Packaging Is Right for Your Organization Owner organizations and contractors alike are both seeing the benefits of adopting an Advanced Work Packaging (AWP) methodology in their capital projects. An AWP framework helps drive increased predictability, improve productivity, and yield significant cost savings. subject: Make Connections and Present Your Research at IMECE 2020
body: ASME 2019 IMECE: Call for Papers The IMECE 2020Â® Presentation Only Abstract Submission Deadline is July 13, 2020 Connect with us: Present your work while finding your next research collaboration at IMECE 2020Â® Submit an Abstract â†’ Presentation Only Abstract Deadline: July 13, 2020 There are still opportunities to present your latest mechanical engineering research at the International Mechanical Engineering Congress & ExpositionÂ®. IMECE 2020Â® is ASMEâ€™s largest research and development conference primarily focused on mechanical engineering that provides attendees with broad, but salient perspectives and knowledge-sharing on technical advances within the field. Showcase your ideas to the global mechanical engineering community by presenting your work related to one of the seventeen IMECE 2020Â® tracks. View all IMECE 2020 Tracks Besides presenting research, attendees go to IMECE to foster new professional relationships among their peers. A recent IMECE attendee says, â€œI like IMECE because it creates a networking opportunity with scholars from a wide range of mechanical engineering disciplines.â€ Another past attendee says that IMECE has â€œgreat networking opportunities as the number of people who attended was huge.â€ Take advantage of the opportunity to present your research but stay to connect with your mechanical engineering colleagues from around the world. The IMECE 2020 presentation only abstract submission deadline is July 13, 2020. If you have any questions, please email congresshelp@asme.org. subject: A COVID-19 Design Community Connects Engineers
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Nanotechnology for Fast-Charging Batteries 04.23.2020 The Robot Will See You Now Robots are proving their worth during the COVID-19 pandemic. From Wuhan, China, where Danish robots are sanitizing hospitals and public spaces with UV radiation to Israel, where telepresence robots enable doctors to examine patients from a distance, and to Italy, where robotic arms mounted on robots may soon swab patients' throats, robots are making their mark. Connect with Engineers via the Open COVID-19 Community Dassault SystÃ¨mes has created the Open COVID-19 Community, an open network platform of engineers, FabLabs, makers, hospitals, and medical professionals. Their goal is to expedite the design and manufacturing of parts and equipment to help treat COVID-19 patients. 7 Big Advances in Soft Robotic Grippers Soft robotic grippers have burst onto the scene. With the ability of a single gripper to pick up a broad range of irregular, delicate, and unstructured objects, soft grippers promise to revolutionize how robots interact with the world around them. We look at seven of the most advanced soft grippers. Sponsored Ad ASME TechCast: Fast-Charging Batteries Depend on Nanotechnology Durable, fast-charging batteries are essential to the development of electric vehicles and evolution of the smart grid. StoreDot CEO Doron Myersdorf talks about the breakthrough in battery technology, eliminating carbon and using nano and other materials to make a battery that can charge an electronic device in 60 seconds. The next step is overcoming obstacles to a full-sized battery. L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April. Be sure to check out our discounted course list. subject: 5 Key Lean Principles for Engineers
body: ASME TechWorkforce - ME Magazine Newsletter Coming Together to Make a Difference During COVID-19 04.24.2020 Coming Together and Making a Difference During COVID-19 Pandemic When times are tough people come together. Engineers and technologists are on the forefront of working to mitigate the consequences of this deadly virus. The ASME team has rallied together from locations around the world. Sponsored Ad Video: The Importance of Educating Every Level of Your Workforce Educating every level of your workforce is critical, as is monitoring their progress to see what gaps need to be addressed. Constantly assess your engineers' needs and find solutions to help them apply the ins and outs of the latest engineering technology. Infographic: 5 Key Lean Principles for Engineers When done correctly, lean can lead to huge improvements in efficiency, cycle time, and productivity, leading to lower costs and enhanced competitiveness. Here are five key lean principles that all engineers must know to generate improvements in any business or production process. QUIZ: What Do You Know about the Saugus Iron Works? When the English colonies were first established in North America, they were dependent on their home country for metal goods. One of the first steps toward self-sufficiencyâ€“and independenceâ€“was the establishment of the Saugus Iron Works in 1647. Test your knowledge of this mechanical engineering landmark. In 1641, the government of the Massachusetts Bay colony appointed 35-year-old John Winthrop to direct a new iron making enterprise. Aside from being one of the few men in the colony with a talent for science, what was Winthrop's biggest qualification? He was the richest man in the colony. He owned the only source of iron. His father was the governor. He had been an iron maker back in England. L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April. Be sure to check out our discounted course list. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Every day, metal additive technologies continue to change the manufacturing landscape. The gap between technology and integration keeps getting wider. That means employers and managers are looking for a well-trained and skilled workforce to integrate this technology into their workplace. With the help of ASME, that will be you. Save over 50% on this new eLearning course. WEBINARS Introduction to Predictive Analytics for Engineers May 27 | 2pm ET This webinar introduces the topic of predictive analytics using use cases and SmartUQ software for illustrative purposes. subject: Discover how testing uncertainty with PTC 19.1 can lead to better decisions
body: Register today for ASME's webinar on PTC 19.1 Test Uncertainty Connect with us: Discover the importance of measuring uncertainty The level of uncertainty in the tests you run can impact results and decisions made down-the-line based off these results. PTC 19.1 helps you to measure the level of uncertainty across different testing variables, so you can optimize your tests and minimize any impact this can cause. At our upcoming webinar, you'll be introduced to the specific methods and techniques that help scientists and engineers make more meaningful decisions during the overall test process. Register today for our upcoming webinar where youâ€™ll learn about: â€¢ Classification systems used to quantify errors and uncertainties â€¢ The Taylor Series Method and Monte Carlo Method - two internationally accepted error propagation methods â€¢ Value of performing a pretest and post-test uncertainty analysis, along with the importance of effectively communicating test results â€¢ How performing an uncertainty analysis can help you to evaluate risk and make more informed decisions when designing your tests To register for the webinar or purchase the latest version of the standard, click on the buttons below. ASME PTC 19.1 Standard on Test Uncertainty â€“ Introduction and Applications Date: Thursday, April 30, 2020 Time: 12:00 PM-1:00 PM EST Share our upcoming webinar with colleagues and friends: You will be emailed instructions after registration. Dr. Glenn Steele, a Giles Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Mississippi State University and Ronald Dieck, who served as chairman of the ASME PTC 19.1 on Test Uncertainty committee for over 20 years, will be conducting the webinar. Immediately following the presentation, you'll have 30 minutes for questions. If you have any comments or questions, please contact Michelle Pagano (PaganoM@asme.org) ABOUT THE PRESENTERS Glenn Steele Ph.D., PE Professor Emeritus Mississippi State University Dr. Steele is a Giles Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Mississippi State University (MSU). He received his B.S. in mechanical engineering from MSU and his doctorate from NC State University. Following graduate school, he worked at the Westinghouse/Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory where he did research and development work on nuclear power plant components for the U.S. Navy. After joining the MSU faculty in 1979, Dr. Steele focused on education, research, and service in the energy area with special emphasis on the applications of uncertainty analysis. He served as head of the MSU ME Department and also in other administrative roles including Interim Dean of Engineering, Interim Vice President for Research and Economic Development, Interim Provost and Academic Vice President, and as director of two university research centers. Uncertainty analysis is the primary focus of Dr. Steeleâ€™s involvement with national and international committees on the development of new standards for experimental error analysis. He also has co-authored a book on the subject which is in its fourth edition. Ronald H. Dieck President Ron Dieck Associates, Inc. Ronald H. Dieck served as chairman of ASME PTC19.1 on Test Uncertainty for over 20 years before assuming his current role as vice chairman of the committee. In 2000, he started Ron Dieck Associates, Inc., to provide consulting and training in instrumentation, measurement systems, metrology and measurement uncertainty. Prior to that he served as President of the Instrumentation Systems and Automation Society, ISA, (1998-1999) and also served as the President of the Asian Pacific Federation of Instrumentation and Control Societies, APFICS, (2002). He is the author of the text: Measurement Uncertainty: Methods and Applications, 5th Edition, 2017 and a Fellow of ISA in measurement uncertainty. Ronald H. Dieck holds a bachelor of science degree in physics and chemistry from Houghton College in Houghton, New York, and a master's degree in physics from Trinity College, Hartford, Connecticut. subject: How COVID-19 Will Change the Engineering Workforce
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Why are ventilators so difficult to engineer? 04.28.2020 COVID-19 May Change the Engineering Workforce The engineering profession won't be exempt from COVID-19 job fallout, but the effects will be temporary, with more engineers needed than ever before after the world returns to a semblance of normalcy. Tomorrow's engineers will also need the soft skillsâ€”the ability to communicate with othersâ€”that go along with working in current multidisciplinary engineering environments. Sponsored Ad Video: Engineering Challenges to Making Ventilators Ventilators are the last line of defense against coronavirus. They deliver concentrated oxygen to patients with fluid in their lungs and remove toxic carbon dioxide. As engineers work quickly to build simplified systems to fight COVID-19, here are some of the key challenges they face. Sponsored Ad ASME Exclusive Dell Sale ASME Members can save up to 50% off on select Latitude 3400 & 3500 laptops while limited quantities lasts! To access this promotion, reach out to Mona_Besleaga@Dell.com or call in to speak with a Small Business Advisor at 800-757-8442. Be sure to mention ASME Member ID: 530005122736 www.dell.com/ASME Quiz: The History of Mechanical Engineering Mechanical engineering came into its own as a discipline during the Industrial Revolution, but its roots go back to antiquity. See what you know about its development. Simple machines, which change direction or magnitude of force, have been known since prehistoric times when the wedge and inclined plane were used. When and where was the wheel and axle invented? Fifth Millenium BC, Greece Third Millenium BC, Greece Fifth Millenium BC, Mesopatamia Fourth Millenium BC, Egypt Sponsored Ad L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Every day, metal additive technologies continue to change the manufacturing landscape. The gap between technology and integration keeps getting wider. That means employers and managers are looking for a well-trained and skilled workforce to integrate this technology into their workplace. With the help of ASME, that will be you. Save 90% on this new eLearning course. WHITE PAPERS Exploring the Mechanism and Longevity of Corrosion Inhibitors in Insulation Even the best designed and installed systems sometimes become compromised, resulting in the presence of water at the pipe surface and the potential for CUI. As such, it is important to understand how the chemistry of the thermal insulation affects the CUI potential. subject: Explore how PTC 19.1 can lead to better test results
body: Register today for ASME's webinar on PTC 19.1 Test Uncertainty Connect with us: Build confidence in your results by using PTC 19.1 to help reduce uncertainty When conducting a test, every decision matters, as errors can occur with each variable you include, negatively impacting your results. An error is the difference between a measurement and its expected true value. And uncertainties quantify the limits of error within which the true value should lie. Discover how PTC 19.1 can help you to make more meaningful decisions across your test process by measuring the level of uncertainty for each variable. By doing so, you can optimize your testâ€™s performance and minimize any errors, helping to build confidence in your results. Register today for our upcoming webinar where youâ€™ll learn about: â€¢ Classification systems used to quantify errors and uncertainties â€¢ The Taylor Series Method and Monte Carlo Method - two internationally accepted error propagation methods â€¢ Value of performing a pretest and post-test uncertainty analysis, along with the importance of effectively communicating test results â€¢ How performing an uncertainty analysis can help you to evaluate risk and make more informed decisions when designing your tests To register for the webinar or purchase the latest version of the standard, click on the buttons below. ASME PTC 19.1 Standard on Test Uncertainty â€“ Introduction and Applications Date: Thursday, April 30, 2020 Time: 12:00 PM-1:00 PM EST Share our upcoming webinar with colleagues and friends: You will be emailed instructions after registration. subject: Resources and Programs Offer Response to COVID-19 Pandemic
body: ASME News April 17, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 8/ April 17, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 8 / April 29, 2020 Resources and Programs Offer Response to COVID-19 Pandemic ASME has been actively responding to the COVID-19 challenge by making many of its resources available during this trying time. These resources include COVID-19 coverage in Mechanical Engineering magazine and on ASME.org, articles in the journals and proceedings, and educational opportunities for professional engineers as well as university and K-12 students. Read more Sponsored Ad Slip Clutches for Human-Device Interaction Dynatect offers small, tight-tolerance clutches for vehicle applications including protecting automatic door/hatch drive mechanisms from human-applied overload or interference. In another instance: autonomous driving vehicles that need the steering wheel to slide, fold, or break-away to allow control in the event of electrical failure. Learn more â†’ Virtual Summit Explores Advanced Manufacturing for Medical Applications Next month, ASME will hold a one-of-a-kind virtual event focusing on advances in additive manufacturing (AM) and 3D printing for medical applications. Registration for the new event, the AM Medical Virtual Summit, is brought to you for free thanks to the support of the eventâ€™s sponsors. Read more Sponsored Ad Presentation-Only Abstracts for IMECE 2020 Due in July ASME 2020 International Mechanical Engineering Congress and ExpositionÂ® (IMECE) organizers are currently accepting presentation-only abstracts. The deadline to submit an IMECE 2020 presentation-only abstract for an oral or poster presentation is July 13. Read more Sponsored Ad New Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems Seeks Submissions Manuscripts are now being accepted for a new journal, the ASME Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems, which will officially launch in conjunction with the International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition in November. Read more Sponsored Ad Why Advanced Work Packaging Is Right for Your Organization In this white paper, youâ€™ll discover the many benefits of Advanced Work Packaging, including: Advantages over traditional project management techniques & benefits to be realized for both owners and contractors. Learn more â†’ Annual Leadership Conference Draws Cross-Section of Members For the third year, leaders from the Societyâ€™s professional sections, technical divisions and research committees â€” along with nearly 20 university student section advisors â€” came together at the annual Group Leadership Development Conference (GLDC) just outside of Las Vegas. Read more Sponsored Ad How Kawasaki Optimized Production with 3D Printed Tooling Read this large-format additive use case to find out: How thermoplastics hold up to metal as end tooling for automated equipment; Why detailed logistics are important to get the most out of your AM system & how on-demand solutions can solve bottlenecks. Learn more â†’ Learn from Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses, so be sure to check out our discounted course list. Learn more Richard Klopp ASME member Richard W. Klopp, Ph.D., P.E., principal engineer at Exponent Inc., was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. A well-regarded professional with substantial experience and expertise in the field of engineering failure analysis and prevention, Dr. Kloppâ€™s work has impacted the fields of industrial machinery, electric and gas utilities, fire protection, medical equipment and devices, recreational products, and missile defense. Learn more â†’ Sreekant Narumanchi ASME member Sreekant Narumanchi, Ph.D., the acting manager of the Advanced Power Electronics and Electric Machines (APEEM) group in the Center for Integrated Mobility Sciences at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. ASME honored Dr. Narumanchi for his extensive involvement with ASME and his excellence in mechanical engineering research at NREL. Text: Resources and Programs Offer Response to COVID-19 Pandemic ASME News April 17, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 8/ April 17, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 8 / April 29, 2020 Resources and Programs Offer Response to COVID-19 Pandemic ASME has been actively responding to the COVID-19 challenge by making many of its resources available during this trying time. These resources include COVID-19 coverage in Mechanical Engineering magazine and on ASME.org, articles in the journals and proceedings, and educational opportunities for professional engineers as well as university and K-12 students. Read more Sponsored Ad Slip Clutches for Human-Device Interaction Dynatect offers small, tight-tolerance clutches for vehicle applications including protecting automatic door/hatch drive mechanisms from human-applied overload or interference. In another instance: autonomous driving vehicles that need the steering wheel to slide, fold, or break-away to allow control in the event of electrical failure. Learn more â†’ Virtual Summit Explores Advanced Manufacturing for Medical Applications Next month, ASME will hold a one-of-a-kind virtual event focusing on advances in additive manufacturing (AM) and 3D printing for medical applications. Registration for the new event, the AM Medical Virtual Summit, is brought to you for free thanks to the support of the eventâ€™s sponsors. Read more Sponsored Ad Presentation-Only Abstracts for IMECE 2020 Due in July ASME 2020 International Mechanical Engineering Congress and ExpositionÂ® (IMECE) organizers are currently accepting presentation-only abstracts. The deadline to submit an IMECE 2020 presentation-only abstract for an oral or poster presentation is July 13. Read more Sponsored Ad New Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems Seeks Submissions Manuscripts are now being accepted for a new journal, the ASME Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems, which will officially launch in conjunction with the International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition in November. Read more Sponsored Ad Why Advanced Work Packaging Is Right for Your Organization In this white paper, youâ€™ll discover the many benefits of Advanced Work Packaging, including: Advantages over traditional project management techniques & benefits to be realized for both owners and contractors. Learn more â†’ Annual Leadership Conference Draws Cross-Section of Members For the third year, leaders from the Societyâ€™s professional sections, technical divisions and research committees â€” along with nearly 20 university student section advisors â€” came together at the annual Group Leadership Development Conference (GLDC) just outside of Las Vegas. Read more Sponsored Ad How Kawasaki Optimized Production with 3D Printed Tooling Read this large-format additive use case to find out: How thermoplastics hold up to metal as end tooling for automated equipment; Why detailed logistics are important to get the most out of your AM system & how on-demand solutions can solve bottlenecks. Learn more â†’ Learn from Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses, so be sure to check out our discounted course list. Learn more Richard Klopp ASME member Richard W. Klopp, Ph.D., P.E., principal engineer at Exponent Inc., was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. A well-regarded professional with substantial experience and expertise in the field of engineering failure analysis and prevention, Dr. Kloppâ€™s work has impacted the fields of industrial machinery, electric and gas utilities, fire protection, medical equipment and devices, recreational products, and missile defense. Learn more â†’ Sreekant Narumanchi ASME member Sreekant Narumanchi, Ph.D., the acting manager of the Advanced Power Electronics and Electric Machines (APEEM) group in the Center for Integrated Mobility Sciences at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. ASME honored Dr. Narumanchi for his extensive involvement with ASME and his excellence in mechanical engineering research at NREL. The International Gas Turbine Instituteâ€™s (IGTI) Student Advisory Committee is accepting applications for Vice-Chair and Secretary positions that will serve from July 2020 â€“ June 2021. The Vice-Chair is responsible for recruiting student liaisons to cover 20+ committees and steps in to represent the SAC to the IGTI if the Chair is unavailable. The Secretary writes all formal correspondence for the SAC and takes notes during all meetings. The deadline to apply for both positions is May 20, 2020. Apply Today â†’ Have questions? subject: Engineers Tackle Water Shortages
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Digital Solutions During the Coronavirus 04.30.2020 The Engineer Who Discovered Global Warming One steam engineer, working alone in his spare time, uncovered the connection between rising carbon dioxide levels and global warming. Meet the engineer who discovered todayâ€™s most contentious issue. Podcast: Digital Solutions During the Coronavirus Pandemic Mechanical Engineering spoke with Tony Hemmelgarn, president and CEO of Siemens digital industries software and Robert Meschel, Director at Siemens Additive Manufacturing Network about how Siemens is providing digital solutions to engineers during the COVID-19 pandemic. Engineers Tackle Water Shortages Some two billion people struggle every day to find safe, clean drinking water. The Department of Energy has launched its largest program in 60 yearsâ€”$100 millionâ€”to find a solution to a problem that will only grow worse. But engineers will need to meet tough cost constraints to make them work. subject: Spread the Word about ASME's Free Freshman/First Year Student Membership
body: ASME Membership Freshman/First Year Students Can Join ASME for Free Connect with us: Spread the Word! ASME Student Membership is Free for Freshman/First Year Students You are already enjoying your FREE ASME Student Membership Isn't it time you let your friends in on the secret? Thank you for joining ASME as a student member and taking advantage of our Freshman/First Year Free option! Now we need your help to be sure every other eligible student knows about this great opportunity! As a student member you are the perfect ambassador to communicate the value of ASME to your Freshman/First Year friends who have yet to join. Simply point them to our quick and easy online form and they can become a student member for absolutely no-cost in just minutes! http://go.asme.org/students or http://go.asme.org/join In addition to telling your peers about this opportunity in person, you can also share ASME's Freshman/First Year Free Student Membership offer on Facebook, LinkedIn, Google+ and Twitter - or by forwarding this email or posting the offer on your university intranet - or however you wish! ASME is committed to helping mechanical engineering students reach their full potential - and with the help of students like you - we can continue to grow our global community of professional engineers and students who are working together to address the world's concerns in meaningful ways. Please help us spread the word about ASME Freshman/First Year Free Student Membership â€” your friends will thank you for it. http://go.asme.org/students or http://go.asme.org/join Unbeatable Benefits! Like regular ASME student membership, Freshman/First Year Free Membership includes unlimited use of AccessEngineering, ASME's world-class online reference tool with over 800 engineering titles including the essential Marks' Standard Handbook for Mechanical Engineers; Perry's Chemical Engineers' Handbook; Standard Handbook for Civil Engineers; Standard Handbook for Electrical Engineers, just to name a few! subject: A Robotic Blood Test
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter A Toolkit for Digital Manufacturing 05.05.2020 Sponsored Content A Toolkit for Customizing Your Parts with Digital Manufacturing For designers trying to decide between ordering custom parts or off-the-shelf components, digital manufacturers can help. Protolabs highlights the benefits that come with using 3D printing, injection molding, and CNC machining for mass customization and on-demand production. An Autonomous Blood Test Finding a vein to take a blood sample can be a prickly experience. A new robot called Venibot uses ultrasound to better locate a vein and insert the needle for a blood test. Sponsored Ad How Will IoT Change Engineering? How has the IoT changed the way you work? Professional Engineering, the IMechEâ€™s membership magazine, has teamed up with ARM for a global report on the Internet of Things and engineering, and we need your expert opinions. Take our quick survey for a chance to win a $125 Amazon voucher. Click here. Quiz: What Do You Know About Medieval Inventions? Many of us discount the Middle Ages as nothing more than a 1,000-year-long interregnum between the fall of Rome and the Renaissance. Yet Medieval times gave us some of our most important inventions. How much do you know about them? Before the Middle Ages, European ships steered either with oars or quarter rudders mounted on the sides of the ship one-quarter of the way from the stern. Starting in the 12th Century, what invention replaced the side rudder? Pintle-and-gudgeon rudder Double-hinged rudder Fixed steering oar Full-mounted steering plane L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April. Get discounts of up to 90% on select eLearning courses. That means employers and managers are looking for a well-trained and skilled workforce to integrate this technology into their workplace. With the help of ASME, that will be you. Save 90% on this new eLearning course. WHITE PAPERS Exploring the Mechanism and Longevity of Corrosion Inhibitors in Insulation Even the best designed and installed systems sometimes become compromised, resulting in the presence of water at the pipe surface and the potential for CUI. As such, it is important to understand how the chemistry of the thermal insulation affects the CUI potential. body: ASME 2019 IMECE: Call for Papers IMECE 2020 Presentation Only Abstract Submission Deadline is July 13, 2020 Connect with us: IMECE 2020Â® is the perfect venue to present your ideas to the Mechanical Engineering Community Submit an Abstract â†’ Presentation Only Abstract Submission Deadline: July 13, 2020 Are you looking for the perfect opportunity to present your latest mechanical engineering research? Then consider presenting at ASMEâ€™s International Mechanical Engineering Congress and ExpositionÂ® (IMECEÂ®) from November 15 - 19, 2020, in Portland, Oregon, at the Oregon Convention Center. IMECE 2020Â® is accepting presentation only abstracts for 17 different tracks, including Advances in Aerospace Technology, Heat Transfer and Thermal Engineering, and Micro- and Nano-Systems Engineering and Packaging. Presenting at IMECE 2020 allows you to share your research with engineering professionals from around the world and receive feedback to enhance your work. View all 17 IMECE 2020 Tracks A previous IMECE attendee recommends the event because of â€œthe breadth of themes being addressed. subject: Scale up your career by learning new skills for advancement and reskilling for the next big opportunity
body: ME Today May 2020 Newsletter ME Today: Learn from home; How to continue learning new tech with your job; Day in the Life at Raytheon; 5 questions with IBM's most prolific inventor May Issue 2020 Learn from Home Now is the time to scale up your career by learning new skills for advancement and reskilling for the next big opportunity. enroll now Sponsored Ad Message from ASME Early Career Programming Committee On behalf of ASME Early Career Programming Committee we want to extend our heartfelt gratitude for those men and women on the front lines of the COVID-19 pandemic. We also want to share with you the ASME statement on COVID-19 response. There you will find updated information and how you can get involved. learn more Sponsored Ad How to continue learning new technologies with your job? Brian Breuhan, an Early Equipment Management Lead at Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, provides his perspective on how to get leap on learning about new technologies based on his experience. learn more ASME FutureME Group on LinkedIn ASME is excited to announce that we have just launched the ASME FutureME LinkedIn Group! This group will provide you a richer and more stream-lined way to receive updates from the FutureME community, access engineering content and resources, and connect and interact with other early career engineers like yourself. join now Webinar: A Day in the Life of an ME working at Raytheon Learn what it's like to work as a mechanical engineer for the world's top defense, civil government and cybersecurity Company. Come join us for this exclusive webinar with Carlos Hurtado, an Engineering Lead at Raytheon. register now Sponsored Ad Your Natural Talent + Our Engineering Degree Learn from award-winning engineers. Gain advanced knowledge of mechanics and thermal fluid science. Hands-on CAD experience. Take Your career further with Michigan State University's online M.S. in Mechanical Engineering. learn more 5 Questions with IBM's Lisa Seacat DeLuca Lisa Seacat DeLuca is one of IBM's most prolific inventors. She is a Distinguished Engineer, the director of the Watson Internet of Things division, and has over 500 patents to her name. learn more IMECE 2020Â® is now accepting Presentation Only Abstracts International Mechanical Engineering Congress & ExpositionÂ® (IMECE 2020Â®) is accepting presentation only abstracts on 17 different tracks, including advanced manufacturing, fluids engineering, and energy. The Presentation Only abstract deadline is July 13, 2020. Presenting at IMECE 2020 (Nov) is a fantastic way to introduce your research and ideas to the mechanical engineering community. submit today Sponsored Ad Solar Energy Applications This book covers varied aspects of solar energy in use around the globe. subject: COVID-19 Oil Price Crash Requires New Thinking
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Corrosion Inhibitor Provides Longevity to Metal Surfaces 05.07.2020 Video: ASME Studies the Impact of COVID-19 on Engineering ASME is conducting an ongoing study tracking how COVID-19 is impacting the ASME community and engineering organizations. The first phase of the survey had close to 3,000 responses. This video highlights some of the responses and the ways the pandemic is changing how engineers work. Sponsored Content Infographic: Exploring the Mechanism and Longevity of the XOX Corrosion Inhibitor Johns Manville infographic helps engineers to understand better how insulation with corrosion-inhibiting properties can limit corrosion by forming a protective surface layer, which does not disappear over repeated wet/dry exposures. Utilizing these findings can be the first step in building a comprehensive corrosion mitigation strategy. Sponsored Ad How Will IoT Change Engineering? How has the IoT changed the way you work? Professional Engineering, the IMechE's membership magazine, has teamed up with ARM for a global report on the Internet of Things and engineering, and we need your expert opinions. Take our quick survey for a chance to win a $125 Amazon voucher. Click Here Energy Blog: It's Time to Break with the Past Despite how common price spikes and collapses are, the recent oil price crash is different. It has different causesâ€”from overproduction and vaporized demandâ€”and will have different impacts. 8 Engineering Challenges for Desalination Technologies Desalination continues to move toward the forefront of clean-water technologies. Engineering challenges, however, remain for improving the desalination process. L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses through the end of April. Be sure to check out our discounted course list. Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Every day, metal additive technologies continue to change the manufacturing landscape. The gap between technology and integration keeps getting wider. That means employers and managers are looking for a well-trained and skilled workforce to integrate this technology into their workplace. With the help of ASME, that will be you. Save 90% on this new eLearning course. FREE WEBINAR How to Choose the Right First Project to Automate with Robotics While industrial automation technologies benefit multiple industries, it is important to understand the full process in order to select the appropriate application for a robot and properly implement a solution. Join ASME and Chris Quick, Founder & CEO, RealBotics, Inc. on May 11 at 12:00 pm EST to learn how to choose the right robotics automation project for your organization. These programs foster collaboration between engineering departments, develop a diverse STEM workforce, and focus on design innovation for global development and the benefit of society. subject: Discover how PTC 19.1 Test Uncertainty can help improve the reliability of your tests
body: Check out ASME's on-demand webinar on PTC 19.1 Test Uncertainty Connect with us: Watch the PTC 19.1 webinar on demand ASME's latest webinar on PTC 19.1 explores the specific methods and techniques that help engineers and scientists make meaningful decisions during the overall test process and when selecting a measurement device or system. Understanding the credibility of your measurements can be essential to the reliability of your results. Discover how PTC 19.1 can help you to make more meaningful decisions across your test process by measuring the level of uncertainty for each variable. By doing so, you can optimize your test's performance and minimize any errors, helping to build confidence in your results. Watch ASMEâ€™s webinar on PTC 19.1 today and learn about: â€¢ Classification systems used to quantify errors and uncertainties â€¢ The Taylor Series Method and Monte Carlo Method - two internationally accepted error propagation methods â€¢ Value of performing a pretest and post-test uncertainty analysis, along with the importance of effectively communicating test results â€¢ How performing an uncertainty analysis can help you to evaluate risk and make more informed decisions when designing your tests To watch the webinar or purchase the latest version of the standard, click on the buttons below. ASME PTC 19.1 Standard on Test Uncertainty â€“ Introduction and Applications Share our upcoming webinar with colleagues and friends: You will be emailed instructions after registration. Dr. Glenn Steele, a Giles Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Mississippi State University and Ronald Dieck, who served as chairman of the ASME PTC 19.1 on Test Uncertainty committee for over 20 years, will be conducting the webinar. Immediately following the presentation, you'll have 30 minutes for questions. If you have any comments or questions, please contact Michelle Pagano ABOUT THE PRESENTERS Glenn Steele Ph.D., PE Professor Emeritus Mississippi State University Dr. Steele is a Giles Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Mississippi State University (MSU). He received his B.S. in mechanical engineering from MSU and his doctorate from NC State University. Following graduate school, he worked at the Westinghouse/Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory where he did research and development work on nuclear power plant components for the U.S. Navy. After joining the MSU faculty in 1979, Dr. Steele focused on education, research, and service in the energy area with special emphasis on the applications of uncertainty analysis. He served as head of the MSU ME Department and also in other administrative roles including Interim Dean of Engineering, Interim Vice President for Research and Economic Development, Interim Provost and Academic Vice President, and as director of two university research centers. Uncertainty analysis is the primary focus of Dr. Steeleâ€™s involvement with national and international committees on the development of new standards for experimental error analysis. He also has co-authored a book on the subject which is in its fourth edition. Ronald H. Dieck President Ron Dieck Associates, Inc. Ronald H. Dieck served as chairman of ASME PTC19.1 on Test Uncertainty for over 20 years before assuming his current role as vice chairman of the committee. In 2000, he started Ron Dieck Associates, Inc., to provide consulting and training in instrumentation, measurement systems, metrology and measurement uncertainty. Prior to that he served as President of the Instrumentation Systems and Automation Society, ISA, (1998-1999) and also served as the President of the Asian Pacific Federation of Instrumentation and Control Societies, APFICS, (2002). He is the author of the text: Measurement Uncertainty: Methods and Applications, 5th Edition, 2017 and a Fellow of ISA in measurement uncertainty. Ronald H. Dieck holds a bachelor of science degree in physics and chemistry from Houghton College in Houghton, New York, and a master's degree in physics from Trinity College, Hartford, Connecticut.
