subject: Designing the Next-Generation Bionic Limbs
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Submit Your Innovations for the 2020 Emerging Tech Awards 05.12.2020 ASME TechCast: Designing Next-Generation Bionic Limbs MIT Media Lab Biomechatronics Group's Matt Carney designs and builds personalized bionic limbs. In this ASME TechCast episode, Carney discusses his interest in humanoid robots as well as the importance of design aesthetics and user experience in developing prosthetics. Calling All Innovations for the 2020 Emerging Technology Awards Every year, the editors of Mechanical Engineering magazine consider dozens of innovations in each of five engineering-related areas-clean energy, bioengineering, advanced manufacturing, robotics, and pressure technology. We are calling for submissions on new innovations for 2020. Prague's Historic Astronomical Clock Prague's astronomical clock is not only a medieval remnant, but also a mechanical landmark, operating in some manner for centuries. Surprisingly, the clock is still powered by much of the original mechanism. Take this quiz to see what you know about this historic astronomical clock. In what year was the clock completed? 1475 1410 1510 1492 L&D COURSES Learn From Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. Get discounts of up to 90% on select eLearning courses. Learn Piping Design At Home Reliance on software without a fundamental understanding of the underlying principles of engineering has become a common industry issue. Save over 75% on this new 4-course eLearning solution. WHITE PAPERS How Kawasaki Optimized Production with 3D Printed Tooling By using additive manufacturing, Kawasaki optimized its automotive and aerospace production processes, saving 85% of estimated outsourcing costs. BigRep's large-format additive manufacturing systems found innovative solutions to their unique manufacturing challenges. subject: Resilient Technologies Battling Climate Change
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Post-Pandemic Discussions We Must Have 05.14.2020 Bioengineering Blog: Remote Modeling and Simulation for Medical Design To make informed design decisions with limited access to testing while working from home, there is an opportunity to use computational modeling and simulation to fill that knowledge gap. This allows design work to continue and can ultimately improve the development process as pandemic-related restrictions are lifted, and companies create the new normal" for medical device development. The Post-Pandemic Discussions We Must Have As we imagine a world post-coronavirus

subject: 9 Materials Transforming Manufacturing
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Bridge Ventilators Fill the Gap 05.19.2020 Bridge Ventilators Fill the Gap Virgin Orbit designs and builds a bridge ventilator for patients with mild COVID-19 symptoms, freeing ventilators for the more seriously ill. The company has already manufactured its first batch in-house for immediate shipment to hospitals. It also is partnering with local and international manufacturers to expand production. 9 Material Discoveries that Could Transform Manufacturing Scientists continue to invent advanced materials with highly specific properties that outperform existing materials and enable more innovative product designs. These include titanium fluoride phosphate, self-healing polymer gel, platinum-gold alloy, composite metal foam, spider silk, carbon-reinforced concrete, aerogel, and rare-earth alloys. QUIZ: How Are Robots Helping Combat COVID-19? Over the past decade, engineers have built smarter robots that can orient in place, avoid obstacles, follow voice commands and make decisions. Roboticists are now realizing another convenient attribute of robotic systemsâ€”they are impervious to disease outbreaks. Take this quiz to find out how robots are helping combat the coronavirus pandemic. Developed by the Danish company UVD Robots, this autonomous device disinfects hospital rooms, shopping malls, supermarkets, train stations, offices, assisted living and nursing homes, fitness centers, schools, and prisons. Name the robot: Iron Giant SCARA robot Pathogen Enemy Number One Germ-Falcon UV-C Robot L&D COURSES Learn From Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. subject: Get Ready to submit your IMECE 2020 National Science Foundation Student Poster Abstracts
body: ASME 2019 IMECE: Call for Papers The IMECE 2020 National Science Foundation Student Poster Abstract Submission Deadline is July 13, 2020 Connect with us: Participate in the IMECE 2020Â® National Science Foundation Student Poster Competition! Submit an Abstract â†’ IMECE 2020Â® National Science Foundation Student Poster Abstraction Submission Deadline: July 13, 2020 The International Mechanical Engineering Congress and ExpositionÂ® (IMECE 2020Â®) organizers are now accepting abstracts for the National Science Foundation (NSF) student poster competition. Students and graduates can present/compete based on work from their NSF-funded research. The NSF poster competition has two topics: 16-1 Poster Session: NSF-funded Research (Grad & Undergrad) 16-2 Poster Session: NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) During IMECE 2020Â®, both NSF topics will run simultaneously to encourage attendees to network and share information with other participants. The NSF track organizers will provide further information on submission details and the availability of travel grants. The poster competition qualifications include: The lead author/presenting author must be a currently registered student (undergraduate or graduate) or has graduated within the past year. Work needs to be from the past two years and NSF majority funded (i.e., research, educational, fellowship, or SBIR/STTR program). After abstract acceptance, the authors will provide the information associated with competition entry and limited travel award application for supplementing travel costs. This is a great opportunity to interact with and learn from your fellow student researchers. The NSF student poster abstract deadline is July 13, 2020, if you have any questions, please email congresshelp@asme.org. subject: You're Invited! Join the ASME FutureME LinkedIn Group
body: ASME E-Fests A community for engineers with 0-10 years of work experience. Innovate. Create. Compete. Celebrate. ASME E-FESTSÂ® NEWS Whatâ€™s Trending in the Engineering Student Community You're invited! Join the ASME FutureME LinkedIn Group Join Now â†’ ASME is excited to announce that we have just launched the ASME FutureME LinkedIn Group! This group will provide you a richer and more stream-lined way to receive updates from the FutureME and E-Fest communities, access engineering content and resources, and connect and interact with other students and early career engineers like yourself. We encourage you to join and take advantage of the following benefits: â€¢ Be the first to receive information and updates on all ASME student and early career initiatives including events, competitions, social meet-ups, Mini-Talks and more! â€¢ Gain access to exclusive content, specifically tailored to engineers with 0-10 years of work experience, on career advancement and professional development including case studies, whitepapers, videos, infographics and more. â€¢ Start conversations and interact with students and early career engineers to share experiences as an undergraduate or graduate student and within the workforce, gain insights into career path planning, and get tips on how to advance and succeed professionally. â€¢ Connect with ASME leadership and staff to learn about exciting opportunities to get involved with the Society through student and professional sections, events and programs. Join Now â†’ Sponsored Ad 500+ Papers and Presentations Explore how your peers are making advances in new product development and research through multiphysics simulation in this open-access resource with over 500 papers, posters, and presentations from COMSOL Conference 2019. More Information â†’ WEBINAR: A Day in the Life of an ME working at Raytheon Date: Wednesday, May 27, 2020 Time: 1:00 PM EST Ever wondered what it's like to work as a mechanical engineer for the world's top defense, civil government and cybersecurity Company? subject: Lung Simulation Model Guide Ventilator Design
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Top 3 Drawbacks of Exceeding Power Supply 05.21.2020 7 Questions with Zohaib Mian on the Future of Data Networks Loon is a company looking to revolutionize how we build our data networks. They use tennis-court-sized, solar-powered satellite balloons to deliver wireless internet signal over a remote location. ASME.org recently spoke with Zohaib Mian, the head of systems engineering at Loon, about how Loon is achieving its goals of ushering a new era of data connectivity. Sponsored Ad Computational Lung Model May Guide How Ventilators are Used Patients with lung disease who are placed on a ventilator for long periods can suffer further damage from the ventilator. A new computational lung model uses data and a CT scan to map a patient's unique tissue, identify damaged areas, and calculate strains placed on the lung's microlevel tissues by different ventilator settings. This will allow doctors to determine the optimal setting, preventing further damage. Sponsored Ad Connecting Emergency Response Structures The COVID crisis is driving efforts for temporary response buildings made from converted shipping containers. This includes mobile hospitals or isolation dorms that may need to be connected via a bellows passageway to reduce the number of doors exposed to the environment. This helps manage climate control and sustain clean, sterile environments. Read more > Sponsored Content What Are the Top 3 Drawbacks of Exceeding a Power Supply's Input Voltage? To answer,What if I operate a power supply outside of its specification range?" CUI has reviewed common power supply specifications and outlined the drawbacks that occur when operating a power supply outside of its specified limits. New Device Helps Human Livers Regenerate Many donor livers are too damaged to transplant within the few hours they can be kept alive. A new medical device now keeps human livers alive for up to one weekâ€”long enough for them to heal and regenerate new liverâ€”by simulating the function of other organs within the human body. L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future

subject: Multiphysics Simulation of Hyperloop Pod Design at EPFL
body: Multiphysics Simulation of Hyperloop Pod Design at EPFL Inspiring Young Engineers to Design for the Future Inspiring Young Engineers to Design for the Future View in your browser Multiphysics Simulation of Hyperloop Pod Design at EPFL EPFLoop, one of the top three teams invited to the 2018 SpaceX Hyperloop Pod Competition, used multiphysics simulation to design their hyperloop pod. Building a high-speed magnetically levitated pod for speeds exceeding 300 mph in near vacuum posed a formidable design challenge. The EPFL team turned to the COMSOL MultiphysicsÂ® simulation software to develop several components of their pod. Check out the EPFLoop hyperloop pod design here: http://comsol.com/c/akz2 For more examples of multiphysics simulation, check out COMSOL News: http://comsol.com/c/alhe 052120 - 19882 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: ASME Journal of Medical Devices - Call for Papers: Special Issue on Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces
body: ASME Journal of Mechanical Design DEADLINE EXTENDED - CALL FOR PAPERS Connect with us: ASME's Guide for Journal Authors Submit Your Manuscript â†’ CALL FOR PAPERS ASME Journal of Medical Devices Special Issue on Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces Significant advances have been made in the field of medical robotics in recent decades. Spanning series and parallel robotic architectures, rigid and soft materials, and a variety of control approaches, the potential for robotic applications in medicine remains vast. As the technologies underlying robotic solutions continue to mature and develop, new robotic medical applications will continue to emerge. A related area of growing interest is the interaction between human operators and robotic medical devices. Without appropriate and user-friendly interfaces, the uses of these technologies are limited. Haptic devices are an example of the profound effect that interface devices can have on practical functionality and applicability of technology in medical applications. The focus of this Special Issue is the intersection of medical robotics and human interfaces for medical applications. Topic Areas â€¢ Kinematics & dynamics for medical robotics â€¢ Exoskeletons & prostheses â€¢ Humanoid & service robots â€¢ Assistive robots & elderly assistance â€¢ Surgical robots â€¢ Human-robot interfaces â€¢ Haptic devices â€¢ Medical treatments using robotics & automation Publication Target Dates Paper submission deadline: September 15, 2020 Initial reviews completed: October 15, 2020 Special Issue publication date: March 2021 Submission Instructions Papers should be submitted electronically to the journal at journaltool.asme.org. If you already have an account, log in as author and select Submit Paper at the bottom of the page. If you do not have an account, select Submissions and follow the steps. In either case, at the Paper Submittal page, select the ASME Journal of Medical Devices and then select the Special Issue Medical Robotics and Human Interfaces. Papers received after the deadline or papers not selected for inclusion in the Special Issue may be accepted for publication in a regular issue. Special Issue Guest Editors Med Amine Laribi, PhD, Associate Professor, Institut PPRIME, DÃ©partement GÃ©nie MÃ©canique et SystÃ¨mes Complexes, CNRS, University of Poitiers, Poitiers, France med.amine.laribi@univ-poitiers.fr Carl Nelson, PhD, Professor, Mechanical and Materials Engineering, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE, USA cnelson5@unl.edu Nandini Duraiswamy, PhD, Biomedical Engineer, US Food and Drug Administration, Silver Spring, MD, USA Nandini.Duraiswamy@fda.hhs.gov The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® (ASMEÂ®) 052120 - 20521 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Finding New Solutions to Old Problems
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter Johnson & Johnson Places Big Bet on 3D Printing 05.22.2020 Infographic: Are Rideshares Taking Over the Streets? Are Uber drivers clogging the roads in your city? Are they creating more pollution as they cruise around waiting for calls? Recent research on ridesharing may surprise you. Workforce Blog: Finding New Solutions to Old Problems We've learned new lessons since the traumatic coronavirus pandemic stripped us of some of our freedoms, and by now we've adapted to thinking and behaving differently. Going back to the same old normal may just not be quite the same. J&J Places a Big Bet on 3D Printing From bandages and beauty products to pharmaceuticals and surgical implants, Johnson & Johnson is one of the world's largest healthcare companies. Now, it is looking to use additive manufacturing to transform all its business. In an exclusive interview, Sam Onukuri explains how J&J hopes to do this. Sponsored Ad The Electrical Components of the Self-Driving Car The scaling of autonomous vehicles will be intertwined with the ramping up of electric vehicles. Due to the easier integration of electrical components, self-driving cars will be easier to manufacture in electric models than traditional gas vehicles. subject: Interactive Sessions to Be Featured at AM Medical Virtual Summit
body: ASME News May 22, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 10 / May 22, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 10 / May 22, 2020 Interactive Sessions to Be Featured at AM Medical Virtual Summit On May 27, ASME will present its first AM Medical Virtual Summit: Additive Manufacturing & 3D Innovations, an online event on the latest advances in additive manufacturing (AM) and 3D printing for medical applications. The free event will take place from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Eastern Time. Read more Sponsored Ad Extend Bearing Life Single Turn Wave Springs are ideal for bearing preload. Preloading the bearing through its outer race takes up play in the bearing. This reduces bearing damage, wear, noise, and vibration. Request free samples today. Learn more â†’ ASME Today and Tomorrow Podcast: How ASME Is Adapting to COVID-19 In the latest installment of the ASME Today and Tomorrow podcast, CEO/Executive Director Tom Costabile is joined by the Societyâ€™s Executive Management Team to discuss the many ways that ASME is adapting and responding to the unique challenges posed by the COVID-19 global pandemic. Learn more Sponsored Ad Webinar Offers Members a Look at the Work of an Engineer at Raytheon On May 27, ASME will offer the latest installment in its â€œA Day in the Lifeâ€ webinar series, which examines the day-to-day activities of engineers who work at innovative companies. The webinar, which is free for ASME members, will feature an engineer employed at Raytheon, the leading international defense, civil government and cybersecurity company. Read more Sponsored Ad Special Journal Issue to Explore Design Engineering in the Age of Industry 4.0 The ASME Journal of Mechanical Design is currently accepting manuscripts for a special issue focusing on the topic â€œDesign Engineering in the Age of Industry 4.0.â€ Authors who are interested in having their papers included in the special issue, to be published in May 2021, should submit their manuscripts by Aug. 31, 2020. Read more Sponsored Ad Learn from Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses, so be sure to check out our discounted course list. Learn more Sponsored Ad Yonggang Huang ASME member Yonggang Huang, Ph.D., the chair of the ASME Applied Mechanics Division and editor of the ASME Journal of Applied Mechanics, was recently elected as a member of both the National Academy of Sciences (NAS) and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences (AAAS). The Walter P. Murphy Professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering and Mechanical Engineering at Northwestern University, Huangâ€™s research is focused on deterministic 3D assembly and the development of models for stretchable and flexible electronics. Learn more â†’ Assad Oberai ASME member Assad Oberai, Ph.D., the Hughes Professor of Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering and interim vice dean at the Viterbi School of Engineering at the University of Southern California, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. Dr. Oberai was recognized for his long-term contributions to the field of computational mechanics. He leads the Computation and Data Driven Discovery (CD3) group at USC, which designs, implements and applies data- and physics-based models and algorithms for a variety of applications. The webinar, which is free for ASME members, will feature an engineer employed at Raytheon, the leading international defense, civil government and cybersecurity company. Read more Sponsored Ad Special Journal Issue to Explore Design Engineering in the Age of Industry 4.0 The ASME Journal of Mechanical Design is currently accepting manuscripts for a special issue focusing on the topic â€œDesign Engineering in the Age of Industry 4.0.â€ Authors who are interested in having their papers included in the special issue, to be published in May 2021, should submit their manuscripts by Aug. 31, 2020. Read more Sponsored Ad Learn from Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. We are now offering discounts on select courses, so be sure to check out our discounted course list. Learn more Sponsored Ad Yonggang Huang ASME member Yonggang Huang, Ph.D., the chair of the ASME Applied Mechanics Division and editor of the ASME Journal of Applied Mechanics, was recently elected as a member of both the National Academy of Sciences (NAS) and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences (AAAS). The Walter P. Murphy Professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering and Mechanical Engineering at Northwestern University, Huangâ€™s research is focused on deterministic 3D assembly and the development of models for stretchable and flexible electronics. Learn more â†’ Assad Oberai ASME member Assad Oberai, Ph.D., the Hughes Professor of Aerospace and Mechanical Engineering and interim vice dean at the Viterbi School of Engineering at the University of Southern California, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. Dr. Oberai was recognized for his long-term contributions to the field of computational mechanics. He leads the Computation and Data Driven Discovery (CD3) group at USC, which designs, implements and applies data- and physics-based models and algorithms for a variety of applications. Learn more â†’ Your Email Preferences Events Calendar ASME Membership ASME Foundation Sections & Divisions Engineering for Change (E4C) Capitol Update Obituaries The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Top 10 Innovative Engineering Universities
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Is Simulation-Driven Design Feasible? 05.26.2020 Video: Top 10 Innovative Engineering Universities Mechanical Engineering magazine list 10 engineering educational institutions that are advancing the engineering education model. These programs foster collaboration between engineering disciplines, advocate STEM education, and focus on the innovative future of technology. Sponsored Ad Simulation-Driven Design: Feasible or Fallacy? Making simulation part of the design processâ€“from the start rather than at the endâ€”accelerates design cycles and frees engineers to test more creative solutions. There are several different ways to implement this technology. Which is right for you? QUIZ: What Do You Know About the Apollo Spacesuit? When the United States set out to send humans to the moon, it needed a new kind of pressurized suit to allow astronauts to work in the vacuum of space. How much do you know about Apolloâ€™s out-of-the-world spacesuit? The main contractor for the Apollo spacesuit was International Latex Corporation (ILC) of Dover, Del. What commercial product was ILC famous for? Spalding basketballs London Fog raincoats Astroturf outdoor carpet Playtex bras and girdles L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. subject: SpaceX's Crew Dragon Demo-2 Mission
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Video Special Report on the Future of 4D Printing 05.28.2020 Robot Applications-in-a-Box Robot vendors have spent years making it easier to integrate components with their robots. Now they are taking the next step: applications-in-a-box that get robots up and runningâ€”and performing usefulâ€”and often complicated-work like machine tending and finishing within hours. Sponsored Ad SpaceX's Crew Dragon Liftoff NASA astronauts Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley liftoff to the International Space Station on NASA's SpaceX Demo-2 mission. The Demo-2 mission will be a culmination of a decade-long effort by NASA to meet its goal of launching the first astronauts into orbit from the U.S. soil since the end of the shuttle program. Video: Embracing 4D Printing 4D-printed healthcare applications may be the closest to commercial applications. Shape-shifting materials, for instance, could be used for small, implantable medical devices. In this video we take a closer look at how 3D printing is building a foundation for 4D development in biomedical applications. Learning and Development for Engineers Advances and breakthroughs in the field of engineering are accelerating at breakneck speeds. The demand for continuous improvement has never been greater. ASME is at work building lifelong learning experiences that engineers and their employers can rely on to form and foster critical competencies, expertise, and credentials. L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. subject: Improving the Resiliency of the Electrical Grid
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter How Do We Reboot After COVID-19? 06.02.2020 Engineering Ways to Improve Electrical Grid Resilience Utilities have lots of practice repairing lines downed by fallen trees. But when widespread or unusual calamities strike, they look to ways to make the grid less likely to break. Mechanical Engineering's special report on energy focuses on the resilience of the electrical grid. Rebooting After the Pandemic: A talk with ASME's CEO Rebooting After the Pandemic is a six-part special series that brings together top engineers, scientists, and futurists to discuss the role that technology plays in rebooting the critical industrial ecosystems, post COVID-19. Mechanical Engineering speaks with ASME Executive Director & CEO Thomas Costabile, a leading technology evangelist and thought leader, on what it will take to move forward. 7 Top Applications of Lasers in Manufacturing Lasers are one of the most widely used tools in manufacturing and can create fine features that are difficult or impossible to make using traditional machining equipment. Laser applications include laser marking, surface texturing, ablation, drilling, cutting, welding, and wire stripping. L&D COURSES 4 Additive Manufacturing Design Courses for The Price Of 1 When you register for ASME's Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Professional Package you'll have access to our Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals course and three additional case study courses covering the concepts in our Replicate, Adapt, Optimize framework. Get your discount code and save over $3,000. Learn from Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. Get discounts of up to 75% on select eLearning courses. FREE WEBINAR Digital Reliability 24/7 Real-time Machinery Diagnostics June 8 | 11 am ET This webinar will provide examples of how COMPACS represents a paradigm shift from sudden equipment failures to an environment of early detection and identification of issues. subject: Gun-Wielding Drone to Plant Trees
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Listen on How to Build Resilience Into the Electrical Grid 06.04.2020 Negative Pressure Helmet Becomes Respirator to Protect Healthcare Workers Keeping a virus contained is key. Now a professor of mechanical engineering at the University of Michigan has created an air-sucking helmet to prevent viruses from leaving a patient and infecting a room. And to think, the idea came from a greeting card. Sponsored Ad ASME TechCast-Episode 31: Building Resilience into the Electrical Grid Electric grid operators are focused on resiliency more now than ever before. ASME's Carlos GonzÃ¡lez talks with Mike Bryson from PJM and Nirmal Paudel from ABB about the steps their companies are taking to ensure that the lights stay on no matter what. Gun-Wielding Drone Plants Trees In an effort to urgently regenerate ecosystems and automate reforestation, a Canadian startup has created a drone that fires rapidly germinating tree seeds into the soil. Using mapping software and other automated tech, Flash Forest is planning to monitor and continuously improve its tree-planting system. Sponsored Ad QUIZ: Historical X-Planes Flying Innovations NASA's X-plane program introduced aviation innovation that created new technology features such as vertical takeoff, supersonic flight, and multi-propeller aircraft. Test your knowledge on historical X-planes. The Bell X-1 was the first X-plane ever designed. Built by Bell Aircraft, the aircraft was able to achieve a high velocity due to its rocket engine. The plane was piloted by Chuck Yeager and exceeded speeds of 1,600 miles per hour. What milestone did the X-1 achieve? First crewed airplane to exceed the speed of sound in level flight. First crewed airplane to be entirely controlled via remote First crewed airplane to fly at 50,000 feet before the Concorde. First crewed airplane to fly on electric power. L&D COURSES Learn From Home with ASME As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. Get discounts of up to 75% on select eLearning courses. 4 Additive Manufacturing Design Courses for The Price Of 1 When you register for ASME's Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Professional Package you'll have access to our Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals course and three additional case study courses covering the concepts in our Replicate, Adapt, Optimize framework. Get your discount code and save over $3,000. FREE WEBINAR Stepping Up Design with Surface-to-Surface Radiation June 11 | 2pm ET In this webinar, you will learn some of the theory behind thermal radiation, when thermal radiation needs to be considered, and how it can be included in heat transfer simulations in COMSOL MultiphysicsÂ®. subject: New Workplaces After COVID-19
body: ASME TechDesign - ME Magazine Newsletter TBDHistorical Inventors' Hall of Fame Inductees 06.05.2020 Manufacturing Blog: Engineers Needed to Fill AI Tool Gaps AI tools like generative design and topology optimization can generate designs automaticallyâ€“but without highly trained engineers, they cannot yet deliver useable results. Here are some specific applications where human ingenuity makes artificial intelligence work. Sponsored Ad Historical Inventors' Hall of Fame The National Inventors Hall of Fame's Class of 2020 includes historical inductees whose inventions transformed their fields. These famous inventors designed new paradigm-shifting technical marvels that created more efficient processes and improved society. Workforce Blog: Engineering the New Workplace After the Pandemic Three engineers who are deeply knowledgeable about indoor air quality, the flow of air in interior spaces, and the spread of infection through buildings reveal what steps can be taken to make offices and schools safer places to work during the COVID-19 pandemic. Sponsored Ad Infographic: The Unintended Consequences of Germany's Nuclear Phase-Out When Germany began phasing out its nuclear plants, it was prompted by safety concerns. But a recent study estimates that by keeping coal- and lignite-fired power plants running, the phase-out has killed more than a thousand Germans each year. Save over 75% on this new 4-course eLearning solution. subject: Super Powers to Smart Wearables
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Prevent Corrosion on Insulated Materials 06.09.2020 Sponsored Content Infographic: Exploring the Mechanism and Longevity of the XOX Corrosion Inhibitor Johns Manville infographic helps engineers to understand better how insulation with corrosion-inhibiting properties can limit corrosion by forming a protective surface layer, which does not disappear over repeated wet/dry exposures. Utilizing these findings can be the first step in building a comprehensive corrosion mitigation strategy. Sponsored Ad Adding Super Powers to Wearable Smart Devices Researchers at the University of Washington are seeking new capabilities for the next generation of computing platformsâ€”particularly a smart device that enhances gaming experiences could also be integrated into fitness bracelets for biomedical applications. Quiz:Technological Advances in World War II Engineering and science have impacted how warfare is conducted since antiquity. Many of today's technology and products are founded on developments used during World War II, which ended 75 years ago. See what you know about the technology developed during World War II. RADAR was in its infancy at the beginning of World War II and is credited with giving Great Britain an advantage during the Battle of Britain. Where was it first developed? The U.S. Great Britain Germany Hungary FREE WEBINAR Stepping Up Design with Surface-to-Surface Radiation June 11 | 2 pm ET In this webinar, you will learn some of the theory behind thermal radiation, when thermal radiation needs to be considered, and how it can be included in heat transfer simulations in COMSOL MultiphysicsÂ®. subject: Bionic Prosthetics for Extreme Sports
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Simulation Revolutionizes Additive Manufacturing 06.11.2020 Smarter, Safer Lung Ventilator Ventilators provide life-saving breath to critically ill patients, but may injure lungs and even cause death. A new technique, multi-frequency oscillatory ventilation, uses short, high-speed pulses of air to reduce injury and enable each region of the lung to use gas at the rate and capacity it needs. Sponsored Ad Sponsored Content MTC Develops Simulation App to Revolutionize Design for AM Parts The Manufacturing Technology Centre (MTC) in Coventry, UK, researches additive manufacturing techniques and supplies designs and prototypes to part producers in the industry. To verify the quality and performance of their additively manufactured parts, the MTC employs multiphysics simulation software for virtual design testing, validation, and performance prediction. Video: Bionic Prosthetic for Extreme Sports For Mike Schultz, Paralympic and X-Games athlete, the prosthetics available to him weren't enough. With the help of the Center for Advanced Design, Schultz turned his focus from extreme sports to bioengineering and created a prosthetic capable of performing for extreme sports competition. Sponsored Ad Finance is the Invisible Hand Driving Energy Policy Engineers typically believe we have the answer to everything, and that better technology is the path to a better future. But look at the major revolutions in energy and mobility, and you'll see another force playing a bigger role than most of us realize: finance. FREE WEBINAR Additive Manufacturing Meets Miniaturization July 29 | 2pm ET In this webinar, you will learn about PÂµSL and how it's a game changer for printing small parts with unparalleled accuracy as well as why PÂµSL is a game changer in electrical, medical, MEMS and microfluidic applications. subject: Check out ASME's A112.6.3 Floor and Trench Drains standard webinar
body: New edition of Floor and Trench Drains standard Connect with us: Explore key updates in this latest edition Explore the new edition of ASME's A112.6.3 Floor and Trench Drain standard at our upcoming webinar. You'll learn about: â€¢ The many drain types that are included â€¢ A variety of drain material types and coatings covered along with associated tests â€¢ Bolts, fasteners, weep holes and other important areas â€¢ New requirements for perimeter drains, aluminum sand castings and for determining the area of grate openings In addition, we'll touch on some key updates, including a chart on body thickness specification for each drain material along with amendments we'll cover in future editions. Sign up today by clicking here. And if youâ€™re ready to buy the standard, purchase the Floor and Trench Drains standard below or by simply clicking here. Floor and Trench Drains (A112.6.3) ASME's latest Floor and Trench Drains Standard educates professionals on adjustable floor and trench drains that are used inside of, or outside and immediately adjacent to, building structures. Price: $56 Share our floor and trench drains standard and upcoming webinar with colleagues and friends: If you have any comments or questions, please contact Mr. Angel Guzman Rodriguez (GuzmanA@asme.org). Abraham Murra Principal, Abraham Murra Consulting Abraham Murra has close to 18 years of experience in leading North American conformity assessment and standards development organizations (i.e., CSA and IAPMO). In 2002, he joined CSA as Project Manager in the Built Environment Program, where he managed 16 national and bi-national committees of more than 300 professional volunteers for developing and maintaining technical standards for plumbing products. Some of the subjects covered by the standards developed by those committees were plumbing fittings and fixtures, piping, backflow preventers, water conservation, water reuse, and decentralized (onsite) wastewater systems. Robert Burnham Code Compliance Lead Engineer, Zurn Industries LLC Robert Burnham is a Mechanical Engineering graduate of Trine University (formerly Tri-State University), in Angola IN. Shortly after graduating, he began working at Zurn Industries in Erie Pennsylvania. Over the past 17 plus years Robert has held various roles within Zurn including Test Engineer, Product Engineer, and most recently Code Compliance Lead. In his current role, Robert oversees the Erie Test Lab as well as all things Compliance related for the Spec. Drain portion of the Zurn business. He has been active in the plumbing standards community since 2013. The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) 20633 - 061120 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Latest ISHOW Kenya Spotlights Social Entrepreneurs
body: ASME News June 12, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 11 / June 12, 2020 Vol. 39 No. 11 / June 15, 2020 Social Entrepreneurs Recognized at Latest ASME ISHOW Kenya Last month, the creators of three innovative products developed to benefit society â€” an affordable solar-powered cook stove, a sanitary pad dispenser system for schools, and a smartphone technology for detecting and diagnosing malaria â€” were selected as the winners of the ASME Innovation Showcase (ISHOW) Kenya. Read more Sponsored Ad Accidents. What if one happened to you? Would your family have the financial resources to survive the crisis? Secure up to $500,000 for yourself in Group Accidental Death & Dismemberment Insurance protection through the ASME Insurance Program for just 67Â¢ a day. Enroll now â†’ Mechanical Engineering Magazine Presents â€œRebooting After the Pandemicâ€ Webinars Through June ASMEâ€™s Mechanical Engineering magazine launches a new webinar series that explores the impact of technology on a post-COVID-19 world. Read more Sponsored Ad Virtual Town Hall Addresses Pandemic and Other Pressing Issues Furthering its government relations outreach despite ongoing coronavirus-related closures in Washington, D.C., ASME recently convened a dynamic town hall discussion featuring Congresswoman Haley Stevens (MI-11), who sits on the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology. Read more Sponsored Ad Deadline Extended for Submissions to New ASME Journal Researchers interested in submitting a manuscript for the new ASME Journal of Autonomous Vehicles and Systems now have an extra few weeks to do so. The deadline to submit a paper to be considered for the new journal has been extended until July 1, 2020. Read more Sponsored Ad Abstracts Due Soon for NSF Poster Competition Abstracts are now being accepted for the National Science Foundation (NSF) Student Poster Competition at the ASME 2020 International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition (IMECE 2020), to be held this November in Portland, Ore. Read more Sponsored Ad Bo Chen ASME member Bo Chen, Ph.D., the Dave House Professor at Michigan Technological University, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. Dr. Chen conducts interdisciplinary research in the areas of mechatronics and embedded systems, agent technology, modeling and control of hybrid electric vehicles, cyber-physical systems, and automation. Her research interests include modeling and control of hybrid electric vehicles; electric vehicle-smart grid integration; distributed monitoring and control; battery control for HEV and energy storage systems; internal combustion engine management systems; and sensor information fusion. Learn more â†’ Roger Fales ASME member Roger Fales, Ph.D., an associate professor in the mechanical and aerospace engineering department and the director of Student Success in the College of Engineering at the University of Missouri, was recently named a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. Dr. Fales was recognized for his â€œsignificant contributions to research, education and leadership in the engineering profession, resulting in over 50 publications on the topics of robust control, hydraulics, and modeling and control of oxygen for premature infants,â€ according to the Fellow citation. subject: 7 Ways COVID-19 May Change Our World
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Top Drawbacks of Exceeding a Power Supply's Input Voltage 06.16.2020 A Vortex of Sound for a Single Cell It turns out that the best tool to test the strength and elasticity of a cell could be sound waves. A team of researchers at the UniversitÃ© de Lille in France together with colleagues from the Sorbonne in Paris have created acoustic tweezers that use a vortex of sound to isolate single particles for precise manipulation. Sponsored Ad Sponsored Content What Are the Top 3 Drawbacks of Exceeding a Power Supply's Input Voltage? What if I operate a power supply outside of its specification range?" CUI has reviewed common power supply specifications and outlined the drawbacks that occur when operating a power supply outside of its specified limits. subject: Four Ways Technology Moves Art
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Intercepting Water Plastic Pollution 06.18.2020 Giving Design Jobs to Machines Researchers at several universities are pushing the frontiers of machine learning into the realms of engineering design. The Iowa State group seeks to use machine learning to speed up the engineering design process for boosting solar cell performance. Sponsored Ad Sponsored Content Magnetic Transmissions Increase Lifespan of Offshore Wind Farms Whether it is a wind turbine or a wristwatch, the transmission of rotational power is important for various technological applications. Mechanical transmission has inherent limitations, including wear and overload, because of the continual contact. At Sintex, multiphysics simulation is used to develop and analyze non-contact magnetic couplings. Four Ways Technology Moves Art In the 21st century, artists are using lasers and facial recognition technology to create interactive light displays, virtual reality for immersive experiences and even artificial intelligence and algorithms to create computer-generated art. Sponsored Ad Intercepting Water Plastic Pollution It's a futile task to clean the oceans from plastic waste without tackling the source of the problem. So the Dutch non-profit The Ocean Cleanup has turned its attention upstream, to the rivers that send the debris to the sea. The solar-powered barge called the Interceptor with its boom and conveyor belt system plucks the garbage right out of the water. FREE WEBINAR Additive Manufacturing Meets Miniaturization July 29 | 2pm ET In this webinar, you will learn about PÂµSL and how it's a game changer for printing small parts with unparalleled accuracy as well as why PÂµSL is a game changer in electrical, medical, MEMS and microfluidic applications. L&D COURSES Learn Piping Design at Home Reliance on software without a fundamental understanding of the underlying principles of engineering has become a common industry issue. subject: How to Address Job Burnout
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter How Well Do You Know the Hubble? 06.19.2020 A Robot for the Tiniest Surgeries Microsurgery requires some very precise and painstaking movements on the part of a surgeon. But now there's a robot to help take some of the painstaking out of the procedure. Called Musa, it is now performing the first robotic microsurgeries. Sponsored Ad The Future of IoT and STEM with IBM's Lisa Seacat DeLuca Mechanical Engineering recently interviewed Lisa Seacat DeLuca, IBM Watson's director of IoT, about the future of IBM's IoT goals, how STEM is vital to the future of engineering, and how her works in children's literature were inspired by her want to provide STEM awareness to her children. Job Burnout is Real: Learn How to Address It Job burnout is pretty common recognizing and addressing the underlying issues behind it could lead to positive career outcomes. There are no quick fixes but here are three ways to recognize burnout and five ways to address it. Sponsored Ad Quiz: What do you know about the Hubble Space Telescope? Everyone has seen the stunning images beamed down from the Hubble Space Telescope, but how much do you know about the telescope itself? Test your knowledge with this ASME quiz! The Hubble Space Telescope wasn't the first telescope in space. Aside from its size, what made the HST different than its predecessors? It was the first to send back digital images rather than exposed film It was the first to use mirrors rather than lenses It was the first to see in visible light It was the first designed to be maintained by astronauts FREE WEBINAR Predicting Vibration and Noise in HVAC and Automotive Systems August 6 | 2pm ET Tune into this live webinar to hear from Jin Liu of Carrier Corporation, who will share her experience helping engineers reduce radiated noise in HVAC and automotive systems by adjusting the acoustic impedance in their pipes and cavities using multiphysics simulation. L&D COURSES Four Additive Manufacturing Design Courses for the Price of One When you register for ASME's Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Professional Package you'll have access to our Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals course and three additional case study courses covering the concepts in our Replicate, Adapt, Optimize framework. Get your discount code and save over 80%. Learn from Home As the global engineering community transitions to the eLearning space for the foreseeable future, ASME has got you covered. subject: Sign up for ASME's upcoming A112.6.3 Floor and Trend Drain standard webinar
body: New edition of Floor and Trench Drains standard Connect with us: Register today to learn about key new requirements in ASME's A112.6.3 Floor and Trench Drains standard Explore the new edition of ASME's A112.6.3 Floor and Trench Drain standard at our upcoming webinar. Learn about key updates from the team who worked on the new edition and get any questions you may have answered. We'll cover a number of important requirements, including: â€¢ Bolts and fasteners â€¢ Weep holes â€¢ Trap primers In addition, we'll go over different drain outlets, including threaded, inside caulk, outside caulk, spigot and gasket connections. ASME A112.6.3 - 2019 Floor and Trench Drains Date: Tuesday, June 30, 2020 Time: 11:00 AM Eastern Daylight Time Sign up today by clicking here. And if you're ready to buy the Floor and Trench Drains standard, you can purchase it below or by simply clicking here. Floor and Trench Drains (A112.6.3) ASME's latest Floor and Trench Drains Standard educates professionals on adjustable floor and trench drains that are used inside of, or outside and immediately adjacent to, building structures. Price: $56 Share our floor and trench drains standard and upcoming webinar with colleagues and friends: If you have any comments or questions, please contact Mr. Angel Guzman Rodriguez (GuzmanA@asme.org). ABOUT THE PRESENTERAbraham Murra Principal, Abraham Murra Consulting Abraham Murra has close to 18 years of experience in leading North American conformity assessment and standards development organizations (i.e., CSA and IAPMO). In 2002, he joined CSA as Project Manager in the Built Environment Program, where he managed 16 national and bi-national committees of more than 300 professional volunteers for developing and maintaining technical standards for plumbing products. Some of the subjects covered by the standards developed by those committees were plumbing fittings and fixtures, piping, backflow preventers, water conservation, water reuse, and decentralized (onsite) wastewater systems. ABOUT THE PRESENTERRobert Burnham Code Compliance Lead Engineer, Zurn Industries LLC Robert Burnham is a Mechanical Engineering graduate of Trine University (formerly Tri-State University), in Angola IN. Shortly after graduating, he began working at Zurn Industries in Erie Pennsylvania. Over the past 17 plus years Robert has held various roles within Zurn including Test Engineer, Product Engineer, and most recently Code Compliance Lead. In his current role, Robert oversees the Erie Test Lab as well as all things Compliance related for the Spec. Drain portion of the Zurn business. He has been active in the plumbing standards community since 2013. The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) 20636 - 062320 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: A Drone Jet Fighter on the Rise
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter 10 Applications for Nanotechnology 06.23.2020 Video: How Industrial Countries Invest in Robotics Governments in major industrial countries invest over $1 billion annually in robotics research. The International Federation of Robotics reports artificial intelligence, Big Data, and 5G are the main drivers of government-sponsored research into robotics in China, Japan, South Korea, the European Union, and the United States. Sponsored Ad Drone Jet Fighter on the Rise Military drones have long been used for reconnaissance and bombing. Now, Boeing Australia is building a drone capable of running with fighter jets. Its primary missions will include reconnaissance, intelligence, and early warning, but Boeing is not revealing whether it will also carry weapons. Infographic: 10 Applications of Nanotechnology Nanotechnology is used to revolutionize many industry sectors: electronics, energy, material science, medicine, transportation, transportation, and environmental science, to name a few. Here are 10 applications that impact our daily life. Sponsored Ad WEBINARS ASME Virtual Town Hall with U.S. Representative Kathleen Rice June 24 | 2pm ET Join ASME's Managing Director of Global Public Affairs, John Hasselmann, for a Town Hall with U.S. Representative Kathleen Rice (NY-04) for a conversation on the engineering community's response to the COVID-19 pandemic and economic recovery efforts underway in Congress. ASME Congressional Briefing on Global Manufacturing Supply Chains June 25 | 1pm ET As manufacturers struggled to source the supplies and equipment needed for production during the COVID-19 pandemic, an understanding arose that implementation of new safeguards and frameworks are essential to strengthening our supply chain. Join us to hear from experts on the work being done to integrate the latest technologies and revamp the supply chain into a more robust and agile infrastructure moving forward. subject: How to make the most of a virtual job fair
body: ASME E-Fests How to make the most of a virtual job fair What's Trending in the Engineering Student Community Innovate. Create. Compete. Celebrate. ASME E-FESTSÂ® NEWS Whatâ€™s Trending in the Engineering Student Community Making the Most of a Virtual Job Fair Practicing social distancing and looking for a job â€“without leaving your homeâ€“is possible, thanks to virtual career fairs. Here are eight steps to make the most of them. Full Article â†’ What Is Taking So Long to Hear Back After an Interview? You had job interviews at a place you'd like to work. The interviews seemed to go well. Maybe one of the interviewers said they looked forward to working with you. But, not a word from them since then. What is going on? Full Article â†’ How to Avoid Spam Filters When Emailing Your Resume Don't assume that your resume and emails will be received by the intended recipient, particularly the first message you send to someone who doesn't know you or who isn't expecting a message from you. Learn about seven steps you can take to avoid spam filters which might stand in the way of your dream job. Full Article â†’ Have questions? We're here to help! subject: How Well Do You Know the International Space Station?
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter New Standards for Nonmetallic Pressure Piping 06.25.2020 Bioengineering Blog: Simulation Does Not Replace Physical Testing Simulation is not meant to be a replacement for all physical testing in medical devices. Prototypes, bench tests, preclinical labs and clinical studies are not replaced by modeling and simulation, but when used side by side they become more efficient at reaching project goals. Sponsored Ad New Standard Simplifies Nonmetallic Pressure Piping Projects A new generation of plastic pipes is challenging metal in pressure piping. Yet despite plastic's performance advantages, many engineers hesitate to specify it. A new set of standards from ASME should simplify everything, from materials selection to installation. Quiz: How Well Do You Know the International Space Station? On May 30, two engineers aboard the SpaceX Crew Dragon flew from Kennedy Space Center to the International Space Station. It was the first commercial flight to the ISS, which is the most expensive structure ever built. Test your knowledge of the ISS with this quiz. It took 16 nations to construct and launch the ISS in 1998. Which of the following nations was not part of that effort? Spain Brazil China Belgium Sponsored Ad WEBINAR LGBTQ Pride Town Hall with Boeing Senior Manager June 25 | 5pm ET Join the co-chairs of ASME's LGBTQ Pride initiative for a virtual town hall with Boeing engineer Jacky-Vy Chau. He serves as senior manager for electrical design and has been a key member of Boeing's LGBTQ inclusion community. He will discuss his background, his work with Boeing, and the importance of diversity and inclusion during this historic Pride Month. subject: Last chance to sign up for ASME's A112.6.3 Floor and Trench Drain standard webinar
body: New edition of Floor and Trench Drains standard Connect with us: Register today to learn about new grate area opening requirements in ASME's Floor and Trench Drains standard Don't miss your chance to directly connect with the developers of ASME's latest A112.6.3 Floor and Trench Drain standard at our upcoming webinar. You'll learn about new updates to grate area opening requirements and can get questions you have on the new edition answered. New requirements include: â€¢ Minimum openings area â€¢ Perpendicular projected area â€¢ Qualifiers for perimeter drain grate openings area calculation â€¢ Opening size for heel-resistant grates In addition, we'll touch on some other key reference data points such as minimum dimension specifications across different drain outlets. ASME A112.6.3 - 2019 Floor and Trench Drains Date: Tuesday, June 30, 2020 Time: 11:00 AM Eastern Daylight Time Sign up today by clicking here. And if you're ready to buy the Floor and Trench Drains standard, you can purchase it below or by simply clicking here. Floor and Trench Drains (A112.6.3) ASME's latest Floor and Trench Drains Standard educates professionals on adjustable floor and trench drains that are used inside of, or outside and immediately adjacent to, building structures. Price: $56 Share our floor and trench drains standard and upcoming webinar with colleagues and friends: If you have any comments or questions, please contact Mr. Angel Guzman Rodriguez (GuzmanA@asme.org). ABOUT THE PRESENTERAbraham Murra Principal, Abraham Murra Consulting Abraham Murra has close to 18 years of experience in leading North American conformity assessment and standards development organizations (i.e., CSA and IAPMO). In 2002, he joined CSA as Project Manager in the Built Environment Program, where he managed 16 national and bi-national committees of more than 300 professional volunteers for developing and maintaining technical standards for plumbing products. Some of the subjects covered by the standards developed by those committees were plumbing fittings and fixtures, piping, backflow preventers, water conservation, water reuse, and decentralized (onsite) wastewater systems. ABOUT THE PRESENTERRobert Burnham Code Compliance Lead Engineer, Zurn Industries LLC Robert Burnham is a Mechanical Engineering graduate of Trine University (formerly Tri-State University), in Angola IN. Shortly after graduating, he began working at Zurn Industries in Erie Pennsylvania. Over the past 17 plus years Robert has held various roles within Zurn including Test Engineer, Product Engineer, and most recently Code Compliance Lead. In his current role, Robert oversees the Erie Test Lab as well as all things Compliance related for the Spec. Drain portion of the Zurn business. He has been active in the plumbing standards community since 2013. The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) 20637 - 062620 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Bryan Erler Becomes ASME's 139th President
body: ASME News June 26, 2020 New Members of the ASME Board of Governors Announced Vol. 39 No. 12 / June 29, 2020 Bryan Erler Becomes ASME's 139th President During a special Salute to Leadership event held at ASME's virtual Annual Meeting, Bryan Erler, P.E., became the 139th president of ASME. At the event, Mahantesh Hiremath, Ph.D., P.E. was also introduced as ASME's president-nominee for the 2021-2022 term and three new members of the ASME Board of Governors began their terms through 2023. Read more Sponsored Ad PE Mechanical CBT Courses Start Soon! Ensure you're ready and confident on exam day with a PPI Live Online or OnDemand Prep Course. PPI's expert instructors will guide you on how to navigate the new NCEES PE Mechanical Reference Handbook including an added focus on weighted topics. Increase your chances of passing the PE Mechanical exam and advancing your career, with PPI. Enroll now â†’ Inaugural AM Medical Virtual Summit Draws an Impressive Audience ASME's inaugural AM Medical Virtual Summit, held on May 27, 2020, brought together engineers, clinicians, technology vendors, and industry leaders in an immersive virtual event experience focused on medical additive manufacturing and innovative 3D printing for medical applications. The high number of participants exceeded all original expectations for the in-person event, making the virtual event an unqualified success. Read more Sponsored Ad Customized Precision Ball Screws Dynatect manufactures ground ball screws with high repeatability, offering customization and unique solutions not available from catalog suppliers, such as large-diameter (up to 6) and long-shaft (over 50 ft) ball screw assemblies. Full-service offering: new or replacement

subject: Making Robots Ubiquitous Post-Pandemic
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Mechanical Transmissions for Offshore Wind Farms 06.30.2020 Floating Metal Disks One of the more basic tenets of the universe is that metal sinks in water. Now, researchers at the University of Rochester have created a hydrophobic metal disk that is as buoyant as bubbles. Sponsored Ad Robotics Blog: Making Robots Ubiquitous Post-Pandemic From ensuring social distancing protocol to disinfecting rooms and delivering medicine as well as automating the production of personal protective equipment, we saw the emergence of mobile and autonomous service robots during the COVID-19 outbreak. How will hospitals, manufacturers, and supply chains use robots to scale-up operations quickly and into the future. Sponsored Ad New Navigator for 3D Printing Yaskawa CompassTM, a graphical user software package for 3D printing, shape cutting, machine tool and robotics, is designed to allow machine builders to brand and easily customize screens to include core machine attributes and customer needs with little programming requirements. Sponsored Content Magnetic Transmissions Increase Lifespan of Offshore Wind Farms Whether it is a wind turbine or a wristwatch, the transmission of rotational power is important for various technological applications. Mechanical transmission has inherent limitations, including wear and overload, because of the continual contact. At Sintex, multiphysics simulation is used to develop and analyze non-contact magnetic couplings. Sponsored Ad WEBINARS Predicting Vibration and Noise in HVAC and Automotive Systems August 6 | 2pm ET A common problem in HVAC systems and automotive systems is undesirable noise levels from pipes and cavities with internal pulsating pressures. How can engineers address this issue? L&D COURSES Get Four Additive Manufacturing Design Courses for the Price Of One When you register for ASME's Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Professional Package you'll have access to our Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals course and three additional project-based courses covering the concepts in our Replicate, Adapt, Optimize framework. subject: The Dream of Access to Water and Energy is Liberation
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Test Your Knowledge of the Historic Model T 07.02.2020 Podcast: Simplifying Nonmetallic Pressure Piping Systems Many companies have started to shift from metal to plastic piping for several high-pressure applications across a range of industries. In this podcast, Charles Henley, chief engineer, piping and material applications, Kiewit, discusses ASME's new standard that could help simplify nonmetallic pressure piping projects. Sponsored Ad Energy Blog: The Farm Woman's Dream, 100 Years Later American farm women 100 years ago and rural women in the global south today share the same dream: access to a modern water system and a modern energy system. Access to water and energy liberated the American farm woman, and so it would for the billion plus people around the world who do not have electricity or piped water today. QUIZ: Test Your Knowledge of The Historic Model T When Henry Ford invented the Model T, the bold innovations that followed was the foundation of the twentieth century. The assembly line became the century's characteristic production mode and was applied to every manufacturing process, from phonographs to hamburgers.When was the Model T introduced by the Ford Motor Company? September 4, 1907 September 13, 1910 October 1, 1908 August 23, 1909 Sponsored Ad WEBINAR Predicting Vibration and Noise in HVAC and Automotive Systems August 6 | 2pm ET A common problem in HVAC systems and automotive systems is undesirable noise levels from pipes and cavities with internal pulsating pressures. How can engineers address this issue? L&D COURSES Four Additive Manufacturing Design Courses for the Price of One When you register for ASME's Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Professional Package you'll have access to our Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals course and three additional case study courses covering the concepts in our Replicate, Adapt, Optimize framework. subject: Manufacturing Smarter After the Pandemic
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Introverts are Natural Managers 07.03.2020 Introverts as Managers: A Natural Pairing Let's dispel one big myth: that introverts can't make good managers. The myth comes up particularly in engineering circles because engineers are often stereotyped as introverts. But introverts have many traits that make effective leaders. Sponsored Ad Manufacturing Blog: Smarter Manufacturing after the COVID-19 Pandemic In the face of the COVID-19 pandemic, engineers in the manufacturing and design industry are being forced to revisit their manufacturing processes, and are being asked to design not only digitally, but also smarter and more efficiently. Danielle Boyer's STEAM Dream Nineteen-year old Danielle Boyer is helping kids develop important life skills through affordable and accessible STEAM education. She has furthered her mission through STEAM Connection, a nonprofit organization she founded in January 2020, to teach disadvantaged students about science, technology, engineering, math, and art (STEAM). Sponsored Ad WEBINAR Additive Manufacturing Meets Miniaturization July 29 | 2pm ET In this webinar, you will learn about Projection Micro Stereolithography and how it's a game changer for printing small parts with unparalleled accuracy as well as why it is a game changer in electrical, medical, MEMS and microfluidic applications. L&D COURSES Four additive manufacturing design courses for the price of one When you register for ASME's Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Professional Package you'll have access to our Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals course and three additional case study courses covering the concepts in our Replicate, Adapt, Optimize framework. Get your discount code and save over 80%. The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) 070320-18955 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: 10 Innovative & Smart Startups
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter New Ventilation Systems to Fight COVID-19 07.07.2020 Infographic: 10 Humanoid Robots of 2020 As we continue to reboot and revaluate toward a post-COVID-19 world, humanoid robots can be used to relieve tired nurses in the hospitals, do basic cleaning and deliveries, help in warehouses, and assist in manufacturing plants. Here's an infographic of 10 other humanoids that collaborate with humans on a daily basis. Sponsored Ad 10 Smart Startups Focusing only on Superstar Cities means missing out on some of the most interesting young companies around. To show the diversity of innovation outside the so-called innovation hubs, we are spotlighting 10 startups or young companies developing products in a variety of engineering fields. Q&A: Developing Ventilation Systems to Prevent Virus Spread With no vaccine expected for COVID-19 anytime soon, preventing the spread could be as important as treating it. Purdue University's Professor Qingyan Chen discusses his lab's work on developing a ventilation system that would prevent the transmission of pathogens like the novel coronavirus. Sponsored Ad WHITE PAPERS Vibration Testing with Accelerometers Over 50 years of vibration measurement and monitoring experience packed in this brand new, user-friendly guide. Understand the basics of accelerometer design, types, typical performance, proper installation, and application tips. L&D COURSES Get Four Additive Manufacturing Design Courses for the Price Of One When you register for ASME's Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Professional Package you'll have access to our Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals course and three additional project-based courses covering the concepts in our Replicate, Adapt, Optimize framework. subject: Now available on demand: ASME's A112.6.3 Floor and Trend Drain standard webinar
body: New edition of Floor and Trench Drains standard Connect with us: Access our on-demand webinar to learn about load, weathering and other testing covered Explore the latest edition of ASME's A112.6.3 Floor and Trench Drain standard with our on-demand webinar. Learn about the different testing factors the standards cover such as load testing and weathering. The webinar covers: â€¢ The purpose of the tests â€¢ Test parameters â€¢ Failure criteria â€¢ Determining factors for identifying whether a material is brittle or ductile â€¢ Formulas for calculating the safe live load â€¢ and more... In addition, we touch on the load classification tables provided along with other key elements. View the webinar on-demand today by clicking here. And if you're ready to buy the Floor and Trench Drains standard, you can purchase below or simply click here. subject: Past and Future Errors of the Gas Turbine Industry
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Micro Solar Cells May Offer More Energy 07.09.2020 Video: Boosting Electrical Grid Resilience Most electric utilities in this country have a reputation for being resilient. In recent years, utilities have been concerned with maintaining reliability in the face of hard-to-predict events. Learn from grid operators on how they are ensuring resiliency into the electrical grid. Sponsored Ad Hits and Errors for Gas Turbine Industry The gas turbine industry has had many successes, but this past year it has been dogged by the specter of two great mistakes. The first was Boeing's 737 MAX 8, which led to two horrific accidents and the grounding of the entire fleet. The other mistake hasn't yet happened, but it is even more serious, the faulty engine configuration on the 737 MAX 8, which may result in the elimination of natural gas as a fuel source. Micro Solar Cells Offer More Energy Micro solar cells are of keen interest due to their high efficiency, configurability, and low manufacturing costs. They can absorb twice as much energy as standard solar cells and, when woven into mesh or fabric, create lightweight and flexible alternatives to heavier, bulkier traditional solar panels. Sponsored Ad WEBINAR How to Remain Effective and Productive in the Next Normal - Tools and Technology to Facilitate Engineering Work From Anywhere July 28 | 2pm ET The COVID-19 pandemic has forced several engineers to work remotely. This webinar will highlight the challenges that both workers and IT departments are facing in addressing the challenges of our new normal." L&D COURSES Four Additive Manufacturing Design Courses for the Price of One When you register for ASME's Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals Professional Package you'll have access to our Design for Additive Manufacturing with Metals course and three additional case study courses covering the concepts in our Replicate

subject: Charging an Electric Car in 5 Minutes
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Rebuilding Medical Supply Chains Post-COVID-19 07.14.2020 Infographic: Coal Power Fades The pandemic-related economic shutdown cut electricity demand. In response, utilities turned off their coal plants. What is taking their place? Sponsored Ad Manufacturing Blog: Rebuilding the Medical Device Supply Chain Vulnerabilites in the supply chain for medical devices were dramatically exposed during the COVID-19 pandemic. Rebuilding it will take a mix of diversified sourcing, automation, reshoring and more. Sponsored Ad Advanced Machine EngineeringIn this webinar, watch how Siemens' Advanced Machine Engineering solution helps tomorrow's industrial machinery manufacturers define, manage, as well as integrate electronics and software earlier into the design phase. Q&A: StoreDot's Doron Myersdorf on Developing Fast-Charging Batteries Doron Myersdorf is co-founder and CEO of StoreDot, an Israeli firm that has developed a new, faster-charging lithium-ion battery using nanotechnology and new materials. The battery can charge an electronic device in five minutes, and electric vehicles are next. Sponsored Ad WEBINARS Get to Market Faster: How to Create Silicone Parts with 3D Printed Molds August 12 | 2 PM EST Short run production can be technically challenging, costly, and slow. Learn the step by step process of how to use RTV moldmaking and in-house 3D printing to rapidly produce silicone parts. L&D NEWS Siemens Gas and Power Announces Partnership with ASME to Develop AM training Services Siemens Gas and Power and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) have announced their collaboration on the development of training services in Additive Manufacturing. The agreement is said to lay the groundwork for the creation of unique AM training solutions to better support Siemens' customers on their additive journey. The course curriculum will cover the end-to-end Additive Manufacturing value chain and offer customers real-world applications experience from developing business cases, design for AM, material considerations, through to printing and post-printing process know-how. subject: Origami Habitats for Future Moon Bases
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Ladybug-Size Sensor Will Save Lives 07.16.2020 Energy Blog: The Color of Energy Because of the critical role energy access plays in fostering economic potential, and the acute damage caused by energy pollution, the energy industry should play a leadership role in reversing racial disparities. Sponsored Ad Moon Base Unfolds a New Frontier There's more to life than just surviving, even on a Moon base. To test this philosophy, startup SAGA Space Architects designed a bi-level origami pop-up habitat for the Moon. Now, they plan to live in it for three months in northern arctic Greenland. Ladybug-Size Sensor May Be a Lifesaver After 10 years in development, a tiny device developed by a team from Georgia Institute of Technology holds promise as an early warning alert to a malfunction in the wearer's body before it would otherwise have become apparent. The alert would be sent not only to the wearer but also transmitted wirelessly to medical professionals. Sponsored Ad WEBINAR How to Remain Effective and Productive in the Next Normal - Tools and Technology to Facilitate Engineering Work From Anywhere July 28 | 2pm ET The COVID-19 pandemic has forced several engineers to work remotely. This webinar will highlight the challenges that both workers and IT departments are facing in addressing the challenges of our new normal." L&D CORNER Infographic: The ROI of L&D The benefits of learning and development might be clear in theory

subject: How Girl Scouts is Boosting STEM Engagement
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter 6 Advances in 3D Bioprinting 07.17.2020 7 Wearable Devices for 2020 Wearable technology today is offering consistent monitoring and information for people, comparable to advanced manufacturing systems. By the end of 2020, more than 400 million users will own at least one wearable device. Here are seven devices that are expected to change the wearable field for 2020. Sponsored Ad Podcast: Girl Scouts CEO Sylvia Acevedo on Sparking STEM Curiosity In this episode of ASME TechCast, Sylvia Acevedo, the CEO at Girl Scouts of the USA, shares her passion for all things engineering and talks about the long-term benefits of a focus on STEM, especially for girls. Since becoming the CEO, Acevedo has led the organization's largest rollout of 125 new Girl Scout badges that include 42 new STEM badges such as cybersecurity, robotics, design thinking, coding, data analytics, and space science. 6 Advances in 3D Bioprinting of Living Tissue While bioprinting organs is still far in the future, the method continues to be studied and perfected. Today's advances can lead to new and better treatments for conditions such as spinal cord injury, Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, brain cancer, and much more. From among the many recent developments that are pushing the 3D bioprinting field forward, we present six major advances. Sponsored Ad WEBINAR How to Remain Effective and Productive in the Next Normal - Tools and Technology to Facilitate Engineering Work From Anywhere July 28 | 2pm ET The COVID-19 pandemic has forced several engineers to work remotely. This webinar will highlight the challenges that both workers and IT departments are facing in addressing the challenges of our new normal". L&D CORNER How to Create Value from Learning & Development Investing in continuous learning and development (L&D) helps engineers stay ahead of rapidly advancing engineering technology and improve their employers' results. However

subject: Check out ASME's Y14.41 Digital Product Definition Data Practices
body: New edition now available Connect with us: Discover the latest in digital product design practices ASME Y14.41 provides requirements and reference documents essential for the creation and revision of digital product definition data, or model-based definition, using computer-aided design (CAD) software. The standard provides guidance on how to organize and present product definition data using digital data sets. New software-dependent requirements are featured in this edition, including: Stationary and rotating annotation planes Display management Attributes available on demand Annotation plane orientation A helpful compliance responsibility table to determine whether software is necessary for data preparation And more! Y14.41 is an integral resource for anyone involved in computer-aided manufacturing, design, engineering, inspection or other industrial practices. Be sure to purchase this indispensable resource below or by simply clicking here. Digital Product Definition Data Practices (Y14.41) Y14.41 establishes requirements and reference documents applicable to the preparation and revision of digital product definition data. Price: $165 You may also find these related standards of interest: ASME Y14.37 Product Definition for Composite Parts ASME Y14.46 Product Definition for Additive Manufacturing ASME Y14.47 Model Organization Practices ASME Y14.100 Engineering Drawing Practices Share our Digital Product Definition Data Practices with colleagues and friends: ASME Customer Care: Phone: 1.800.843.2763 Email: customercare@asme.org ASME Codes and Standards ASME is the leading international developer of codes and standards associated with the art, science, and practice of mechanical engineering. Starting with the first issuance of its legendary Boiler & Pressure Vessel Code in 1911, ASMEâ€™s codes and standards have grown to nearly 600 offerings currently in print. subject: A Mechanical Way to Recycle Foam
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter What Do You Know About the First High Rise AC? 07.21.2020 Infographic: What Makes a Smart City? Smart cities will integrate IoT solutions, sensors, and cloud data networks to power automated services, regulate energy usage, and provide more information to the people of the city. Here are the top applications that make up a smart city. Sponsored Ad A Mechanical Way to Recycle Foam Our cushions are clogging up landfills. Made of polyurethane foam, they're unrecyclable and don't break down for a millennium. But now, researchers at the University of Minnesota and Northwestern University have found a way to process that foam so nearly all of it can be recycled. Quiz: What Do You Know About the First Air-Conditioned High Rise? Office buildings in the American South and Southwest were unbearably hot before the advent of air conditioning. What do you know about the Milam Building in San Antonio, Tex., the first high-rise air-conditioned office building in the United States? Take this ASME quiz to find out.When the Milam Building was constructed, stores and theaters already had featured air conditioning. What made the Milam Building groundbreaking? It was the first to control humidity as well as temperature. The system ran on electricity, rather than a steam engine. The system used chilled water instead of more dangerous ammonia. Air conditioning was part of the original design, rather than retrofitted. Sponsored Ad WEBINARS How to Remain Effective and Productive in the Next Normal - Tools and Technology to Facilitate Engineering Work From Anywhere July 28 | 2 PM EST The COVID-19 pandemic has forced several engineers to work remotely. This webinar will highlight the challenges that both workers and IT departments are facing in addressing the challenges of our new normal." L&D CORNER How to Choose the Right Provider to Educate Your Workforce It's hard for professional engineers to keep up with the rapid pace of technological change. So going "back to school" occasionally is a good idea. What that looks like has changed
