subject: 5 Smart Startups in Small Cities
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter 7 Manufacturing Lessons Post-COVID-19 07.23.2020 Robotic Dolphin Changes Aquatics A New Zealand tech entrepreneur is collaborating with animatronics and special effect engineers to build a lifelike robotic dolphin and possibly other marine mammals and large fish, like sharks. If successful, the venture could replace captive mammals and fish in aquariums and entertainment venues. Sponsored Ad Video: 5 Smart Startups in Cities Under 100,000 Technology startups in superstar cities get the lion's share of attention from investors, but there are plenty of smart companies developing amazing products in every part of the United States. Meet five of these smart startups and learn about the innovative products that make them stand out. 7 Manufacturing Lessons fromCOVID-19 The COVID-19 pandemic has severely disrupted manufacturing operations and their supply chains around the world. Key lessons manufacturers have learned include the benefits of a remote workforce, building redundancy and transparency into supply chains, deploying new technologies, including automation, conducting site visits remotely, and being ready to innovate when needed. Sponsored Ad WEBINAR How to Remain Effective and Productive in the Next Normal - Tools and Technology to Facilitate Engineering Work From Anywhere July 28 | 2pm ET The COVID-19 pandemic has forced several engineers to work remotely. This webinar will highlight the challenges that both workers and IT departments are facing in addressing the challenges of our new normal." So going "back to school" occasionally is a good idea. What that looks like has changed

subject: New Virtual Summit to Focus on Aerospace and Medical Devices Additive Manufacturing
body: ASME News June 26, 2020 The two-day event will highlight the medical and aerospace convergence and their shared challenges and opportunities. Vol. 39 No. 13 / July 24, 2020 New Virtual Summit to Focus on Aerospace and Medical Devices Additive Manufacturing ASME invites all additive manufacturing professionals to attend a new virtual event, AM Industry Summit, focused on accelerating additive manufacturing and 3D printing innovations in aerospace and defense and medical device applications. Read more Sponsored Ad ASME Online Voting Procedures - Society Officer Ballot This September, ASME members can once again expect to receive an e-mail that includes information on how to log into the ballot page to vote for the Society's new president and members of the Board of Governors. Members are advised to check their ASME records to ensure that their e-mail address is up-to-date or to add an e-mail address if one is currently not on file. Hard copies will be sent to those without active emails. Read more Sponsored Ad Deadline to Renew Your ASME Membership is Approaching It's time to renew your ASME Membership for 2020-2021. Renewing early will make you eligible for a chance to win valuable credit toward the purchase of ASME products and services. Read more Sponsored Ad Update Your Communications Preferences Stay informed about the latest status of ASME events, meetings, and other activities during this time of the COVID-19 pandemic, by making sure your communications preferences are up-to-date. Opting-in to emails relating to your areas of interest will ensure that you are aware of events going virtual, schedule changes, virtual learning opportunities, and more. This short video walks you through the process. subject: Smart Habitats for Lunar Living
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Can You Name These Historical Inventors? 07.28.2020 Workforce Blog: Is PDM Worth the Hassle? Product Data Management systems aggregate engineering data that would otherwise be stored haphazardly across many formats. It's essential for complex projects and large organizations. But is it worth the time spent downloading, uploading, checking in, and checking out models and drawings? Sponsored Ad Smart Habitats for Sustained Lunar Living The Moon is unforgiving. To survive during and in between missions, lunar habitats must take sustainability to extremes. Researchers at Purdue are working on how to build SmartHabs that can survive - and repair - damage without triggering cascading failures. QUIZ: Can You Name These Historical Inventors? Every year the National Inventors Hall of Fame (NIHF) honoring and celebrating the world's foremost inventors and their contributions to society. This year, NIHF inducted eight historical inventors whose ideas changed the world. Take this quiz to see if you can name these inventors.A farmer from Nebraska worked for his father's farm and blacksmith shop. There he learned how to be an inventor and earned nine patents over his lifetime. His first patent was a driverless tractor that he designed in his teenage years, which would plow fields in concentric circles. He also invented the center-pivot irrigation systems that would be used in farming production worldwide. Who is he? Text: Smart Habitats for Lunar Living ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Can You Name These Historical Inventors? 07.28.2020 Workforce Blog: Is PDM Worth the Hassle? Product Data Management systems aggregate engineering data that would otherwise be stored haphazardly across many formats. It's essential for complex projects and large organizations. But is it worth the time spent downloading, uploading, checking in, and checking out models and drawings? Sponsored Ad Smart Habitats for Sustained Lunar Living The Moon is unforgiving. To survive during and in between missions, lunar habitats must take sustainability to extremes. Researchers at Purdue are working on how to build SmartHabs that can survive - and repair - damage without triggering cascading failures. QUIZ: Can You Name These Historical Inventors? Every year the National Inventors Hall of Fame (NIHF) honoring and celebrating the world's foremost inventors and their contributions to society. This year, NIHF inducted eight historical inventors whose ideas changed the world. Take this quiz to see if you can name these inventors.A farmer from Nebraska worked for his father's farm and blacksmith shop. There he learned how to be an inventor and earned nine patents over his lifetime. His first patent was a driverless tractor that he designed in his teenage years, which would plow fields in concentric circles. He also invented the center-pivot irrigation systems that would be used in farming production worldwide. Who is he? subject: ASME Journal of Vibration and Acoustics (JVA) - "The Latest Vibe" eNewsletter
body: Christopher D. Rahn, PhD - Editor Note from the Editor Welcome to the August 2020 issue of The Latest Vibe - the eNewsletter for the ASME Journal of Vibration and Acoustics! The purpose of this eNewsletter is to highlight the latest publications and activities associated with the ASME Journal of Vibration and Acoustics (JVA). The eNewsletter, issued bi-annually, will keep you abreast of the latest research developments in our field. I look forward to receiving any feedback and suggestions for this eNewsletter. Sincerely, Christopher D. Rahn Editor, ASME Journal of Vibration and Acoustics cdrahn@psu.edu Full Editorial Board Submit a Paper View Recent JVA Issue Learn More â†’ Latest JVA News JVA's 2019 Journal Impact Factor We have received the 2019 Journal Impact Reports and JVA's Impact Factor for 2019 is 2.343, up by 32% from 2017. This is quite an increase and is a testament to the quality of our papers, hard work of our Associate Editors and reviewers, and leadership of Steve Shen (University of Washington), the Editor from 2015 - 2019. I am currently seven months into my tenure as the new Editor of JVA and it is a very demanding job. I want to thank Steve for his five years of stellar service to our technical community. Special Issue on Tribomechadynamics Please keep your eyes open for a Special Issue planned for October on Tribomechadynamics. Matthew Brake (Rice University) is the Guest Editor for this Special Issue and he has a full slate of high quality and interesting papers scheduled for publication. Check it out! Associate Editors Starting Service in 2020 Matteo Aureli, University of Nevada (first term) Ryan Harne, Penn State University (first term) Alper Erturk, Georgia Tech (second term) Stefano Gonella, University of Minnesota (second term) Stefano Lenci, Polytechnic University of Marche (second term) Huageng Luo, National Institute of Clean-and-Low-Carbon Energy (second term) Julian Rimoli, Georgia Institute of Technology (second term) Karsten Stahl, Technical University of Munich (second term) Associate Editors Finishing Service in 2020 Izhak Bucher, Technion Israel Institute of Technology (two terms) Mahmoud Hussein, University of Colorado Boulder (two terms) Lei Zuo, Virginia Tech (two terms) Please check out the complete list of AEs listed on our website. We are very fortunate to have such accomplished researchers serving the vibrations and acoustics technical community. We thank them for their service. Top Most Cited JVA Articles Published Within the Past Four Years Nonlinear Energy Sink for Whole-Spacecraft Vibration Reduction Yang, Kai; Zhang, Ye-Wei; Ding, Hu; Yang, Tian-Zhi; Li, Yang; Chen, Li-Qun Comprehensive Analysis for Influence of Controllable Damper Time Delay on Semi-Active Suspension Control Strategies Qin, Yechen; Zhao, Feng; Wang, Zhenfeng; Gu, Liang; Dong, Mingming Underwater Dynamic Response at Limited Points Expanded to Full-Field Strain Response Chen, Yuanchang; Joffre, Dagny; Avitabile, Peter Metastructure With Piezoelectric Element for Simultaneous Vibration Suppression and Energy Harvesting Hu, Guobiao; Tang, Lihua; Banerjee, Arnab; Das, Raj Pantograph/Catenary Contact Formulations Kulkarni, Shubhankar; Pappalardo, Carmine M.; Shabana, Ahmed A. About the ASME Journal of Vibration and Acoustics The ASME Journal of Vibration and Acoustics is sponsored jointly by the Design Engineering and the Noise Control and Acoustics Divisions of ASME. The journal is the premier international venue for publication of original research concerning mechanical vibration and sound. subject: 5 Real-World Tips for Early Career Engineers
body: ASME E-Fests Find out how early career engineers can prepare for the real world. Innovate. Create. Compete. Celebrate. ASME E-FESTSÂ® NEWS Whatâ€™s Trending in the Engineering Student Community Five Real-World Tips for Early Career Engineers ASME's 2019 Executive Intern offers advice on how early career engineers can prepare for the real world. Full Article â†’ Becoming an Engineer: Deciding Why and Learning How A young mechanical engineering student reflects on what inspired him to pursue engineering. Full Article â†’ Early-Career Advice for Global Development Engineers A young mechanical engineer shares her career milestones in global development. Full Article â†’ Hey Students, Attend ASME'sUpcoming Events ASME's POWER 2020 and Nuclear Engineering Conference powered by ICONE August 4-5, 2020 | Online/Virtual This joint virtual conference has numerous student opportunities to help you develop professionally and interact with experts from industry and academia. Student activities include: student paper competition, panel sessions and awards session. Advanced Clean Energy Summit August 17-18, 2020 | Online/Virtual Students, this event is a great opportunity for you to learn from and interact with energy industry professionals and innovators in clean energy technology. Internal Combustion Engine Fall Technical Conference November 4-5, 2020 | Online/Virtual The ASME Internal Combustion Engines Fall Conference (ICEF) is a premier conference on internal combustion engines and their applications. Students can participate in the undergraduate student competition, expand their knowledge during Keynote and panel sessions and network with professionals from industry and academia. Have questions? subject: Self-Powering Metal-Eating Robots
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Listen to a Fluid-Power Inspired Rap Song 07.30.2020 Engineers Know How to Have Fun Professor Ivo Nedyalkov, a mechanical engineer who is active in ASME's Fluids Engineering Division, has two passions in life: fluids engineering and rap music. Dr. Ivo N" - as he's known in rap circles - joined ASME's Executive Director/CEO Thomas Costabile for a spirited discussion about the deep connections between fluids engineering and rap. subject: 4 Online Learning Platforms for Engineers
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Raytheon's Laura McGill on a Multigenerational Workforce 07.31.2020 Workforce Blog: Developing Career Skills through Design Projects For students, engineering internships provide a challenging variety of work. For industry, the internships are primarily designed to find future employees with desired talents. Each engineering company searching for talent, however, must evaluate whether offering internships or sponsoring a senior design project or offering both, fits the company's needs best. Sponsored Ad 4 Online Learning Platforms for Engineers Campuses across the country had to close, and education conferences were canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, massive open online course platforms like edX and Coursera have surged in popularity, offering engineers an online alternative to in-person learning. 6 Questions with Raytheon's Laura McGill Laura McGill is the vice president of engineering at Raytheon Missile Systems, an $8.3 billion business of Raytheon Corporation. She discusses the challenges of leading a multigenerational workforce and how a model-based engineering approach helps in bringing the teams together. Sponsored Ad WEBINAR Get to Market Faster: How to Create Silicone Parts with 3D Printed Molds August 12 | 2pm ET Short run production can be technically challenging, costly, and slow. Learn the step by step process of how to use RTV mold making and in-house 3D printing to rapidly produce silicone parts. subject: Automating the Risk out of Farming
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Innovation in the Dairy Farming Industry 08.04.2020 Sponsored Content Simple, Sophisticated Automation for Produce Packaging Packaging operations continue to embrace automation as a way to reduce labor costs and workplace injuries while improving efficiency. One area ripe for increased automation is operations that package or process produce. Sponsored Ad Automating the Risk Out of Farming The problems plaguing the farming systems did not disappear; instead, they were heightened during the COVID-19 pandemic. The automation limitations in the supply chain and the lack of risk management and flexibility led to massive food waste and increases in the labor shortage. In response, the industry has turned to automation as a solution to help introduce stability and reduce risk. Sponsored Ad Additive Manufacturing Virtual Industry Summit powered by ASME - August 11 - 12, 2020 - Medical and Aerospace Convergence The AM Industry Summit, powered by ASME, virtually brings together more than 4,000 leading additive manufacturing and 3D printing professionals working in Aerospace & Defense and Medical Device Manufacturing. The event will focus on their shared challenges and unique opportunities in Additive Manufacturing. Find answers in materials, processes, equipment, regulatory issues, quality, repeatability and more. AM Industry Summit bridges the gap. Register here for free > Podcast: Automation Innovation in Dairy Farming Chad Huyser is the regional director and North America president of Lely International. Huyser shares his thoughts on automation in farming today, how COVID-19 impacted the supply chain, and how the future may look like as dairy farmers transition to new automation techniques. Sponsored Ad WEBINARS Predicting Vibration and Noise in HVAC and Automotive Systems August 6 | 2 PM EST A common problem in HVAC systems and automotive systems is undesirable noise levels from pipes and cavities with internal pulsating pressures. How can engineers address this issue? subject: Killing COVID-19 with Robots
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter The Benefits of Multidisciplinary Design for Engineers 08.06.2020 Bioengineering Blog: Computational Modeling's Place in Medical Device Testing The shift from the traditional method of building physical prototypes of medical devices and performing tests in a preclinical or clinical setting to one that uses computational modeling and simulation as a parallel analysis and optimization path enables a product development team to gain insights not feasible through physical testing alone. Sponsored Ad Video: Killing the Coronavirus with Disinfection Robots The novel coronavirus lingers on surfaces and poses a risk for disease transmission. In this video, Mark Stibich, an infectious disease epidemiologist, who is the chief scientific officer and co-founder of Xenex, discusses how UV disinfection robots are being used to destroy COVID-19 on surfaces. Sponsored Ad Additive Manufacturing Virtual Industry Summit powered by ASME - August 11 - 12, 2020 The technical conference sessions on the Main Stage will focus on two tracks: aerospace and defense and medical device manufacturing. AM Aerospace will focus on advanced applications and processes driving safety, performance, and cost reduction. AM Medical will highlight innovative device designs and production efficiencies driving healthcare solutions. Thanks to the support of sponsors, Registration is Free. Sponsored Content The Benefits of a Multidisciplinary Design for Machine Builders Today, engineering disciplines need to work closely together to ensure that a design is completed in a timely and cost-effective manner. Multidisciplinary design blends all the capabilities and skillsets required for advanced machine engineering into a single collaborative environment for engineers. Sponsored Ad WEBINAR Get to Market Faster: How to Create Silicone Parts with 3D Printed Molds August August 12 | 2pm ET Short run production can be technically challenging, costly, and slow. Learn the step by step process of how to use RTV mold making and in-house 3D printing to rapidly produce silicone parts. L&D CORNER The ROI of L&D The benefits of learning and development might be apparent in theory, but that doesn't mean every solution will lead to a positive impact. To develop a business case and show benefit, ask these questions about your company, and determine how an investment in learning and development might change your answers to these questions for the better. subject: Super Animal Robotics
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter The Design Race of the Turbojet Engine 08.11.2020 Sponsored Content Join Us for the Virtual COMSOL Conference 2020 North America On October 7th to the 8th, the 2020 COMSOL Conference of North America will be held virtually. During the online event, users will get a firsthand look at how multiphysics simulation can aid design engineers. The event will have panel discussions, keynote talks, user presentations, and exhibitions on how multiphysics can empower engineering. Registration for all is now open. Sponsored Ad Superman of Soft Robots Inspired by nature, especially the biomechanics of a cheetah's spine, researchers at North Carolina State University have developed a new type of soft robot that can move quickly on solid surfaces or like a fish under water, ascend with gecko-inspired climbing ability, jump off a table, grab delicate objects such as an uncooked egg, and lift heavy objects as well. QUIZ: The Design Race of the Turbojet Engine During the 1930s, Frank Whittle in the United Kingdom and Ernest Heinkel and Hans von Ohain in Germany were independently designing the first prototypes of the turbojet engine. Test your knowledge and learn how the turbojet design developed alongside World War II. A former British Royal Air Force mechanic and pilot, Frank Whittle was initially ridiculed for his propulsion ideas. Eventually, he would establish his own company, Power Jets Ltd., in 1936 and hold his first ground test of a jet engine in 1937. In what year did Frank Whittle first patent the jet engine concept? 1932 1934 1930 1936 Sponsored Ad WEBINARS Get to Market Faster: How to Create Silicone Parts with 3D Printed Molds August 12 | 2 PM EST Short run production can be technically challenging, costly, and slow. Learn the step by step process of how to use RTV mold making and in-house 3D printing to produce silicone parts rapidly. L&D CORNER Learn GD&T in Real-Time Video Conferences With An Expert Learn the fundamentals of Geometric Dimensioning & Tolerancing in a real-time virtual classroom with one of ASME's world-class instructors. Save 20% when you register before September 30th. Get 20% off registration on any Virtual Classroom course when you register by September 30, 2020.Get your discount code now. subject: Cinema-Inspired Robot Design
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Advanced Mini NASA Rovers 08.13.2020 Turning Ash Wood into 3D-Printed Art With tens of millions of ash trees already dead, and eight billion at risk, there is plenty of material available in the construction industry that can turn slightly away from standardization and toward a kind of organic mass customization. Two architects are using 3D printing to transform dead wood into an organic piece of art. Sponsored Ad Cinema-Inspired Simulation Spawns Soft Robots A team of engineers at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh and the University of California, Los Angeles, looking for a way to model the movements of soft materials, took a page from live animation. The new simulation tool they are building can significantly reduce the time it takes to bring a soft robot from drawing board to application. Planetary Rovers Find New Moves Georgia Tech researchers used the NASA rover prototype to build a Mini Rover that displays advanced locomotion principles. Students and professors studied how animals move through granular soils to improve the design. Sponsored Ad WHITE PAPER Automation for Agriculture: Bringing more efficiency to the farm Automation - and especially digitally-driven automation - has revolutionized industries from transportation to manufacturing. One unexpected industry that is now embracing the automation revolution is also one of our oldest: Agriculture. In this white paper, you'll meet some of the leaders in the new agriculture automation sector and how they are starting to transform the farm industry. L&D CORNER Get The ASME Bolting Specialist Qualification Elearning Course For 30% Off One of our most popular programs, the Bolting Specialist Qualification Program, is now available for 30% off! In this 4-course eLearning program, successful candidates will learn and demonstrate the principles and practices to the safe bolted joint assembly as outlined in Appendix A of ASME PCC-1: Guidelines for Pressure Boundary Bolted Flange Joint Assembly. Get the discount code The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) 081320 - 19049 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Explore key additions to ASME's B46.1 Surface Texture standard at our upcoming webinar
body: Sign up for ASME's webinar on its new edition of B46.1 Surface Texture New sections on additive manufacturing, functional correlations for determining a part's strength and more... ASME's latest edition of B46.1 provides a wealth of updates and new information for defining and specifying a surface's texture. The new edition goes beyond traditional measurement and analysis methodologies for characterizing surfaces shaped by conventional machines and now includes guidance on identifying surface textures generated through additive manufacturing based off the unique geometric characteristics this new form of manufacturing provides. Sign up for our upcoming webinar, taking place on Thursday, September 10th at 2pm EDT, and you'll gain insight into: The unique geometric characteristics of additive manufactured parts Identifying parameters that illustrate an additive manufactured product's surface topography Correlating and discriminating between process and performance parameters Determining the strength of a part based on the measurements taken at the surface To sign up for this valuable webinar or to purchase your copy of the standard today, click on the buttons below: Title: ASME's B46.1 Surface Texture 2019 Edition - Updates with Additive Manufacturing Date: Thursday, September 10, 2020 Time: 2:00 PM Eastern Daylight Time REGISTER TODAY ASME B46.1-2019 Surface Texture (Surface Roughness, Waviness, and Lay) This standard is concerned with the geometric irregularities of surfaces. It defines surface texture and its constituents: roughness, waviness, and lay. It also defines parameters for specifying surface texture. The terms and ratings in this standard relate to surfaces produced by such means as abrading, casting, coating, cutting, etching, plastic deformation, sintering, wear, erosion, etc. Price: $215 BUY PDF BUY PRINT BOOK Inform colleagues and friends about ASME's new B46.1 Surface Texture standard edition and upcoming webinar by clicking on the share buttons below: ASME Customer Care: Phone: 1.800.843.2763 Email: customercare@asme.org ASME Codes and Standards ASME is the leading international developer of codes and standards associated with the art, science, and practice of mechanical engineering. Starting with the first issuance of its legendary Boiler & Pressure Vessel Code in 1911, ASME's codes and standards have grown to nearly 600 offerings currently in print. To learn more, visit www.asme.org/codes-standards/about-standards The American Society of Mechanical EngineersÂ®( ASMEÂ® )081320 - 20931 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: 14 Leadership Books for Today's Business World
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Modern Ergonomic Tools for Manufacturing 08.14.2020 8 Questions with ASME President Bryan A. Erler Bryan A. Erler, P.E., is the 139th president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, serving the 2020-2021 term. In this interview, he talks about his lifelong motivation as an engineer and what he hopes to accomplish in the next year. Sponsored Ad 14 Leadership Books for a Changing Business World For many of us, being a good leader is always challenging - whether it is leading a project development team, department, division, or entire company. If you want to improve your leadership skills, check out some of these highly regarded books by top leadership experts. Podcast: Ergonomic Tools for Manufacturing GM's Stephen Krajcarski talks about how the company is testing the IronHand soft exoskeleton system and other exoskeletons on the factory floor. The device provides extra power to a user's hand to help in performing repetitive grasp-intensive tasks. Sponsored Ad JOB OPPORTUNITIES North Carolina State University's Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering is looking for outstanding applicants for full-time faculty positions in all areas of Mechanical Engineering. Candidates in the emerging regions of Mechanical Engineering, including but not limited to autonomous systems and robotics, cyber-physical systems, energy storage, additive manufacturing, renewable energies, and industrial IoT, are encouraged to apply.Visit ASME's Digital Collection for more information. L&D CORNER How to Attract the Next Generation of Engineers Quality Magazine interviewed Arin Ceglia, director of ASME Learning & Development, to find out what organizations can do to keep pace with changing technology and fill skills gaps in their workforce. Learn how today's top innovators are developing skilled young engineers. The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) 081420 - 18958 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Designing Machines with Multi-Disciplinary Design
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Understanding the Limitations of Additive Manufacturing 08.18.2020 Sponsored Content Video: Design a Machine, Not a Prototype In manufacturing, building a machine is a complicated process. Now more than ever, all the engineering disciplines need to work closely together to ensure the design is completed on time and cost-effectively manufactured and commissioned by using multidisciplinary design. Sponsored Ad We Need to Be Real About Additive Manufacturing's Limitations 3D printers filled the supply chain gap during the first stages of the pandemic. But they aren't ready to replace conventional manufacturing. If companies want to use advanced manufacturing as a supply chain fix, they need to leverage the advantages and mitigate the limitations. Infographic: The Persistent Trade Deficit The trade deficit has been a concern among U.S. policymakers for decades. The gap between imports and exports of goods and services has risen and fallen without regard to policies in Washington. Even the current administration, which campaigned on reducing the deficit, has scarcely budged it. Sponsored Ad WHITE PAPER Automation for Agriculture: Bringing more efficiency to the farm Automation - and especially digitally-driven automation - has revolutionized industries from transportation to manufacturing. One unexpected sector that is now embracing the automation revolution is also one of our oldest: Agriculture. In this white paper, you'll meet some of the leaders in the new agriculture automation sector and how they are starting to transform the farm industry. L&D CORNER Fundamentals of Industrial Automation Learn to identify areas in manufacturing processes where robotics and automation should be used when you take the Fundamentals of Industrial Automation. To help the global engineering community achieve learning goals on tighter budgets, ASME is now offering this eLearning course for only $119. Get 80% Off Advanced Manufacturing eLearning Course. subject: Robot Rises to the Challenge of Toolmaking
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Test Your Knowledge on the Arecibo Radio Telescope 08.20.2020 Sponsored Content Simple, Sophisticated Automation for Produce Packaging Packaging operations continue to embrace automation as a way to reduce labor costs and workplace injuries while improving efficiency. One area ripe for increased automation is operations that package or process produce. Sponsored Ad Robot Rises to the Challenge of Toolmaking Can toolmaking innovation be programmed into a robot's code? A team of researchers at Georgia Tech's Robot Autonomy and Interactive Learning Lab has created a robot that uses machine learning to reason about shape, function, and attachment of unrelated parts. QUIZ: What Do You Know About the Arecibo Radio Telescope? Sixty years ago, workers began constructing the Arecibo Telescope in Puerto Rico, the largest single-dish radio telescope ever built. Test your knowledge on the Arecibo radio telescope, an engineering marvel, and an ASME landmark! The reflecting dish is wider across than three football fields. How does the telescope support its weight against gravity? The dish is made of moveable copper tiles mounted on mechanized poles The dish is made of liquid mercury and spins to provide a reflecting shape The dish is made of aluminum foil and floats on a cushion of air The dish was carved from a sinkhole on the top of a mountain, with aluminum panels mounted on short towers Sponsored Ad WHITE PAPER Automation for Agriculture: Bringing more efficiency to the farm Automation - and especially digitally-driven automation - has revolutionized industries from transportation to manufacturing. One unexpected industry that is now embracing the automation revolution is also one of our oldest: Agriculture. In this white paper, you'll meet some of the leaders in the new agriculture automation sector and how they are starting to transform the farm industry. L&D CORNER Expansion Joints: How Thermal Expansion Solutions Can Become Big Pressure Problems Almost all industrial facilities - whether process, power, manufacturing or research - have at least one and often many expansion joints to provide engineered solutions for issues such as thermal expansion, piping fit-up, equipment nozzle loads and vibration isolation. Sometimes they are a last resort. Other times, they are widely accepted as an extra means of safety. Grow your understanding of expansion joints with three key takeaways from this free whitepaper from ASME's expert instructor, Jim Meyer. The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Â® ( ASMEÂ® ) 082020 - 19050 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: Industry 4.0 - UC Online
body: The University of Cincinnati Engineering is now 100% Industry 4.0 focused Set Yourself Apart With a Master's in Mechanical Engineering The future of manufacturing is Industry 4.0. Whether it is the implementation of AI, Big Data, or 3-D Printing, organizations are looking to become more efficient with their output. The University of Cincinnati has dedicated it's entire Master of Engineering program to train students for this marketplace shift towards Industry 4.0. This program offers: In-depth knowledge related to Industry 4.0. 100% online learning. Technical and leadership skill development. subject: ASME Student Membership Profile: Missing Information Request
body: Please Update Your ASME Contact Information Important Information about your ASME Benefits Missing information request: Please complete your student membership profile today! Dear Chandu Binu, ASME is a global, diverse, and inclusive society. As part of your ASME Student member benefits, you are entitled to register for one of our Professional Technical Divisions (see below) in order to receive notifications of ASME offerings highlighting the latest technology developments. We noticed that your Technical Division selection was missing from your ASME membership application. In addition, we encourage you to provide your demographic information related to ethnicity and gender, if you have not done so already. Please take a minute to update your selection and stay up-to-date! Select Your Technical Divisions 27 Advanced Energy Systems 29 Materials and Energy Recovery 01 Aerospace 04 Materials Handling Engineering 02 Applied Mechanics 39 Microelectromechanical Engineering 09 Bioengineering 32 Noise Control & Acoustics 31 Computers & Information in Engineering 33 Nondestructive Evaluation, Diagnosis, and Prognosis 14 Design Engineering 17 Nuclear Engineering 25 Dynamic Systems & Control 35 Ocean, Offshore & Arctic Engineering 34 Electronic & Photonic Packaging 16 Petroleum 23 Environmental Engineering 40 Pipeline Systems 36 Fluid Power Systems & Technology 21 Plant Engineering & Maintenance 08 Fluids Engineering 19 Power 11 Heat Transfer 28 Pressure Vessels & Piping 38 Information Storage & Processing Systems 12 Process Industries 05 Internal Combustion Engine 18 Rail Transportation 22 Int'l Gas Turbine Institute 07 Safety Engineering & Risk Analysis 03 Management 30 Solar Energy 13 Manufacturing Engineering 24 Technology & Society 10 Materials 15 Tribology We understand this information may be sensitive, so if you prefer to call us, you can reach our Customer Care Department directly at: (800) 843-2763 or +1 646-616-3100. subject: A Star Wars-Inspired Robotic Prosthetic
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter 3D-Printing Design Tips for Engineers 08.25.2020 Sponsored Content The Benefits of a Multidisciplinary Design for Machine Builders Today, engineering disciplines need to work closely together to ensure that a design is completed in a timely and cost-effective manner. Multidisciplinary design blends all the capabilities and skillsets required for advanced machine engineering into a single collaborative environment for engineers. Sponsored Ad Star Wars Inspires a Mind-Controlled Prosthetic Advanced prosthetic hand devices use electrodes placed on the skin to intercept neural signals, stimulating basic motions in the prosthetic device. Engineers at Mobius Bionics have taken this a step further, wiring electrodes directly to nerves within the arm, allowing the brain to create natural movements and sensations with the hand. Infographic: 3D Printing Design Tips Recently, the material known commonly as Teflon, is one the latest of 3D-printable materials on the market. 3M has released a tip guide on how to handle the new material, which can also be used as a general tip guide for engineers taking their first steps into 3D printing. Sponsored Ad WHITE PAPER Automation for Agriculture: Bringing more efficiency to the farm Automation - and especially digitally driven automation - has revolutionized industries from transportation to manufacturing. One unexpected sector that is now embracing the automation revolution is also one of our oldest: Agriculture. In this white paper, you'll meet some of the leaders in the new agriculture automation sector and how they are starting to transform the farm industry. L&D CORNER Expansion Joints: How Thermal Expansion Solutions Can Become Big Pressure Problems Almost all industrial facilities - whether process, power, manufacturing, or research - have at least one and often many expansion joints to provide engineered solutions for issues such as thermal expansion, piping fit-up, equipment nozzle loads and vibration isolation. Sometimes they are the last resort. Other times, they are widely accepted as an extra means of safety. Grow your understanding of expansion joints with three key takeaways from this free whitepaper from ASME's expert instructor, Jim Meyer. subject: ASME Journal of Energy Resources Technology - 2019 Journal Impact Factor now 3.183
body: Hameed Metghalchi, PhD - Editor ASME Journal of Energy Resources Technology 2019 Journal Impact Factor now 3.183 ASME is pleased to announce that the Journal Impact Factor* of the ASME Journal of Energy Resources Technology increased by 45% (2017-2019) to 3.183. ASME recognizes the hard work and dedication of the Editor, Associate Editors, peer reviewers, and authors of the ASME Journal of Energy Resources Technology who made this possible. Below please find some highly cited articles recently published in the journal that are FREE to access and download for a limited period of time. *2019 Journal Citation ReportsÂ® (Clarivate Analytics, 2020) Review of Wind Turbine Research in 21st Century Ryoichi S. subject: Panama Canal Expands to Meet Demand
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter What Do You Know of U.S. Power Generation? 08.27.2020 3D Bioprinting Tumor Models to Study Drug Response Researchers at Northeastern University in Boston and the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute are perfecting a bioprinting method, combined with 3D imaging, to study how glioblastoma tumors respond to drug therapies in a bid to find the most successful treatment. Sponsored Ad Panama Canal Expands to Meet Demand The Panama Canal remains one of the most difficult engineering projects built. Its recent expansion eliminated nagging geotechnical issues and now operators are looking to build a fourth set of locks and improve port facilities. Still, water shortages may hamper operations. QUIZ: The Energy Mix of U.S. Power Generation The energy mix in the U.S. is going through a realignment as traditional fossil fuels of oil, coal and natural gas lose ground to renewable sources of power. Take this quiz to see what you know about power generation. In 2019, almost 63 percent of electricity was generated by fossil fuels. What were the three leading sources? Coal, natural gas, oil Natural gas, coal, oil Coal, oil, natural gas Oil, natural gas, coal Sponsored Ad WEBINAR Design and Optimization of a BMR Loudspeaker Drive Unit October 15 | 2 pm ET Balanced mode radiator drive units are experiencing widespread adoption due to their full bandwidth, wide directivity radiation field that is largely decoupled from their physical size. Although the behavior of the diaphragm is unique, the remaining key elements of the drive unit, such as the motor and suspension structures, require similar optimization to conventional drive units. COMSOL MultiphysicsÂ® will highlight some of the key design steps including the incorporation of the Magnetic Fields, Solid Mechanics, and Pressure Acoustics physics interfaces. L&D CORNER Fundamentals of Industrial Automation Learn to identify areas in manufacturing processes where robotics and automation should be used when you take the Fundamentals of Industrial Automation. To help the global engineering community achieve learning goals on tighter budgets, ASME is now offering this eLearning course for only $119. Get the discount code. subject: Is There an Alternative to China for Manufacturing?
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter The Excitement of Rising Mechanical Engineers 08.28.2020 Bioengineering Blog: Patents for Pandemics The coronavirus pandemic seemed to catch the world by surprise, but for some inventors, epidemics have been a prime concern. A quick review of patents filed over the past decade shows how the problems we face today were anticipated, along with descriptions of proposed solutions. Sponsored Ad ASME TechCast: Is There an Alternative to China? In the wake of COVID-19, global manufacturers are reconsidering their dependence on Chinese factories. Mechanical Engineering magazine editor-in-chief Jeffrey Winters talks with senior editor John Kosowatz about whether it's possible to break away from China. Communicating the Excitement of Engineering Through its wide range of programs such as the ASME INSPIRE and scholarships, the ASME Foundation is championing the Society's mission. ASME philanthropy plays a crucial role in this mission by supporting an arc of programs that support aspiring and rising engineers at every stage of their professional journeys. Sponsored Ad WEBINAR Design and Optimization of a BMR Loudspeaker Drive Unit October 15 | 2 pm ET Balanced mode radiator drive units are experiencing widespread adoption due to their full bandwidth, wide directivity radiation field that is largely decoupled from their physical size. Although the behavior of the diaphragm is unique, the remaining key elements of the drive unit, such as the motor and suspension structures, require similar optimization to conventional drive units. COMSOL MultiphysicsÂ® will highlight some of the key design steps including the incorporation of the Magnetic Fields, Solid Mechanics, and Pressure Acoustics physics interfaces. L&D CORNER Introduction to Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing - Y14.5 Designed for those who use the ASME Y14.5 Dimensioning and Tolerancing standard, this course covers most of the geometric dimensioning controls used on mechanical engineering drawings. This is an online, instructor-supported course, allowing you to work at your own pace and convenience. Composed of twelve modules with quizzes, most modules have drawing assignments and supplementary information. Get the discount code. A quick review of patents filed over the past decade shows how the problems we face today were anticipated, along with descriptions of proposed solutions. Sponsored Ad ASME TechCast: Is There an Alternative to China? In the wake of COVID-19, global manufacturers are reconsidering their dependence on Chinese factories. Mechanical Engineering magazine editor-in-chief Jeffrey Winters talks with senior editor John Kosowatz about whether it's possible to break away from China. ASME philanthropy plays a crucial role in this mission by supporting an arc of programs that support aspiring and rising engineers at every stage of their professional journeys. subject: Discover ASME's new Y14.47 Model Organization Practices
body: ASME Y14.47 is now available Connect with us: Explore how Y14.47's complete model-based definitions can help drive efficiencies in design time ASME's new Y14.47 Model Organization Practices standard has been written to provide the foundation elements for design in a model-based enterprise (MBE). Y14.47 outlines model organization schema practices for organizing three-dimensional (3D) modeling and other information to support model-based definitions. The standard provides requirements and guidelines for computer-aided design (CAD) users and is the first ASME standard to include a 3D PDF. Successful application of Y14.47 means that all of the dimensions and tolerances that fully describe a part will be baked into a model. This enables the 3D model to be used as a master source for obtaining product definition data, providing a designer with key information, thereby helping to streamline the design process. This new standard offers: Clear definitions for a complete model A model-only definition without the need to accommodate a 2D drawing Organizational framework requirements such as associated groups, naming conventions, presentation states, product definition elements and metadata Semantic (digitally associated) data geometry and tolerances Application examples of data set completeness states Be sure to secure your copy today by clicking on the order button below or by simply clicking here. Model Organization Practices (Y14.47) ASME Y14.47 is intended to be the foundation for design development efforts in a model-based enterprise (MBE). This standard establishes a schema for organizing a three-dimensional (3D) model and other associated information within the context of a digital product definition data set for the purpose of conveying a product definition that enables a MBE. It outlines model organization schema practices to support model-based definition (MBD) and provides a set of requirements and guidelines for the computer-aided design (CAD) user. This standard contains no requirements pertaining to drawing graphic sheets. The 3D model is a master source for obtaining product definition data and eliminates the need for a drawing graphic sheet. Price: $56 You may also find these related standards of interest: ASME Y14.37 Product Definition for Composite Parts ASME Y14.41 Digital Product Definition Practices ASME Y14.5 Dimensioning and Tolerancing Click one of the share buttons to tell colleagues and friends about ASME's new Y14.47 Model Organization Practices standard: ASME Customer Care: Phone: 1.800.843.2763 Email: customercare@asme.org ASME Codes and Standards ASME is the leading international developer of codes and standards associated with the art, science, and practice of mechanical engineering. Starting with the first issuance of its legendary Boiler & Pressure Vessel Code in 1911, ASMEâ€™s codes and standards have grown to nearly 600 offerings currently in print. subject: How to Design and Optimize a Balanced Mode Radiator Drive Unit
body: What are the key design steps you need to consider? Design and Optimization of a BMR Loudspeaker Drive Unit Thursday, October 15, 2020 â€¢ 2:00 PM ET / 11:00 AM PT Sponsored By: Register Now â†’ Balanced mode radiator (BMR) drive units are experiencing widespread adoption due to their full bandwidth, wide directivity radiation field that is largely decoupled from their physical size. This is achieved through careful control of the modal behavior of the diaphragm. Although the behavior of the diaphragm is unique, the remaining key elements of the drive unit, such as the motor and suspension structures, require similar optimization to conventional drive units. All of these components can be designed and optimized efficiently using COMSOL MultiphysicsÂ®. Join COMSOL's webinar where some of these key design steps will be highlighted, incorporating the Magnetic Fields, Solid Mechanics, and Pressure Acoustics physics interfaces, either coupled together or used individually to design and optimize a BMR drive unit. Speakers: Tim Whitwell Vice President Engineering Tectonic Audio Labs Jinlan Huang PhD, Applications Engineer COMSOL Sign Me Up â†’ Note: Registration information will be shared with the sponsor. subject: 7 Examples of Lean Manufacturing
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Students Compete in the Army FirePoint 3C UAV Challenge 09.01.2020 Energy Blog: Time is Energy The grid needs to be balanced by the millisecond, while infrastructure lasts for decades or even centuries. That means that for energy planners, solving today's challenges requires juggling past, present, and future across many timescales. Sponsored Ad 7 Examples of Lean Manufacturing in Action Lean manufacturing has been around for decades. The implementation of lean tools and techniques usually results in impressive gains in efficiency and production. These seven real-life examples show how lean methods improve operational performance and reduce costs. Digitization Opens Door to Collaboration During COVID-19 Three student groups have won a competition to collaborate on designing a UAV for the U.S. Army. The winners of the FirePoint 3C Challenge are each designing a subset of the UAV: lift, power, and airframe. Their work has been complicated because of COVID-19. Sponsored Ad WHITE PAPER Automation for Agriculture: Bringing more efficiency to the farm Automation - and especially digitally driven automation - has revolutionized industries from transportation to manufacturing. One unexpected sector that is now embracing the automation revolution is also one of our oldest: Agriculture. In this white paper, you'll meet some of the leaders in the new agriculture automation sector and how they are starting to transform the farm industry. L&D CORNER Fracture Mechanics Virtual Classroom Learn how to select materials for fatigue and fracture resistance, how to perform simple to moderately complex fracture mechanics calculations, identify codified procedures for flaw evaluation, and much more. subject: The Future of Artificial Intelligence Domination
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter A 16th Century Design for a 21st Century Compressor 09.08.2020 Sponsored Content Video: 5 Ways 3D Printing is Becoming Bigger Not too long ago, additive manufacturers measured their workspace in centimeters. Today, they are printing rockets, boats, motor vehicles, small bridges, and other products. Engineers are constantly finding more applications for 3D printing, and the 3D-printed products are getting bigger in size. This video highlights five such examples. Sponsored Ad Blast from the Past A California startup is taking a cue from 16th-century technology to design a compressor that uses a centrifugal system to produce compressed air quieter, without oil and only two moving parts. The machine works off the principles of a trompe, a medieval device that uses the weight and force of falling water diffused with air bubbles to compress air and force it through a pipe. Infographic: The Future of Artificial Intelligence Domination Artificial intelligence is proliferating into different technologies such as machine vision, language processing tools, and manufacturing equipment. AI will significantly expedite processes and minimize human error and will create new hybrid roles where humans enable machines, and AI augments human capabilities. Here are some growing trends in the AI market. Sponsored Ad WHITE PAPER Automation for Agriculture: Bringing more efficiency to the farm Automation - and especially digitally driven automation - has revolutionized industries from transportation to manufacturing. One unexpected sector that is now embracing the automation revolution is also one of our oldest: Agriculture. In this white paper, you'll meet some of the leaders in the new agriculture automation sector and how they are starting to transform the farm industry. L&D CORNER Expansion Joints: How Thermal Expansion Solutions Can Become Big Pressure Problems Almost all industrial facilities - whether process, power, manufacturing, or research - have at least one and often many expansion joints to provide engineered solutions for issues such as thermal expansion, piping fit-up, equipment nozzle loads, and vibration isolation. Sometimes they are the last resort. Other times, they are widely accepted as an extra means of safety. Grow your understanding of expansion joints with three key takeaways from this free whitepaper from ASME's expert instructor, Jim Meyer.. subject: Last chance - Register for the B46.1 webinar & explore why it's key for additive products
body: Sign up for ASME's webinar on its new edition of B46.1 Surface Texture Last chance - Register for the B46.1 webinar & explore why it's key for additive manufactured products The surfaces generated by additive manufacturing differ from those produced by conventional manufacturing and have their own unique geometric characteristics. These distinct differences mean that the results of existing tests many not be accurate. Don't miss out on our upcoming B46.1 webinar where you'll learn about these unique characteristics, found in the latest edition of the standard, along with other key information. Sign up for our upcoming webinar on B46.1, taking place today at 2pm EDT, and you'll gain insight into: The unique geometric characteristics of additive manufactured parts Identifying an additive manufactured product's surface topography Correlating and discriminating between process and performance parameters Determining the strength of a part based on the measurements taken at the surface Common additive manufacturing issues and how to address them To sign up for this valuable webinar or to purchase your copy today, click on the buttons below: Title: ASME's B46.1 Surface Texture 2019 Edition - Updates with Additive Manufacturing Date: Thursday, September 10, 2020 Time: 2:00 PM Eastern Daylight Time REGISTER TODAY ASME B46.1-2019 Surface Texture (Surface Roughness, Waviness, and Lay) This standard is concerned with the geometric irregularities of surfaces. It defines surface texture and its constituents: roughness, waviness, and lay. It also defines parameters for specifying surface texture. The terms and ratings in this standard relate to surfaces produced by such means as abrading, casting, coating, cutting, etching, plastic deformation, sintering, wear, erosion, etc. Price: $215 BUY PDF BUY PRINT BOOK Inform colleagues and friends about ASME's new B46.1 Surface Texture standard edition and upcoming webinar by clicking on the share buttons below: ASME Customer Care: Phone: 1.800.843.2763 Email: customercare@asme.org ASME Codes and Standards ASME is the leading international developer of codes and standards associated with the art, science, and practice of mechanical engineering. Starting with the first issuance of its legendary Boiler & Pressure Vessel Code in 1911, ASME's codes and standards have grown to nearly 600 offerings currently in print. These distinct differences mean that the results of existing tests many not be accurate. Don't miss out on our upcoming B46.1 webinar where you'll learn about these unique characteristics, found in the latest edition of the standard, along with other key information. Sign up for our upcoming webinar on B46.1, taking place today at 2pm EDT, and you'll gain insight into: The unique geometric characteristics of additive manufactured parts Identifying an additive manufactured product's surface topography Correlating and discriminating between process and performance parameters Determining the strength of a part based on the measurements taken at the surface Common additive manufacturing issues and how to address them To sign up for this valuable webinar or to purchase your copy today, click on the buttons below: Title: ASME's B46.1 Surface Texture 2019 Edition - Updates with Additive Manufacturing Date: Thursday, September 10, 2020 Time: 2:00 PM Eastern Daylight Time REGISTER TODAY ASME B46.1-2019 Surface Texture (Surface Roughness, Waviness, and Lay) This standard is concerned with the geometric irregularities of surfaces. It defines surface texture and its constituents: roughness, waviness, and lay. It also defines parameters for specifying surface texture. The terms and ratings in this standard relate to surfaces produced by such means as abrading, casting, coating, cutting, etching, plastic deformation, sintering, wear, erosion, etc. Price: $215 BUY PDF BUY PRINT BOOK Inform colleagues and friends about ASME's new B46.1 Surface Texture standard edition and upcoming webinar by clicking on the share buttons below: ASME Customer Care: Phone: 1.800.843.2763 Email: customercare@asme.org ASME Codes and Standards ASME is the leading international developer of codes and standards associated with the art, science, and practice of mechanical engineering. Starting with the first issuance of its legendary Boiler & Pressure Vessel Code in 1911, ASME's codes and standards have grown to nearly 600 offerings currently in print. To learn more, visit www.asme.org/codes-standards/about-standards The American Society of Mechanical EngineersÂ®( ASMEÂ® )090920 - 20935 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. subject: 3D Printing Goes Nuclear
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Physic-Based Simulations for the Machine Learning Systems 09.10.2020 Five Key Trends in Industrial Connectivity Heavy-duty industrial connectors are being preferred to hardwiring/lugging in wiring modular machines and systems for IoT networks. Here are five key trends that demonstrate how connectivity supports digitalization and new possibilities in machine and systems design. Sponsored Ad 3D Printing Goes Critical with Nuclear Reactor Core The design and materials of nuclear reactors haven't changed much since the 1950s. Now, a team at Oak Ridge National Laboratory is following a data-driven approach to build a 3D-printed nuclear reactor core prototype that could enable nuclear plants to run more efficiently. Bioengineering Blog: Physics-based Simulation Helps Train Machine-Learning Systems Simulation is not meant to be a replacement for all physical testing in medical devices. Prototypes, bench tests, preclinical labs, and clinical studies are not replaced by modeling and simulation, but when used side by side, they become more efficient at reaching project goals. Sponsored Ad WEBINAR Design and Optimization of a BMR Loudspeaker Drive Unit October 15 | 2 pm ET Balanced mode radiator drive units are experiencing widespread adoption due to their full bandwidth, wide directivity radiation field that is largely decoupled from their physical size. Although the behavior of the diaphragm is unique, the remaining key elements of the drive unit, such as the motor and suspension structures, require similar optimization to conventional drive units. COMSOL MultiphysicsÂ® will highlight some of the key design steps including the incorporation of the Magnetic Fields, Solid Mechanics, and Pressure Acoustics physics interfaces. L&D CORNER Expansion Joints: How Thermal Expansion Solutions Can Become Big Pressure Problems Almost all industrial facilities - whether process, power, manufacturing or research - have at least one and often many expansion joints to provide engineered solutions for issues such as thermal expansion, piping fit-up, equipment nozzle loads and vibration isolation. Sometimes they are a last resort. Other times, they are widely accepted as an extra means of safety. Grow your understanding of expansion joints with three key takeaways from this free whitepaper from ASMEs expert instructor, Jim Meyer. subject: Advanced Simulation for Optimal Speaker Design
body: COMSOL Multiphysics software highlights how to optimize a speaker design for better sound Design and Optimization of a BMR Loudspeaker Drive Unit Thursday, October 15, 2020 â€¢ 2:00 PM ET / 11:00 AM PT Sponsored By: Register Now â†’ Several sound systems in the audio industry are adopting balanced mode radiator speakers due to their full bandwidth, wide directivity radiation field that is largely decoupled from their physical size. The speaker achieves this field through careful control of the modal behavior of the diaphragm. Although the behavior of the diaphragm is unique, the remaining key elements of the drive unit, such as the motor and suspension structures, require similar optimization to conventional drive units. COMSOL's webinar will highlight how each of these components was optimized using advanced simulation incorporating magnetic field, solid mechanics, and acoustic pressure analysis. Speakers: Tim Whitwell Vice President Engineering Tectonic Audio Labs Jinlan Huang PhD, Applications Engineer COMSOL Sign Me Up â†’ Note: Registration information will be shared with the sponsor. ASME and Mechanical Engineering Magazine do not endorse vendor products or services. subject: Snake Physiology Inspires 4D-Printed Design
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Quiz on the Engineering Feat of the Holland Tunnel 09.15.2020 Podcast: Engineers Make Microscopic Robots Walk A collaboration between Cornell and Penn Engineering has resulted in the first microscopic robots that incorporate semiconductor components, allowing them to be controlled with standard electronic signals. In this podcast, Itai Cohen, professor of physics, who is leading the research at Cornell, discusses the cross-disciplinary research that led to this breakthrough. Sponsored Ad Slither and Squirm: Snakes Inspire a 4D-Printed Design Snakes have certain repeating elements in their skin surface design, from the size and shape of scales to microscopic hair-like elements called fibrils that enable friction control. Understanding these snakeskin patterns may be the first step toward designing better surfaces. QUIZ: What Do You Know About the Holland Tunnel? When construction on the Holland Tunnel was completed, it was the longest underwater, mechanically ventilated tunnel in the world. Test your knowledge of this mechanical engineering landmark in this ASME quiz. The Holland Tunnel was designed to link New York City and New Jersey. What body of water does it pass under? subject: Discover the latest safety requirements and guidelines for pressure vessels for human occupancy
body: ASME's PVHO standard is now available Connect with us: Explore key design and material updates thataid in designing and documenting your PVHOs ASME PVHO-1 lays out requirements for the design, fabrication, inspection, testing, marking and stamping of pressure vessels for human occupancy (PVHO) that have an internal or external pressure differential exceeding 2 psi. These pressure vessels include submersibles, diving bells, personnel transfer capsules, decompression chambers, recompression chambers, hyperbaric chambers, high altitude chambers and medical hyperbaric oxygenation facilities. This standard also applies to the design, fabrication, inspection, testing, cleaning and certification of piping systems for PVHOs. The 2019 edition of PVHO-1 includes: Updates that address PVHOs and systems made from nonstandard materials New definitions have been added to Mandatory Appendix II to assist in documenting a complete PVHO system rather than as single or multiple pressure chambers Changes that clarify several design standards and requirements for easier understanding and implementation And more... ASME PVHO-2 provides technical criteria and guidelines for the operation and maintenance of PVHOs, as well as systems designed, constructed, tested and certified in accordance with ASME PVHO-1. New updates included in these guidelines will allow users to: Assess the serviceability of a PVHO acrylic window in protected as well as severe environments Determine when an acrylic window requires replacement Be sure to purchase these essential resources by clicking the links below. Safety Standard for Pressure Vessels for Human Occupancy (PVHO-1) ASME PVHO-1 provides requirements for the design, fabrication, inspection, testing, marking, and stamping of pressure vessels for human occupancy, having an internal or external pressure differential exceeding 2 psi. This standard also provides requirements for the design, fabrication, inspection, testing, cleaning, and certification of piping systems for PVHOs. Price: $275 Safety Standard for Pressure Vessels for Human Occupancy: In-Service Guidelines (PVHO-2) ASME PVHO-2 provides technical criteria and guidelines for the operation and maintenance of PVHOs and PVHO systems that were designed, constructed, tested and certified in accordance with ASME PVHO-1. Price: $95 You may also find these related standards of interest: ASME BPVC-VIII-2 BPVC Section VIII: Rules for Construction of Pressure Vessels Division 2 - Alternative Rules ASME PTB-6 Guidelines for Strain Gaging of Pressure Vessels Subjected to External Pressure Loading in the PVHO-1 Standard ASME STP-PT-047 Principles of Safety and Performance for Medical Hyperbaric Chambers: Guidelines for Regulatory Submission Tell your colleagues and friends about ASME's two new PVHO editions by clicking on the share buttons below: ASME Customer Care: Phone: 1.800.843.2763 Email: customercare@asme.org ASME Codes and Standards ASME is the leading international developer of codes and standards associated with the art, science, and practice of mechanical engineering. Starting with the first issuance of its legendary Boiler & Pressure Vessel Code in 1911, ASMEâ€™s codes and standards have grown to nearly 600 offerings currently in print. subject: Rethinking China Manufacturing Post-Pandemic
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Q&A with Former Girl Scouts CEO Sylvia Acevedo 09.18.2020 Identifying as an Engineer What makes you an engineer? Texas researchers surveyed around 1,200 undergraduate engineering students at their institutions to probe how gender and ethnicity influence engineering identity in students. Sponsored Ad Rethinking China The coronavirus pandemic exposed the downside of sourcing much of global manufacturing in one country. The global shutdown put the spotlight on China, the country first affected by the coronavirus and where the great bulk of the world's goods are manufactured. Moving that production elsewhere - or even returning some of it to the United States - is easier said than done. 6 Questions with Former Girl Scouts CEO Sylvia Acevedo Former Girl Scouts CEO Sylvia Acevedo shares her career journey and explains the power of persistence. During her tenure as CEO of Girl Scouts, she led the organization's largest rollout of new Girl Scout badges, including 117 new STEM badges. subject: Video on How Farm Robotics and Automation Reduce Risk
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter Sensors to Track the Lifespan of 3D-Printed Parts 09.22.2020 Sensors Track Wear and Tear on 3D-Printed Parts For members of the armed forces, 3D-printed parts have a key advantage because they can be made quickly and easily at less cost onsite or in the field. U.S. Army researchers at Aberdeen Proving Ground recently discovered a way to use sensors to monitor the performance and degradation of 3-D printed parts over time. With this data, they can predict when a part will need to be replaced. Sponsored Ad Farm Robotics and Automation to Reduce Risk Several new technology areas, such as greenhouse farming and IoT-powered automation equipment, are part of an automation tech wave taking hold of the agriculture industry. This future of automation and robotics in the agriculture industry will help reduce labor and production costs and mitigate risk. Sponsored Ad ASMEÂ® IMECEÂ® 2020 is Going Virtual - Register Today ASMEÂ® IMECEÂ® is going virtual this year, taking place November 16-19...With up to 20 parallel sessions and a fresh approach to learning, networking and advancing the industry, this online experience sets the stage for meaningful connections and knowledge sharing, without having to leave your desk. Register today for as low as $199! QUIZ: What is the Future of Automation in Agriculture? Increasing food waste, the labor shortage, and economic instability have created a situation with high risk for many farmers across the world. Automation is one method farmers can gain some control and create some stability on their own. Test your knowledge and learn how automation will impact the agriculture sector for years to come. Food waste is one of the significant problems plaguing the farming industry today. According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, an estimated $160 billion of food is wasted every year. How many tons of food is that? 50 Million Tons 40 Million Tons 20 Million Tons 30 Million Tons Sponsored Ad WEBINAR Design and Optimization of a BMR Loudspeaker Drive Unit October 15 | 2 PM ET Balanced mode radiator drive units are experiencing widespread adoption due to their full bandwidth, wide directivity radiation field that is largely decoupled from their physical size. subject: Trading One Energy Crisis for Another
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter 5 Ways 3D Printing is Becoming Bigger 09.24.2020 Sponsored Content Video: 5 Ways 3D Printing is Becoming Bigger Not too long ago, additive manufacturers measured their workspace in centimeters. Today, they are printing rockets, boats, motor vehicles, small bridges, and other products. Engineers are constantly finding more applications for 3D printing, and the 3D-printed products are getting bigger in size. This video highlights five such examples. Sponsored Ad Energy Blog: Trading One Crisis for Another To solve today's climate emergency, we'll need to deploy lots of new energy technologies-and fast. But in addition to heeding engineers to get the technology right, we need to plan ahead, anticipating problems before they arise, and building an incentive structure that doesn't lead to unintentional feedback loops. Efficiency is the Infinitely Expandable Resource The cheapest way to cut carbon emissions is to reduce the need for energy. Amory Lovins has been advocating for efficient design his entire career. The path forward is to embrace efficient design. Starting the design from the bottom up has now become more important than ever. Sponsored Ad WEBINAR Remote Threats: Insider Risk and the Remote Work Paradigm October 26 | 2 pm ET It's a new world for businesses everywhere. Learn the indicators professionals look for in potential problem employees and review the motivations that drive employees to cross the line. Get equipped with strategies and questions you should ask your leadership to better protect you company in these unprecedented times. subject: Reduce Virus Transmission with New Surface Materials
body: ASME TechReboot - ME Magazine Newsletter What Do You Know About Manufacturing in China? 09.29.2020 LIDAR for Remote Sensing During COVID-19 As the global pandemic continues, some manufacturers are realizing they can repurpose their 3D LIDAR systems for monitoring employee distancing. LIDAR, along with thermal monitoring and video systems, can help keep illness at bay in a manufacturing plant. Sponsored Ad Virus-Vanquishing Surface to Reduce Transmission Coronavirus and its cohorts go from body to body by hanging out on surfaces. But if our surfaces could stop them in their tracks, we could defang the next potential pandemic. Researchers out of the Queensland University of Technology have created that surface. To do so, they studied surfaces found in the animal kingdom: Shark and gecko skin, dragonfly, and cicada wings. Sponsored Ad AM Professionals - Apply by October 30th Apply your advanced manufacturing know-how to tomorrow's hydropower innovations! The I AM Hydro Prize" is open for applications through October 30th

subject: Call for Papers: Special Issue on Uncertainty Quantification and Management in Additive Manufacturing
body: ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Eng. Systems ASME's Guide for Journal Authors Submit Manuscript â†’ CALL FOR PAPERSASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems, Part B: Mechanical EngineeringSpecial Issue on Uncertainty Quantification and Management in Additive Manufacturing (SI046B) Additive Manufacturing (AM) represents a new paradigm of manufacturing where parts are manufactured using their 3D models (such as CAD models) by joining materials in a layer-by-layer manner. AM can have significant impact on the economies all over the world, as it tends to be more sustainable (in terms of material wastage) compared to traditional manufacturing processes. Widespread implementation of AM requires robust techniques for performance evaluation, quality control, and certification. In reality, manufacturing processes are impacted by heterogeneous uncertainty sources at various stages of a manufacturing process, such as raw materials, process equipment, process parameters, process simulation models, and sensors. Therefore, techniques of Uncertainty Quantification and Management (UQ&M) are essential for the quality control and certification of AM processes. With the development of advanced simulation techniques, artificial intelligence, and big data analytics, new UQ&M approaches are emerging to enable model-based quality control and certification, data-driven quality monitoring, and AI-based quality assurance in AM. This Special Issue is dedicated to recent advances in the field of UQ&M with application in AM. Topics of interest include but are not limited to the following: AM process design under uncertainty Model-based uncertainty quantification in AM Uncertainty quantification in AM with heterogeneous data sources Machine learning techniques (e.g., deep learning) for UQ&M in AM Validation and certification of AM process under uncertainty Reliability analysis in AM Health monitoring, diagnostics, prognostics, and control of AM processes under uncertainty Heterogeneous, multi-modal, and multi-scale data fusion under uncertainty for UQ&M in AM Sensitivity analysis in AM under uncertainty Publication Target Dates Paper submission opens: November 1, 2020 Paper submission deadline: February 1, 2021 First reviews completed: June 1, 2021 Second reviews completed: September 30, 2021 Special Issue finalized: November 2021 Submission Instructions Papers should be submitted electronically to the journal at journaltool.asme.org. If you already have an account, log in as author and select Submit Paper at the bottom of the page. If you do not have an account, select Submissions and follow the steps. In either case, at the Paper Submittal page, select the ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems, Part B: Mechanical Engineering and then select the Special Issue Uncertainty Quantification and Management in Additive Manufacturing (SI046B). Early submission before the deadline is strongly encouraged to promote early review and publication of this Special Issue. Quality Assurance Standards The Special Issue will include only high quality, original contributions that advance the state of the art. The standard review procedure of ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems will guarantee the quality of the accepted manuscripts. From 2016 onward, all articles in the journal are included in Web of Science and in Scopus. Guest Editors Zhen Hu, University of Michigan-Dearborn, Dearborn, MI, USA, zhennhu@umich.edu Saideep Nannapaneni, Wichita State University, Wichita, KS, USA, saideep.nannapaneni@wichita.edu Sankaran Mahadevan, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, USA, sankaran.mahadevan@vanderbilt.edu The American Society of Mechanical EngineersÂ® ( ASMEÂ® ) 093020 - 21472 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com. Text: Call for Papers: Special Issue on Uncertainty Quantification and Management in Additive Manufacturing ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Eng. Systems ASME's Guide for Journal Authors Submit Manuscript â†’ CALL FOR PAPERSASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems, Part B: Mechanical EngineeringSpecial Issue on Uncertainty Quantification and Management in Additive Manufacturing (SI046B) Additive Manufacturing (AM) represents a new paradigm of manufacturing where parts are manufactured using their 3D models (such as CAD models) by joining materials in a layer-by-layer manner. AM can have significant impact on the economies all over the world, as it tends to be more sustainable (in terms of material wastage) compared to traditional manufacturing processes. Widespread implementation of AM requires robust techniques for performance evaluation, quality control, and certification. In reality, manufacturing processes are impacted by heterogeneous uncertainty sources at various stages of a manufacturing process, such as raw materials, process equipment, process parameters, process simulation models, and sensors. Therefore, techniques of Uncertainty Quantification and Management (UQ&M) are essential for the quality control and certification of AM processes. With the development of advanced simulation techniques, artificial intelligence, and big data analytics, new UQ&M approaches are emerging to enable model-based quality control and certification, data-driven quality monitoring, and AI-based quality assurance in AM. This Special Issue is dedicated to recent advances in the field of UQ&M with application in AM. Topics of interest include but are not limited to the following: AM process design under uncertainty Model-based uncertainty quantification in AM Uncertainty quantification in AM with heterogeneous data sources Machine learning techniques (e.g., deep learning) for UQ&M in AM Validation and certification of AM process under uncertainty Reliability analysis in AM Health monitoring, diagnostics, prognostics, and control of AM processes under uncertainty Heterogeneous, multi-modal, and multi-scale data fusion under uncertainty for UQ&M in AM Sensitivity analysis in AM under uncertainty Publication Target Dates Paper submission opens: November 1, 2020 Paper submission deadline: February 1, 2021 First reviews completed: June 1, 2021 Second reviews completed: September 30, 2021 Special Issue finalized: November 2021 Submission Instructions Papers should be submitted electronically to the journal at journaltool.asme.org. If you already have an account, log in as author and select Submit Paper at the bottom of the page. If you do not have an account, select Submissions and follow the steps. In either case, at the Paper Submittal page, select the ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems, Part B: Mechanical Engineering and then select the Special Issue Uncertainty Quantification and Management in Additive Manufacturing (SI046B). Early submission before the deadline is strongly encouraged to promote early review and publication of this Special Issue. Quality Assurance Standards The Special Issue will include only high quality, original contributions that advance the state of the art. The standard review procedure of ASCE-ASME Journal of Risk and Uncertainty in Engineering Systems will guarantee the quality of the accepted manuscripts. From 2016 onward, all articles in the journal are included in Web of Science and in Scopus. Guest Editors Zhen Hu, University of Michigan-Dearborn, Dearborn, MI, USA, zhennhu@umich.edu Saideep Nannapaneni, Wichita State University, Wichita, KS, USA, saideep.nannapaneni@wichita.edu Sankaran Mahadevan, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, USA, sankaran.mahadevan@vanderbilt.edu The American Society of Mechanical EngineersÂ® ( ASMEÂ® ) 093020 - 21472 This email was sent to chandubinu10@gmail.com.
